Utah Code Annotated - Title 19 - Environmental Quality Code
===========================================================

Utah Code Annotated - Title 19 - Chapter 1 - General Provisions
***************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-101 Short title.
-------------------------------------------
This title is known as the "Environmental Quality Code."

Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-102 Purposes.
----------------------------------------
The purpose of this title is to:Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-102(1): clarify the powers and duties of the Department of Environmental Quality in relationship to local health departments;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-102(2): provide effective, coordinated management of state environmental concerns;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-102(3): safeguard public health and quality of life by protecting and improving environmental quality while considering the benefits to public health, the impacts on economic development, property, wildlife, tourism, business, agriculture, forests, and other interests, and the costs to the public and to industry; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-102(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-102(4)(a): strengthen local health departments' environmental programs;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-102(4)(b): build consensus among the public, industry, and local governments in developing environmental protection goals; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-102(4)(c): appropriately balance the need for environmental protection with the need for economic and industrial development.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-103 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this title:Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-103(1): "Department" means the Department of Environmental Quality.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-103(2): 19-1-104 "Executive director" means the executive director of the department appointed pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-103(3): Title 26A, Chapter 1, Part 1, Local Health Department Act "Local health department" means a local health department as defined in
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-103(4): "Person" means an individual, trust, firm, estate, company, corporation, partnership, association, state, state or federal agency or entity, municipality, commission, or political subdivision of a state.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-104 Creation of department -- Appointment of executive director.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-104(1): There is created within state government the Department of Environmental Quality.  The department shall be administered by an executive director.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-104(2): The executive director shall be appointed by the governor with the advice and consent of the Senate and shall serve at the pleasure of the governor.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-104(3): The executive director shall have demonstrated the necessary administrative and professional ability through education and experience to efficiently and effectively manage the department's affairs.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-104(4): Title 67, Chapter 22, State Officer Compensation The Legislature shall fix the compensation of the executive director in accordance with

Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-109 Clean Air Support Restricted Account.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-109(1): There is created in the General Fund a restricted account known as the "Clean Air Support Restricted Account."
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-109(2): 41-1a-422 The account shall be funded by:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-109(2)(a): 41-1a-422 contributions deposited into the account in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-109(2)(b): private contributions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-109(2)(c): donations or grants from public or private entities.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-109(3): Title 51, Chapter 7, State Money Management Act
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-109(3)(a): Title 51, Chapter 7, State Money Management Act The state treasurer shall invest money in the account according to
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-109(3)(b): The Division of Finance shall deposit interest or other earnings derived from investment of account money into the account.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-109(4): Subject to appropriation, the department shall distribute the money in the account to one or more organizations that:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-109(4)(a): are tax exempt under Section 501(c)(3), Internal Revenue Code; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-109(4)(b): have as part of the organization's mission:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-109(4)(b)(i): to encourage and educate the public about simple changes to improve air quality in the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-109(4)(b)(ii): to provide grants to organizations or individuals with innovative ideas to reduce emissions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-109(4)(b)(iii): to partner with other organizations to strengthen efforts to improve air quality.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-109(5): The department may also expend funds in the account to pay the costs of issuing or reordering Clean Air Support special group license plate decals.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-201(8)(a): (8); 11-58-102 As used in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-201(8)(a)(i): "Environmental impacts" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-201(8)(a)(i)(A): impacts on air quality, including impacts associated with air emissions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-201(8)(a)(i)(B): impacts on water quality, including impacts associated with storm water runoff.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-201(8)(a)(ii): 11-58-102 "Inland port" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-201(8)(a)(iii): "Inland port area" means the area in and around the inland port that bears the environmental impacts of destruction, construction, development, and operational activities within the inland port.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-201(8)(a)(iv): "Monitoring facilities" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-201(8)(a)(iv)(A): for monitoring air quality, a sensor system consisting of monitors to measure levels of research-grade particulate matter, ozone, and oxides of nitrogen, and data logging equipment with internal data storage that are interconnected at all times to capture air quality readings and store data; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-201(8)(a)(iv)(B): for monitoring water quality, facilities to collect groundwater samples, including in existing conveyances and outfalls, to evaluate sediment, metals, organics, and nutrients due to storm water.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-201(8)(b): Title 11, Chapter 58, Part 3, Port Authority Board The department shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-201(8)(b)(i): develop and implement a sampling and analysis plan to:

Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-201(8)(b)(i)(B): characterize the environmental baseline for only air quality for the Salt Lake International Airport; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-201(8)(b)(i)(C): define the frequency, parameters, and locations for monitoring;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-201(8)(b)(ii): establish and maintain monitoring facilities to measure the environmental impacts in the inland port area arising from destruction, construction, development, and operational activities within the inland port;

Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-202 Duties and powers of the executive director.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-202(1): 19-1-301 The executive director shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-202(1)(a): administer and supervise the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-202(1)(b): coordinate policies and program activities conducted through boards, divisions, and offices of the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-202(1)(c): approve the proposed budget of each board, division, and office within the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-202(1)(d): approve all applications for federal grants or assistance in support of any department program;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-202(1)(e): with the governor's specific, prior approval, expend funds appropriated by the Legislature necessary for participation by the state in any fund, property, or service provided by the federal government; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-202(1)(f): 19-1-301 in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-202(2): 19-1-106; 19-1-106; Title 63A, Chapter 17, Utah State Personnel Management Act; Title 19, Chapter 6, Part 3, Hazardous Substances Mitigation Act; Title 19, Chapter 8, Voluntary Cleanup Program The executive director may:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-202(2)(a): 19-1-106; 19-1-106 issue orders to enforce state laws and rules established by the department except where the enforcement power is given to a board created under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-202(2)(b): with the approval of the governor, participate in the distribution, disbursement, or administration of any fund or service, advanced, offered, or contributed by the federal government for purposes consistent with the powers and duties of the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-202(2)(c): accept and receive funds and gifts available from private and public groups for the purposes of promoting and protecting the public health and the environment and expend the funds as appropriated by the Legislature;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-202(2)(d): make policies not inconsistent with law for the internal administration and government of the department, the conduct of its employees, and the custody, use, and preservation of the records, papers, books, documents, and property of the department;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-202(2)(e): create advisory committees as necessary to assist in carrying out the provisions of this title;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-202(2)(f): appoint division directors who may be removed at the will of the executive director and who shall be compensated in an amount fixed by the executive director;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-202(2)(g): advise, consult, and cooperate with other agencies of the state, the federal government, other states and interstate agencies, affected groups, political subdivisions, and industries in carrying out the purposes of this title;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-202(2)(h): Title 63A, Chapter 17, Utah State Personnel Management Act consistent with
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-202(2)(i): authorize any employee or representative of the division to conduct inspections as permitted in this title;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-202(2)(j): encourage, participate in, or conduct any studies, investigations, research, and demonstrations relating to hazardous materials or substances releases necessary to meet the requirements of this title;

Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-203 Representatives of department authorized to enter regulated premises.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-203(1): Authorized representatives of the department, upon presentation of appropriate credentials, may enter at reasonable times upon the premises of properties regulated under this title to perform inspections to insure compliance with rules made by the department.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-203(2): The inspection authority provided in this section does not apply to chapters in this title which provide for specific inspection procedures and authority.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-204 Legal advice and representation for department.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-204(1): The attorney general is the legal adviser for the department and the executive director and shall defend them in all actions and proceedings brought against either of them.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-204(2): 19-1-106 The attorney general or the county attorney of the county in which a cause of action arises or a public offense occurs shall bring any civil or criminal action requested by the executive director or any board created in Section


Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-205 Assumption of responsibilities.
--------------------------------------------------------------
The department assumes all the policymaking functions, regulatory and enforcement powers, rights, duties, and responsibilities of the Division of Environmental Health, the Air Conservation Committee, the Solid and Hazardous Waste Committee, the Utah Safe Drinking Water Committee, and the Water Pollution Control Committee previously vested in the Department of Health and Human Services and its executive director:Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-205(1): including programs for individual wastewater disposal systems, liquid scavenger operations, and vault and earthen pit privies; but
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-205(2): excluding all other sanitation programs, which shall be administered by the Department of Health and Human Services.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-207 Regulatory certainty to support economic recovery.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-207(1): (2) On or before June 30, 2021, the Air Quality Board or the Water Quality Board may not make, amend, or repeal a rule related to air or water quality pursuant to this title, if formal rulemaking was not initiated on or before July 1, 2020, unless the rule constitutes:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-207(1)(a): a state rule related to a federally-delegated program;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-207(1)(b): a rule mandated by statute to be made, amended, or repealed on or before July 1, 2020; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-207(1)(c): (2) subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-207(1)(c)(i): cause an imminent peril to the public health, safety, or welfare;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-207(1)(c)(ii): cause an imminent budget reduction because of budget restraints or federal requirements;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-207(1)(c)(iii): place the agency in violation of federal or state law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-207(1)(c)(iv): fail to provide regulatory relief.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-207(2): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; (1)(c) In addition to complying with
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-207(3): On or after August 31, 2020, but on or before June 30, 2021, the Air Quality Board, Division of Air Quality, Water Quality Board, or Division of Water Quality may not impose a new fee or increase a fee related to air or water quality pursuant to this title or rules made under this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-207(4): Only the Legislature may extend the time limitations of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-207(5): Notwithstanding the other provisions of this section, this section does not apply to a rule, fee, or fee increase to the extent that the rule, fee, or fee increase applies to an activity in a county of the first or second class.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-207(6): Notwithstanding the other provisions of this section, the agencies may engage with stakeholders in the process of discussing, developing, and drafting a rule, fee, or fee increase on or after July 1, 2020, but on or before June 30, 2021.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-301.5(17)(d)(ii)(C): the stay, if issued, would not be adverse to the public interest; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-301.5(17)(d)(ii)(D): there is a substantial likelihood that the party seeking the stay will prevail on the merits of the underlying claim, or the case presents serious issues on the merits, which should be the subject of further adjudication.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-302 Violation of laws and orders unlawful.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
It is unlawful for any person:Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-302(1): to violate the provisions of the laws of this title or the terms of any order or rule issued under it; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-302(2): to fail to remove or abate from private property under the person's control at his own expense within 48 hours, or such other reasonable time as the department determines, after being ordered to do so, any nuisance, source of filth, or other sanitation violation.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-303 Criminal and civil penalties -- Liability for violations.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-303(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-303(1)(a): Any person who violates any provision of this title or lawful orders or rules adopted under this title by the department shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-303(1)(a)(i): in a civil proceeding be assessed a penalty not to exceed the sum of $5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-303(1)(a)(ii): in a criminal proceeding:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-303(1)(a)(ii)(A): for the first violation, be guilty of a class B misdemeanor; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-303(1)(a)(ii)(B): for a subsequent similar violation within two years, be guilty of a class A misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-303(1)(b): In addition, a person is liable for any expense incurred by the department in removing or abating any violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-303(2): Assessment or conviction under this title does not relieve the person assessed or convicted from civil liability for any act which was also a violation of the public health laws.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-303(3): Each day of violation of this title or rules made by the department under it may be considered a separate violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-303(4): (1); (3) The enforcement procedures and penalties provided in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-303(5): Unless otherwise specified in statute, the department shall deposit all civil penalties and fines imposed and collected under this title into the General Fund.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-304 Principal and branch offices of department.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-304(1): The principal office of the department shall be in Salt Lake County.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-304(2): The department may establish branch offices at other places in the state to furnish comprehensive and effective environmental programs and to coordinate with and assist local health officers.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-305 Administrative enforcement proceedings -- Tolling of limitation period.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Issuing a notice of a violation, an order, or a notice of agency action under this title tolls the running of the period of limitation for commencing a civil action to assess or collect a penalty until the sooner of:Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-305(1): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act the day on which the notice of violation, order, or agency action becomes final under
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-305(2): three years from the day on which the department issues a notice or order described in this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(1): "Air barrier system" means air barrier material, a system, or an assembly that is specifically and primarily designed to minimize the passage of air through the building thermal envelope and the assemblies when installed in or on a dwelling.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(2): "Clean fuel" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(2)(a): propane, natural gas, renewable natural gas, hydrogen, or electricity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(2)(b): other fuel that meets the clean fuel vehicle standards in the federal Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990, 42 U.S.C. Sec. 7521 et seq.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(3)(a): "Clean vehicle" means a vehicle that:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(3)(a)(i): uses a clean fuel;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(3)(a)(ii): is an electric-hybrid vehicle; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(3)(a)(iii): is an electric vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(3)(b): "Clean vehicle" may include heavy duty equipment, such as:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(3)(b)(i): a tractor;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(3)(b)(ii): earth-moving equipment;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(3)(b)(iii): an off-highway vehicle; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(3)(b)(iv): other equipment approved by the director of the Division of Air Quality.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(4): "Dwelling" means a house, multi-family dwelling, apartment complex, or other residential type building.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(5): "Electric-hybrid vehicle" means a vehicle:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(5)(a): primarily powered by an electric motor that draws current from:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(5)(a)(i): rechargeable storage batteries;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(5)(a)(ii): fuel cells; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(5)(a)(iii): other sources of electric current; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(5)(b): that also operates on or is capable of operating on a nonelectrical source of power.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(6): "Electric vehicle" means a vehicle powered by an electric motor that draws current from rechargeable storage batteries, fuel cells, or other sources of electric current and does not need carbon based fuel for operation.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(7): "Energy-efficient building envelope improvements" means an insulation and air barrier system that meets the prescriptive criteria for insulation and air barrier systems established by the 2021 International Energy Conservation Code.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(8): 19-1-403 "Fund" means the Clean Fuels and Emission Reduction Technology Fund created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(9): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(9)(a): "Government vehicle" means a motor vehicle:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(9)(a)(i): registered in Utah; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(9)(a)(ii): owned and operated by:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(9)(a)(ii)(A): the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(9)(a)(ii)(B): a public trust authority;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(9)(a)(ii)(C): a school district;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(9)(a)(ii)(D): a county; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(9)(a)(ii)(E): a municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(9)(b): "Government vehicle" includes a metropolitan rapid transit motor vehicle, bus, truck, law enforcement vehicle, or emergency vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(10): "Incremental cost" means the difference between the cost of an OEM vehicle and the same vehicle model manufactured without the clean fuel fueling system.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(11): "Insulation" means a material or system that is specifically and primarily designed to reduce the heat loss or gain of a dwelling unit when installed in or on the dwelling unit.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(12): "OEM vehicle" means a vehicle manufactured by the original vehicle manufacturer or the manufacturer's contractor as a clean vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(13): "Private sector business vehicle" means a motor vehicle registered in Utah that is owned and operated solely in the conduct of a private business enterprise.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(14): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act "Qualified energy-efficient residential dwelling" means a dwelling with an energy efficiency rating determined by the department by rule made in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(15): "Refueling equipment" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(15)(a): compressors when used separately;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(15)(b): compressors used in combination with cascade tanks;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(15)(c): other equipment that constitute a central refueling system capable of dispensing vehicle fuel; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-402(15)(d): electric charging stations and equipment.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-501 Title.
-------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Engine Coolant Bittering Agent Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-502 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-502(1): "Bittering agent" means an aversive agent that renders engine coolant unpalatable.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-502(2): "Engine coolant" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-502(2)(a): a substance or preparation, regardless of its origin, used as the cooling medium in the cooling system of an internal combustion engine to provide protection against freezing, overheating, and corrosion of the cooling system; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-502(2)(b): a product that is labeled to indicate or imply that it will prevent freezing or overheating of the cooling system of an internal combustion engine.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-503 Requirements for engine coolant sold in state.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
On or after January 1, 2011, a person may not sell engine coolant to a person in this state that is manufactured on or after January 1, 2011, if the engine coolant:Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-503(1): contains more than 10% ethylene glycol; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-503(2): does not contain:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-503(2)(a): denatonium benzoate within the following amounts:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-503(2)(a)(i): a minimum of 30 parts per million; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-503(2)(a)(ii): a maximum of 50 parts per million; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-503(2)(b): a similar bittering agent that renders the engine coolant unpalatable if it meets or exceeds the degree of aversion as compared to denatonium benzoate at a concentration of 30 parts per million.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-504 Recordkeeping.
---------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-504(1): 19-1-503 A manufacturer or packager of engine coolant that sells the engine coolant to a person in this state shall maintain for at least three years a record of the following for a bittering agent used in the engine coolant in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-504(1)(a): the trade name;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-504(1)(b): the scientific name; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-504(1)(c): the active ingredients.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-504(2): (1) A manufacturer or packager shall make the information described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-505 Liability limitation.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-505(1): (1)(b); 19-1-503; (1)(a); 19-1-503
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-505(1)(a): (1)(b); 19-1-503 Subject to the other provisions of this section, a person may not be held liable as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-505(1)(a)(i): the person is a manufacturer, processor, distributor, recycler, or seller of an engine coolant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-505(1)(a)(ii): 19-1-503 the engine coolant at issue contains denatonium benzoate in a concentration described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-505(1)(b): (1)(a); 19-1-503 A person described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-505(1)(b)(i): personal injury;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-505(1)(b)(ii): death;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-505(1)(b)(iii): property damage;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-505(1)(b)(iv): damage to the environment, including natural resources; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-505(1)(b)(v): economic loss.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-505(2): (1); (1)(b) Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-505(2)(b): (1)(b) the injury described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-505(3): Nothing in this section shall be construed to exempt any manufacturer or distributor of denatonium benzoate from any liability related to denatonium benzoate.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-506 Preemption.
------------------------------------------
With respect to a retail container containing less than 55 gallons of engine coolant, a political subdivision of this state may not establish or enforce a prohibition, limitation, standard, or other requirement relating to the inclusion of a bittering agent in an engine coolant that differs from, or is in addition to, a requirement under this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-507 Civil action.
--------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-507(1): The attorney general or a person may bring a civil action in a court of competent jurisdiction to seek:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-507(1)(a): an injunction to enforce this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-507(1)(b): if the action is brought by the attorney general, a civil penalty not to exceed $500 for each day this part is violated.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-507(2): (1); (2) In an action brought under this section, a court may:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-507(2)(a): order injunctive relief;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-507(2)(b): (1) impose a civil penalty to the extent provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-507(2)(c): award attorney fees and costs to the attorney general or person who brings the civil action, if the attorney general or person prevails; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-507(2)(d): (2) take a combination of actions under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-507(3): A civil penalty imposed under this section shall be deposited into the General Fund.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-508 Exemptions.
------------------------------------------
This part does not apply to:Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-508(1): the sale of a motor vehicle or a part of a motor vehicle that contains engine coolant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-508(2): a wholesale container of engine coolant that contains 55 gallons or more of engine coolant if it contains a conspicuous label indicating whether or not it contains a bittering agent.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-601 Title.
-------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Environmental Mitigation and Response Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-602 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-602(1): "Environmental mitigation" means an action or activity intended to remedy, reduce, or offset known negative impacts to the environment.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-602(2): "Environmental response action" means action taken to prevent, eliminate, minimize, investigate, monitor, clean up, or remove contaminants in the environment.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-602(3): "Financial assurance" means a mechanism or instrument intended to provide funds if necessary to the department to conduct closure, monitoring, or cleanup of a specific facility or site in accordance with the applicable environmental requirements provided in this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-602(4): "Funding source" means an individual or entity that provides a monetary contribution to the Environmental Mitigation and Response Fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-602(5): "Natural resource damage" means damages to land, fish, wildlife, biota, air, water, ground water, drinking water supplies, and other resources that are held in trust for the public or otherwise controlled by the United States, the state, or local government.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-602(6): "Unused funds" means the remaining funds from a specific funding source following the complete implementation of the environmental mitigation or response actions pursuant to the terms and conditions of the contribution.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-603 Environmental Mitigation and Response Fund.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-603(1): There is created an expendable special revenue fund known as the Environmental Mitigation and Response Fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-603(2): (3); (4) The fund consists of:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-603(2)(a): (3); (4) public and private funding sources made under Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-603(2)(b): legally binding bankruptcy, financial assurance, or natural resource damage claim settlements; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-603(2)(c): interest earnings on cash balances.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-603(3): The department may accept contributions for deposit into the fund from public and private sources, including from a source as a condition of a consent decree, settlement agreement, stipulated agreement, or court order.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-603(4): If funds are deposited as part of a consent decree, settlement agreement, stipulated agreement, or court order, the source of the funding may specify terms and conditions in which the funds may be used, in accordance with the consent decree, settlement agreement, stipulated agreement, or court order.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-603(5): Unless mandated by court order, the department may refuse funds if the department determines it is incapable of meeting the terms and conditions of the agreement to obtain the funds, including covering the costs to administer the fund and oversee the implementation of the specific mitigation or response action.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-603(6): The fund may account for assets held by the state for:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-603(6)(a): an individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-603(6)(b): a private or public entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-603(6)(c): another governmental unit, including a local or federal agency;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-603(6)(d): a state agency; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-1-603(6)(e): a Native American tribe.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 19 - Chapter 2 - Air Conservation Act
*****************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-101 Short title -- Policy of state and purpose of chapter -- Support of local and regional programs -- Provision of coordinated statewide program.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-101(1): This chapter is known as the "Air Conservation Act."
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-101(2): It is the policy of this state and the purpose of this chapter to achieve and maintain levels of air quality which will protect human health and safety, and to the greatest degree practicable, prevent injury to plant and animal life and property, foster the comfort and convenience of the people, promote the economic and social development of this state, and facilitate the enjoyment of the natural attractions of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-101(3): Local and regional air pollution control programs shall be supported to the extent practicable as essential instruments to secure and maintain appropriate levels of air quality.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-101(4): The purpose of this chapter is to:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-101(4)(a): provide for a coordinated statewide program of air pollution prevention, abatement, and control;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-101(4)(b): provide for an appropriate distribution of responsibilities among the state and local units of government;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-101(4)(c): facilitate cooperation across jurisdictional lines in dealing with problems of air pollution not confined within single jurisdictions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-101(4)(d): provide a framework within which air quality may be protected and consideration given to the public interest at all levels of planning and development within the state.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-102(1): "Air pollutant" means a substance that qualifies as an air pollutant as defined in 42 U.S.C. Sec. 7602.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-102(2): "Air pollutant source" means private and public sources of emissions of air pollutants.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-102(3): "Air pollution" means the presence of an air pollutant in the ambient air in the quantities, for a duration, and under the conditions and circumstances that are injurious to human health or welfare, animal or plant life, or property, or would unreasonably interfere with the enjoyment of life or use of property, as determined by the rules adopted by the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-102(4): "Ambient air" means that portion of the atmosphere, external to buildings, to which the general public has access.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-102(5): "Asbestos" means the asbestiform varieties of serpentine (chrysotile), riebeckite (crocidolite), cummingtonite-grunerite, anthophyllite, actinolite-tremolite, and libby amphibole.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-102(6): "Asbestos-containing material" means a material containing more than 1% asbestos, as determined using the method adopted in 40 C.F.R. Part 61, Subpart M, National Emission Standard for Asbestos.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-102(7): "Asbestos inspection" means an activity undertaken to determine the presence or location, or to assess the condition of, asbestos-containing material or suspected asbestos-containing material, whether by visual or physical examination, or by taking samples of the material.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-102(8): "Board" means the Air Quality Board.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-102(9): "Clean school bus" means the same as that term is defined in 42 U.S.C. Sec. 16091.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-102(10): "Director" means the director of the Division of Air Quality.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-102(11): 19-1-105 "Division" means the Division of Air Quality created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-102(12): "Friable asbestos-containing material" means a material containing more than 1% asbestos, as determined using the method adopted in 40 C.F.R. Part 61, Subpart M, National Emission Standard for Asbestos, that hand pressure can crumble, pulverize, or reduce to powder when dry.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-102(13): "Indirect source" means a facility, building, structure, or installation which attracts or may attract mobile source activity that results in emissions of a pollutant for which there is a national standard.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103 Members of board -- Appointment -- Terms -- Organization -- Per diem and expenses.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(1): Title 63G, Chapter 24, Part 2, Vacancies The board consists of the following nine members:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(1)(a): the following non-voting member, except that the member may vote to break a tie vote between the voting members:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(1)(a)(i): the executive director; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(1)(a)(ii): an employee of the department designated by the executive director; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(1)(b): Title 63G, Chapter 24, Part 2, Vacancies the following eight voting members, who shall be appointed by the governor with the advice and consent of the Senate in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(1)(b)(i): one representative who:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(1)(b)(i)(A): is not connected with industry;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(1)(b)(i)(B): is an expert in air quality matters; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(1)(b)(i)(C): is a Utah-licensed physician, a Utah-licensed professional engineer, or a scientist with relevant training and experience;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(1)(b)(ii): two government representatives who do not represent the federal government;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(1)(b)(iii): one representative from the mining industry;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(1)(b)(iv): one representative from the fuels industry;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(1)(b)(v): one representative from the manufacturing industry;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(1)(b)(vi): one representative from the public who represents:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(1)(b)(vi)(A): an environmental nongovernmental organization; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(1)(b)(vi)(B): a nongovernmental organization that represents community interests and does not represent industry interests; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(1)(b)(vii): one representative from the public who is trained and experienced in public health.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(2): 19-1-201(1)(d)(i)(A); Title 63G, Chapter 24, Part 3, Conflicts of Interest; 19-1-201(1)(d)(i)(B) A member of the board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(2)(a): be knowledgeable about air pollution matters, as evidenced by a professional degree, a professional accreditation, or documented experience;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(2)(b): be a resident of Utah;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(2)(c): 19-1-201(1)(d)(i)(A) attend board meetings in accordance with the attendance rules made by the department under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(2)(d): Title 63G, Chapter 24, Part 3, Conflicts of Interest; 19-1-201(1)(d)(i)(B) comply with all applicable statutes, rules, and policies, including the conflict of interest provisions described in
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(3): No more than five of the appointed members of the board shall belong to the same political party.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(4): A majority of the members of the board may not derive any significant portion of their income from persons subject to permits or orders under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(5): (5)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(5)(a): Members shall be appointed for a term of four years.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(5)(b): (5)(a) Notwithstanding the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(6): A member may serve more than one term.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(7): A member shall hold office until the expiration of the member's term and until the member's successor is appointed, but not more than 90 days after the expiration of the member's term.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(8): When a vacancy occurs in the membership for any reason, the replacement shall be appointed for the unexpired term.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(9): The board shall elect annually a chair and a vice chair from its members.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(10)(a): The board shall meet at least quarterly.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(10)(b): Special meetings may be called by the chair upon the chair's own initiative, upon the request of the director, or upon the request of three members of the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(10)(c): Three days' notice shall be given to each member of the board before a meeting.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-103(11): Five members constitute a quorum at a meeting, and the action of a majority of members present is the action of the board.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3 Clean fuel requirements for fleets.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3(1): (1)(b)(i); 41-6a-102; Title 41, Chapter 1a, Part 2, Registration; 41-1a-102 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3(1)(a): "1990 Clean Air Act" means the federal Clean Air Act as amended in 1990.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3(1)(b): (1)(b)(i) "Clean fuel" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3(1)(b)(i): propane, compressed natural gas, or electricity;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3(1)(b)(ii): (1)(b)(i) other fuel the board determines annually on or before July 1 is at least as effective as fuels under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3(1)(b)(iii): other fuel that meets the clean fuel vehicle standards in the 1990 Clean Air Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3(1)(c): "Fleet" means 10 or more vehicles:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3(1)(c)(i): owned or operated by a single entity as defined by board rule; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3(1)(c)(ii): capable of being fueled or that are fueled at a central location.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3(1)(d): 41-6a-102; Title 41, Chapter 1a, Part 2, Registration; 41-1a-102 "Fleet" does not include motor vehicles that are:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3(1)(d)(i): held for lease or rental to the general public;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3(1)(d)(ii): held for sale or used as demonstration vehicles by motor vehicle dealers;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3(1)(d)(iii): used by motor vehicle manufacturers for product evaluations or tests;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3(1)(d)(iv): 41-6a-102 authorized emergency vehicles as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3(1)(d)(v): Title 41, Chapter 1a, Part 2, Registration registered under
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3(1)(d)(vi): 41-1a-102 special mobile equipment as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3(1)(d)(vii): heavy duty trucks with a gross vehicle weight rating of more than 26,000 pounds;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3(1)(d)(viii): regularly used by employees to drive to and from work, parked at the employees' personal residences when they are not at their employment, and not practicably fueled at a central location;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3(1)(d)(ix): owned, operated, or leased by public transit districts; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3(1)(d)(x): exempted by board rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3(2): 19-1-406
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3(2)(a): After evaluation of reasonably available pollution control strategies, and as part of the state implementation plan demonstrating attainment of the national ambient air quality standards, the board may by rule require fleets in specified geographical areas to use clean fuels if the board determines fleet use of clean fuels is:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3(2)(a)(i): necessary to demonstrate attainment of the national ambient air quality standards in an area where they are required; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3(2)(a)(ii): reasonably cost effective when compared to other similarly beneficial control strategies for demonstrating attainment of the national ambient air quality standards.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3(2)(b): 19-1-406 A vehicle retrofit to operate on compressed natural gas in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3(3): After evaluation of reasonably available pollution control strategies, and as part of a state implementation plan demonstrating only maintenance of the national ambient air quality standards, the board may by rule require fleets in specified geographical areas to use clean fuels if the board determines fleet use of clean fuels is:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3(3)(a): necessary to demonstrate maintenance of the national ambient air quality standards in an area where they are required; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3(3)(b): reasonably cost effective as compared with other similarly beneficial control strategies for demonstrating maintenance of the national ambient air quality standards.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-105.3(4): 63J-1-504 Rules the board makes under this section may include:

------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-106(1)(a)(ii): the board finds that the different rule will provide reasonable added protections to public health or the environment of the state or a particular region of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-106(1)(b): The board shall consider the differences between an industry that continuously produces emissions and an industry that episodically produces emissions, and make rules that reflect those differences.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-106(2): (1)(a)(ii) The findings described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-106(2)(a): in writing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-106(2)(b): based on evidence, studies, or other information contained in the record that relates to the state of Utah and type of source involved.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-106(3): In making rules, the board may incorporate by reference corresponding federal regulations.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107 Director -- Appointment -- Powers.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(1): The executive director shall appoint the director.  The director shall serve under the administrative direction of the executive director.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(2): (3); 19-2-104(3)(b)(i); Title 19, Chapter 12, Pollution Control Act
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(2)(a): The director shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(2)(a)(i): prepare and develop comprehensive plans for the prevention, abatement, and control of air pollution in Utah;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(2)(a)(ii): advise, consult, and cooperate with other agencies of the state, the federal government, other states and interstate agencies, and affected groups, political subdivisions, and industries in furtherance of the purposes of this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(2)(a)(iii): review plans, specifications, or other data relative to air pollution control equipment or any part of the air pollution control equipment;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(2)(a)(iv): under the direction of the executive director, represent the state in all matters relating to interstate air pollution, including interstate compacts and similar agreements;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(2)(a)(v): secure necessary scientific, technical, administrative, and operational services, including laboratory facilities, by contract or otherwise;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(2)(a)(vi): encourage voluntary cooperation by persons and affected groups to achieve the purposes of this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(2)(a)(vii): encourage local units of government to handle air pollution within their respective jurisdictions on a cooperative basis and provide technical and consulting assistance to them;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(2)(a)(viii): determine by means of field studies and sampling the degree of air contamination and air pollution in all parts of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(2)(a)(ix): monitor the effects of the emission of air pollutants from motor vehicles on the quality of the outdoor atmosphere in all parts of Utah and take appropriate responsive action;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(2)(a)(x): collect and disseminate information relating to air contamination and air pollution and conduct educational and training programs relating to air contamination and air pollution;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(2)(a)(xi): assess and collect noncompliance penalties as required in Section 120 of the federal Clean Air Act, 42 U.S.C. Section 7420;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(2)(a)(xii): comply with the requirements of federal air pollution laws;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(2)(a)(xiii): subject to the provisions of this chapter, enforce rules through the issuance of orders, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(2)(a)(xiii)(A): prohibiting or abating discharges of wastes affecting ambient air;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(2)(a)(xiii)(B): requiring the construction of new control facilities or any parts of new control facilities or the modification, extension, or alteration of existing control facilities or any parts of new control facilities; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(2)(a)(xiii)(C): adopting other remedial measures to prevent, control, or abate air pollution; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(2)(a)(xiv): as authorized by the board and subject to the provisions of this chapter, act as executive secretary of the board under the direction of the chairman of the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(2)(b): (3); 19-2-104(3)(b)(i); Title 19, Chapter 12, Pollution Control Act The director may:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(2)(b)(i): employ full-time, temporary, part-time, and contract employees necessary to carry out this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(2)(b)(ii): subject to the provisions of this chapter, authorize an employee or representative of the department to enter at reasonable times and upon reasonable notice in or upon public or private property for the purposes of inspecting and investigating conditions and plant records concerning possible air pollution;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(2)(b)(iii): encourage, participate in, or conduct studies, investigations, research, and demonstrations relating to air pollution and its causes, effects, prevention, abatement, and control, as advisable and necessary for the discharge of duties assigned under this chapter, including the establishment of inventories of pollution sources;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(2)(b)(iv): collect and disseminate information relating to air pollution and the prevention, control, and abatement of it;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(2)(b)(v): cooperate with studies and research relating to air pollution and its control, abatement, and prevention;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(2)(b)(vi): (3) subject to Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(2)(b)(vi)(B): the air pollution problem that may be related to the source;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(2)(b)(vii): accept, receive, and administer grants or other funds or gifts from public and private agencies, including the federal government, for the purpose of carrying out any of the functions of this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107(2)(b)(viii): 19-2-104(3)(b)(i) subject to Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.5 Solid fuel burning.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.5(1): The division shall create a public awareness campaign, in consultation with representatives of the solid fuel burning industry, the healthcare industry, and members of the clean air community, on best wood burning practices and the effects of wood burning on air quality, specifically targeting nonattainment areas.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.5(2): (2)(b); (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.5(2)(a): (2)(b) Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.5(2)(b): (2)(a) In creating the program described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.5(2)(b)(i): have an adjusted gross household income of 250% or less of the federal poverty level;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.5(2)(b)(ii): live in a house where wood is the sole or supplemental source of heating; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.5(2)(b)(iii): live within six miles of the Great Salt Lake Base and Meridian.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.5(3): (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.5(3)(a): The division may not impose a burning ban prohibiting burning during a specified seasonal period of time.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.5(3)(b): (3)(a) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.5(3)(b)(i): allow burning:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.5(3)(b)(i)(A): during local emergencies and utility outages; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.5(3)(b)(i)(B): if the primary purpose of the burning is to cook food; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.5(3)(b)(ii): provide for exemptions, through registration with the division, for:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.5(3)(b)(ii)(A): devices that are sole sources of heat; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.5(3)(b)(ii)(B): locations where natural gas service is limited or unavailable.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.5(4): (2) The division may seek private donations and federal sources of funding to supplement any funds appropriated by the Legislature to fulfill Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.7 Water heater regulations.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.7(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.7(1)(a): "Natural gas-fired water heater" means a device that heats water by the combustion of natural gas to a thermostatically-controlled temperature not exceeding 210 degrees Fahrenheit for use external to the vessel at pressures not exceeding 160 pounds per square inch gauge.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.7(1)(b): "Recreational vehicle" means a motor home, travel trailer, truck camper, or camping trailer, with or without motive power, designed for human habitation for recreational, emergency, or other occupancy.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.7(2): Title 15A, State Construction and Fire Codes Act A person may not sell or purchase a natural gas-fired water heater that is manufactured after July 1, 2018 with the intent to install it in Utah if the natural gas-fired water heater exceeds the applicable nitrogen oxide emission rate limit set in
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.7(3): A manufacturer in Utah shall display the model number and nitrogen oxide emission rate of a water heater complying with this section on:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.7(3)(a): the shipping carton for the water heater; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.7(3)(b): the permanent rating plate of each water heater unit.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.7(4): This section does not apply to a water heater unit that:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.7(4)(a): uses a fuel other than natural gas;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.7(4)(b): is used in a recreational vehicle; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-107.7(4)(c): is manufactured in Utah for shipment and use outside of Utah.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-109.1(1)(c): "Operating permit" means a permit issued by the director to sources of air pollution that meet the requirements of Titles IV and V of the 1990 Clean Air Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-109.1(1)(d): "Program" means the air pollution operating permit program established under this section to comply with Title V of the 1990 Clean Air Act.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-109.1(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-109.1(3)(a): Operating permits issued under this section shall be for a period of five years unless the director makes a written finding, after public comment and hearing, and based on substantial evidence in the record, that an operating permit term of less than five years is necessary to protect the public health and the environment of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-109.1(3)(b): The director may issue, modify, or renew an operating permit only after providing public notice, an opportunity for public comment, and an opportunity for a public hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-109.1(3)(c): The director shall, in conformity with the 1990 Clean Air Act and implementing federal regulations, revise the conditions of issued operating permits to incorporate applicable federal regulations in conformity with Section 502(b)(9) of the 1990 Clean Air Act, if the remaining period of the permit is three or more years.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-109.1(3)(d): The director may terminate, modify, revoke, or reissue an operating permit for cause.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-109.1(4)(a): impose a penalty of not more than 50% of the fee, in addition to the fee, plus interest on the fee computed at 12% annually; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-109.1(4)(b): revoke the operating permit.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-109.2 Small business assistance program.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
The division shall establish a small business stationary source technical and environmental compliance assistance program that conforms with Title V of the 1990 Clean Air Act to assist small businesses to comply with state and federal air pollution laws.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-113 Variances -- Judicial review.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-113(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-113(1)(a): A person who owns or is in control of a plant, building, structure, establishment, process, or equipment may apply to the board for a variance from its rules.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-113(1)(b): The board may grant the requested variance following an announced public meeting, if it finds, after considering the endangerment to human health and safety and other relevant factors, that compliance with the rules from which variance is sought would produce serious hardship without equal or greater benefits to the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-113(2): A variance may not be granted under this section until the board has considered the relative interests of the applicant, other owners of property likely to be affected by the discharges, and the general public.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-113(3): (1); (3)(a); (b) A variance or renewal of a variance shall be granted within the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-113(3)(a): if the variance is granted on the grounds that there are no practicable means known or available for the adequate prevention, abatement, or control of the air pollution involved, it shall be only until the necessary means for prevention, abatement, or control become known and available, and subject to the taking of any substitute or alternate measures that the board may prescribe;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-113(3)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-113(3)(b)(i): if the variance is granted on the grounds that compliance with the requirements from which variance is sought will require that measures, because of their extent or cost, must be spread over a long period of time, the variance shall be granted for a reasonable time that, in the view of the  board, is required for implementation of the necessary measures; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-113(3)(b)(ii): a variance granted on this ground shall contain a timetable for the implementation of remedial measures in an expeditious manner and shall be conditioned on adherence to the timetable; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-113(3)(c): (3)(a); (b) if the variance is granted on the ground that it is necessary to relieve or prevent hardship of a kind other than that provided for in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-113(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-113(4)(a): A variance granted under this section may be renewed on terms and conditions and for periods that would be appropriate for initially granting a variance.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-113(4)(b): If a complaint is made to the board because of the variance, a renewal may not be granted unless, following an announced public meeting, the board finds that renewal is justified.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-113(4)(c): To receive a renewal, an applicant shall submit a request for agency action to the board requesting a renewal.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-113(4)(d): Immediately upon receipt of an application for renewal, the board shall give public notice of the application as required by its rules.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-113(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-113(5)(a): A variance or renewal is not a right of the applicant or holder but may be granted at the board's discretion.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-113(5)(b): A person aggrieved by the board's decision may obtain judicial review.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-113(5)(c): Venue for judicial review of informal adjudicative proceedings is in the district court in which the air pollutant source is situated.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-113(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-113(6)(a): The board may review a variance during the term for which it was granted.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-113(6)(b): The review procedure is the same as that for an original application.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-113(6)(c): The variance may be revoked upon a finding that:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-113(6)(c)(i): the nature or amount of emission has changed or increased; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-113(6)(c)(ii): if facts existing at the date of the review had existed at the time of the original application, the variance would not have been granted.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-113(7): 19-2-112 Nothing in this section and no variance or renewal granted pursuant to it shall be construed to prevent or limit the application of the emergency provisions and procedures of Section


Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-114 Activities not in violation of chapter or rules.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The following are not a violation of this chapter or of a rule made under it:Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-114(1): burning incident to horticultural or agricultural operations of:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-114(1)(a): prunings from trees, bushes, and plants; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-114(1)(b): dead or diseased trees, bushes, and plants, including stubble;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-114(2): burning of weed growth along ditch banks incident to clearing these ditches for irrigation purposes;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-114(3): controlled heating of orchards or other crops to lessen the chances of their being frozen so long as the emissions from this heating do not violate minimum standards set by the board; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-114(4): the controlled burning of not more than two structures per year by an organized and operating fire department for the purpose of training fire service personnel when the United States Weather Service clearing index for the area where the burn is to occur is above 500.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-118 Violation of injunction evidence of contempt.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Failure to comply with the terms of any injunction issued under this chapter is prima facie evidence of contempt which is punishable as for other civil contempts.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-119 Civil or criminal remedies not excluded -- Actionable rights under chapter -- No liability for acts of God or other catastrophes.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-119(1): Existing civil or criminal remedies for a wrongful action that is a violation of the law are not excluded by this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-119(2): 19-1-301; 19-1-301.5 Except as provided in Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-119(3): The liabilities imposed for violation of this chapter are not imposed for a violation caused by an act of God, war, strike, riot, or other catastrophe.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-120 Information required of owners or operators of air pollutant sources.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The owner or operator of a stationary air pollutant source in the state shall furnish to the director the reports required by rules made in accordance with Section

Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-121 Ordinances of political subdivisions authorized.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any political subdivision of the state may enact and enforce ordinances to control air pollution that are consistent with this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-122 Cooperative agreements between political subdivisions and department.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-122(1): A political subdivision of the state may enter into and perform, with other political subdivisions of the state or with the department, contracts and agreements as they find proper for establishing, planning, operating, and financing air pollution programs.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-122(2): The agreements may provide for an agency to:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-122(2)(a): supervise and operate an air pollution program;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-122(2)(b): prescribe the agency's powers and duties; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2-122(2)(c): fix the compensation of the agency's members and employees.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-102 Air Quality Policy Advisory Board created -- Composition -- Responsibility -- Terms of office -- Compensation.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-102(1): There is created the Air Quality Policy Advisory Board consisting of the following 12 voting members:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-102(1)(a): two members of the Senate, appointed by the president of the Senate;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-102(1)(b): three members of the House of Representatives, appointed by the speaker of the House of Representatives;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-102(1)(c): the director;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-102(1)(d): one representative of industry interests, appointed by the president of the Senate;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-102(1)(e): one representative of business or economic development interests, appointed by the speaker of the House of Representatives, who has expertise in air quality matters;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-102(1)(f): one representative of the academic community who has expertise in air quality matters, appointed by the president of the Senate;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-102(1)(g): two representatives of the academic community, appointed by the governor, who have expertise in air quality matters; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-102(1)(h): one representative of a nongovernmental organization, appointed by the governor, who:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-102(1)(h)(i): represents community interests;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-102(1)(h)(ii): does not represent industry or business interests; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-102(1)(h)(iii): has expertise in air quality matters.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-102(2): The Air Quality Policy Advisory Board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-102(2)(a): seek the best available science to identify legislative actions to improve air quality;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-102(2)(b): identify and prioritize potential legislation and funding that will improve air quality; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-102(2)(c): make recommendations to the Legislature on how to improve air quality in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-102(3): (3)(b); (1)(d); (h); (3)(a)

Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-102(3)(c): When a vacancy occurs in the membership for any reason, the replacement shall be appointed for the unexpired term.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-102(4): The advisory board shall elect one member to serve as chair of the advisory board for a term of one year.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-102(5):

Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-102(5)(b): The action of the majority of the advisory board when a quorum is present is the action of the advisory board.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105 Prescribed fires, pile burns, and nonfull suppression events.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(1): 19-1-105 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(1)(a): "Board" means the Air Quality Board.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(1)(b): "Burn plan" means the plan required for each fire application ignited by a land manager.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(1)(c): "Burn window" means the period of time during which the prescribed fire is scheduled for ignition.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(1)(d): "Director" means the director of the division.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(1)(e): 19-1-105 "Division" means the Division of Air Quality created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(1)(f): "Exceptional event" means one or more prescribed burning or pile burning events and the resulting emissions that affect air quality in such a way that there exists a clear causal relationship between the specific event and the monitored exceedance or violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(1)(g): "Land manager" means a person who administers, directs, oversees, or controls the use of public or private land, including the application of fire to the land.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(1)(h): "Large prescribed fire" means a fire that a land manager ignites to meet a specific objective, including a resource benefit that covers 20 acres or more per burn.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(1)(i): "Large prescribed pile fire" means a fire that a land manager ignites to meet a specific objective, including a resource benefit, that exceeds 30,000 cubic feet per day.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(1)(j): "Nonfull suppression event" means a naturally ignited wildland fire for which a land manager secures less than full suppression to accomplish a specific prestated resource management objective in a predefined geographic area.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(1)(k): "Pile burning" means a fire or fires that a land manager ignites for fuel mitigation designed to reduce the risk of catastrophic fire, improve ecological health, and prevent dangerous wildfires by burning piled or scattered leaves, pine needles, downed trees, natural woody debris, thick vegetation, or similar organic material left behind after logging or other forest treatments.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(1)(l): "Prescribed burning" means the planned and controlled burning of plant material in order to minimize the risk of catastrophic wildfire or to meet specific land management objectives.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(1)(m): "Wildland" means an area in which development is essentially nonexistent other than the existence of a pipeline, power line, road, railroad, or other transportation or conveyance facility or one or more structures that are widely scattered.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(2): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(2)(a): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The division may not permit a land manager to conduct a large prescribed fire or large prescribed pile fire if the land manager does not comply with the rules made by the board in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(2)(b): (2) In the rules made by the board under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(2)(b)(i): describe the use of a state, county, or municipal resource in the large prescribed fire or large prescribed pile fire;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(2)(b)(ii): provide the division the burn plan for a large prescribed fire or large prescribed pile fire by no later than one week before the day of the burn window; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(2)(b)(iii): notify the division of a nonfull suppression event once a fire becomes a nonfull suppression event.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(3): The director shall approve a prescribed burning or pile burning in wildland areas and the prescribed burning or pile burning may be conducted under the following conditions:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(3)(a): the United States National Weather Service clearing index in the area of the burn is 500 or greater;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(3)(b): the United States National Weather Service clearing index in the area of the burn is less than 500, and to maximize the opportunities for prescribed burning or pile burning the director approves a prescribed burning or pile burning after the land manager demonstrates to the director that the planned prescribed burning or pile burning will:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(3)(b)(i): not cause an exceedance of a national ambient air quality standard outside the wildland area;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(3)(b)(ii): minimize the long range transport of smoke; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(3)(b)(iii): protect visibility in mandatory federal class 1 areas; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(3)(c): the United States National Weather Service clearing index in the burn area is less than 500 and the prescribed burning or pile burning may cause an exceedance of a national ambient air quality standard outside the wildland area if the land manager demonstrates to the director that the prescribed burning or pile burning fuel conditions are optimal to:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(3)(c)(i): protect safety of the public and fire staff;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(3)(c)(ii): minimize the risk of catastrophic fire;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(3)(c)(iii): achieve necessary watershed and ecological conditions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(3)(c)(iv): establish, restore, or maintain a sustainable and resilient wildland ecosystem or to preserve endangered or threatened species through a program of prescribed burning or pile burning.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(4): The director shall approve a prescribed burning or pile burning to reduce hazardous fuels for public safety in areas not defined as wildland and the prescribed burning or pile burning may be conducted under the following conditions:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(4)(a): the United States National Weather Service clearing index in the area of the burn is 500 or greater; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(4)(b): the United States National Weather Service clearing index in the area of the burn is less than 500, and to maximize the opportunities for prescribed burning or pile burning the director approves a prescribed burning or pile burning after the land manager:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(4)(b)(i): provides a demonstration that includes an assessment of the impact to local receptors;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(4)(b)(ii): implements measures to notify residents; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(4)(b)(iii): minimizes residents exposure to smoke.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(5): The director shall approve a prescribed burning or pile burning for resource management purposes in areas not defined as wildland and the prescribed burning or pile burning may be conducted under the following conditions:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(5)(a): the United States National Weather Service clearing index in the area of the burn is 500 or greater; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(5)(b): the United States National Weather Service clearing index in the area of the burn is less than 500, and to maximize the opportunities for prescribed burning or pile burning the director approves a prescribed burning or pile burning after the land manager demonstrates that the planned prescribed burning or pile burning will:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(5)(b)(i): not cause an exceedance of a national ambient air quality standard;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(5)(b)(ii): minimize the long range transport of smoke; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(5)(b)(iii): protect visibility in mandatory federal class 1 areas.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-2a-105(6): The division shall make the necessary filings with the United States Environmental Protection Agency if a prescribed burning or pile burning approved by the director results in an exceptional event.
