Utah Code Annotated - Title 19 - Chapter 5 - Water Quality Act
**************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-101 Short title.
-------------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Water Quality Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(1): "Agriculture discharge":
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(1)(a): means the release of agriculture water from the property of a farm, ranch, or feed lot that:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(1)(a)(i): pollutes a surface body of water, including a stream, lake, pond, marshland, watercourse, waterway, river, ditch, and other water conveyance system of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(1)(a)(ii): pollutes the ground water of the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(1)(a)(iii): constitutes a significant nuisance on urban land; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(1)(b): does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(1)(b)(i): runoff from a farm, ranch, or feed lot or return flows from irrigated fields onto land that is not part of a body of water; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(1)(b)(ii): a release into a normally dry water conveyance, unless the release reaches the water of a lake, pond, stream, marshland, river, or other active body of a water.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(2): "Agriculture water" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(2)(a): water used by a farmer, rancher, or feed lot for the production of food, fiber, or fuel;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(2)(b): return flows from irrigated agriculture; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(2)(c): agricultural storm water runoff.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(3): 19-1-106 "Board" means the Water Quality Board created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(4): 4-18-104 "Commission" means the Conservation Commission, created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(5): "Contaminant" means a physical, chemical, biological, or radiological substance or matter in water.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(6): "Director" means the director of the Division of Water Quality or, for purposes of groundwater quality at a facility licensed by and under the jurisdiction of the Division of  Waste Management and Radiation Control, the director of the Division of Waste Management and Radiation Control.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(7): "Discharge" means the addition of a pollutant to waters of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(8): "Discharge permit" means a permit issued to a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(8)(a): discharges or whose activities would probably result in a discharge of pollutants into the waters of the state; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(8)(b): generates or manages sewage sludge.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(9): "Disposal system" means a system for disposing of wastes and includes sewerage systems and treatment works.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(10): 19-1-105(1)(e) "Division" means the Division of Water Quality, created in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(11): "Effluent limitations" means restrictions, requirements, or prohibitions, including schedules of compliance established under this chapter, that apply to discharges.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(12): "Point source":
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(12)(a): means discernible, confined, and discrete conveyance, including a pipe, ditch, channel, tunnel, conduit, well, discrete fissure, container, rolling stock, concentrated animal feeding operation, or vessel or other floating craft, from which pollutants are or may be discharged; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(12)(b): does not include return flows from irrigated agriculture.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(13): "Pollution" means a man-made or man-induced alteration of the chemical, physical, biological, or radiological integrity of waters of the state, unless the alteration is necessary for the public health and safety.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(14): "Publicly owned treatment works" means a facility for the treatment of pollutants owned by the state, its political subdivisions, or other public entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(15): "Schedule of compliance" means a schedule of remedial measures, including an enforceable sequence of actions or operations leading to compliance with this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(16): "Sewage sludge" means solid, semisolid, or liquid residue removed during the treatment of municipal wastewater or domestic sewage.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(17): "Sewerage system" means pipelines or conduits, pumping stations, and other constructions, devices, appurtenances, and facilities used for collecting or conducting wastes to a point of ultimate disposal.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(18): "Total maximum daily load" means a calculation of the maximum amount of a pollutant that a body of water can receive and still meet water quality standards.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(19): "Treatment works" means a plant, disposal field, lagoon, dam, pumping station, incinerator, or other works used for the purpose of treating, stabilizing, or holding wastes.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(20): "Underground injection" means the subsurface emplacement of fluids by well injection.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(21): "Underground wastewater disposal system" means a system for underground disposal of domestic wastewater discharges as defined by the board and the executive director.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(22): "Waste" or "pollutant" means dredged spoil, solid waste, incinerator residue, sewage, garbage, sewage sludge, munitions, chemical wastes, biological materials, radioactive materials, heat, wrecked or discarded equipment, rock, sand, cellar dirt, and industrial, municipal, and agricultural waste discharged into water.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(23): "Waters of the state":
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(23)(a): means streams, lakes, ponds, marshes, watercourses, waterways, wells, springs, irrigation systems, drainage systems, and all other bodies or accumulations of water, surface and underground, natural or artificial, public or private, that are contained within, flow through, or border upon this state or any portion of the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-102(23)(b): does not include bodies of water confined to and retained within the limits of private property, and that do not develop into or constitute a nuisance, a public health hazard, or a menace to fish or wildlife.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103 Water Quality Board -- Members of board -- Appointment -- Terms -- Organization -- Meetings -- Per diem and expenses.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(1): Title 63G, Chapter 24, Part 2, Vacancies The board consists of the following nine members:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(1)(a): the following non-voting member, except that the member may vote to break a tie vote between the voting members:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(1)(a)(i): the executive director; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(1)(a)(ii): an employee of the department designated by the executive director; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(1)(b): Title 63G, Chapter 24, Part 2, Vacancies the following eight voting members, who shall be appointed by the governor with the advice and consent of the Senate in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(1)(b)(i): one representative who:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(1)(b)(i)(A): is an expert and has relevant training and experience in water quality matters;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(1)(b)(i)(B): is a Utah-licensed physician, a Utah-licensed professional engineer, or a scientist with relevant training and experience; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(1)(b)(i)(C): represents local and special service districts in the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(1)(b)(ii): two government representatives who do not represent the federal government;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(1)(b)(iii): one representative from the mineral industry;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(1)(b)(iv): one representative from the manufacturing industry;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(1)(b)(v): one representative who represents agricultural and livestock interests;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(1)(b)(vi): one representative from the public who represents:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(1)(b)(vi)(A): an environmental nongovernmental organization; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(1)(b)(vi)(B): a nongovernmental organization that represents community interests and does not represent industry interests; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(1)(b)(vii): one representative from the public who is trained and experienced in public health.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(2): 19-1-201(1)(d)(i)(A); 19-1-201(1)(d)(i)(B); Title 63G, Chapter 24, Part 3, Conflicts of Interest A member of the board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(2)(a): be knowledgeable about water quality matters, as evidenced by a professional degree, a professional accreditation, or documented experience;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(2)(b): be a resident of Utah;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(2)(c): 19-1-201(1)(d)(i)(A) attend board meetings in accordance with the attendance rules made by the department under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(2)(d): 19-1-201(1)(d)(i)(B); Title 63G, Chapter 24, Part 3, Conflicts of Interest comply with all applicable statutes, rules, and policies, including the conflict of interest rules made by the department under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(3): No more than five of the appointed members may be from the same political party.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(4): When a vacancy occurs in the membership for any reason, the replacement shall be appointed for the unexpired term with the advice and consent of the Senate.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(5): (5)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(5)(a): A member shall be appointed for a term of four years and is eligible for reappointment.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(5)(b): (5)(a) Notwithstanding the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(6): A member shall hold office until the expiration of the member's term and until the member's successor is appointed, not to exceed 90 days after the formal expiration of the term.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(7): The board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(7)(a): organize and annually select one of its members as chair and one of its members as vice chair;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(7)(b): hold at least four regular meetings each calendar year; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(7)(c): keep minutes of its proceedings which are open to the public for inspection.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(8): The chair may call a special meeting upon the request of three or more members of the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(9): Each member of the board and the director shall be notified of the time and place of each meeting.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(10): Five members of the board constitute a quorum for the transaction of business, and the action of a majority of members present is the action of the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-103(11): 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107; 63A-3-106; 63A-3-107 A member may not receive compensation or benefits for the member's service, but may receive per diem and travel expenses in accordance with:

Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3 Independent peer review of a proposal.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(1)(a): "Challenging party" means a person who has or is seeking a permit in accordance with this chapter and chooses to use the independent peer review process described in this section to challenge a proposal.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(1)(b): "Independent peer review" is a review conducted:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(1)(b)(i): in accordance with this section;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(1)(b)(ii): by experts having technical expertise in the proposal being reviewed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(1)(b)(iii): by individuals who are not:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(1)(b)(iii)(A): currently conducting research funded by the division or the challenging party;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(1)(b)(iii)(B): employed by an entity that is regulated under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(1)(b)(iii)(C): a spouse or family member of someone who is employed by the division or the challenging party; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(1)(b)(iii)(D): an active, participatory member of a non-profit organization that advocates positions with the division or the Legislature.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(1)(c): "Proposal" means any science-based initiative proposed by the division on or after January 1, 2016, that would financially impact a challenging party and that would:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(1)(c)(i): change water quality standards;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(1)(c)(ii): develop or modify total maximum daily load requirements;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(1)(c)(iii): modify wasteloads or other regulatory requirements for permits; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(1)(c)(iv): change rules or other regulatory guidance.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(1)(d): "Study" means a written analysis conducted by or otherwise relied upon by the division in support of a proposal.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(1)(e): "Technology based nutrient effluent limits" are maximum nutrient limitations based on the availability of technology to achieve the limitations, rather than on a water quality standard or a total maximum daily load standard.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(2): The director shall initiate an independent peer review when the following conditions are met:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(2)(a): a challenging party challenges in writing a study or the technical or scientific data upon which a proposal is based and requests an independent peer review;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(2)(b): if the independent peer review is related to examining a technology based nutrient effluent limit, the challenging party provides written notice to the division requesting an independent peer review before the technology based nutrient effluent limit is adopted into a permit issued by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(2)(c): if the independent peer review is not related to examining a technology based nutrient effluent limit, the challenging party provides written notice to the division requesting an independent peer review related to a proposal before the proposal has been adopted by the division or the board;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(2)(d): the challenging party agrees to provide the funding to pay for the independent peer review; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(2)(e): the challenging party would be substantially impacted by the adoption of the proposal.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(3): (5) The director shall ensure that the independent peer review is completed within one year from the date the peer review panel described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(4)(a): If there is more than one challenging party challenging a study or the technical or scientific data upon which a proposal is based, the challenges will be consolidated into one independent peer review.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(4)(b): If challenges are consolidated into one independent peer review, the challenging parties will be responsible for allocating the costs of the independent peer review among the challenging parties.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(5): (4); (5)(c)(i); (ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(5)(a): When an independent peer review is conducted, there shall be appointed to a peer review panel a minimum of three independent experts who are mutually agreeable to both the division and the challenging party.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(5)(b): Any additional independent experts appointed to the panel shall be mutually agreeable to both the division and the challenging party.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(5)(c): (4); (5)(c)(i); (ii) If an independent peer review panel has not been appointed within 60 days of the day on which the director receives a written request for an independent peer review, a three-person panel shall be selected as follows:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(5)(c)(i): one independent expert selected by the division;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(5)(c)(ii): (4) one independent expert selected by the challenging party or, if more than one challenge has been consolidated as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(5)(c)(iii): (5)(c)(i); (ii) one independent expert mutually agreeable to the independent experts described in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(6)(a): An independent peer review panel shall conduct its review in general accordance with the guidance contained in the United States Environmental Protection Agency's Peer Review Handbook.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(6)(b): As part of an independent peer review, the independent peer review panel shall allow for written public comment on the proposal being reviewed prior to issuing a written report.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(7): An independent peer review panel shall prepare a final written report that:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(7)(a): includes the findings of each member of the panel;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(7)(b): is supported by the majority of the panel;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(7)(c): includes an analysis of the panel's confidence, certainty, and major data gaps, if any, related to the scientific basis behind the proposal; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(7)(d): includes one of the following findings:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(7)(d)(i): the proposal is scientifically defensible;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(7)(d)(ii): the proposal is not scientifically defensible; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(7)(d)(iii): the proposal is scientifically defensible with conditions developed by the panel.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(8): (7) In addition to the requirements described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(8)(a): the technology based nutrient effluent limit is scientifically necessary to protect the designated beneficial uses of the specified downstream water body or the series of hydrologically connected water bodies; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(8)(b): the technology based nutrient effluent limit is not scientifically necessary to protect the designated beneficial uses of the specified downstream water body or the series of hydrologically connected water bodies.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(9): The findings and any conditions of an independent peer review panel shall be incorporated into a proposal as needed to ensure the scientific accuracy of the proposal.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(10): A proposal reviewed by an independent peer review panel that is found scientifically defensible or scientifically defensible with conditions may be forwarded to the board or to the director for further consideration and action as applicable.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.3(11): If technology based nutrient effluent limits in a proposal are found by an independent peer review to not be scientifically necessary to protect a specified downstream water body or series of hydrologically connected water bodies, the challenging party shall be granted a variance by the division exempting compliance with the technology based effluent limitation.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.5 Agriculture water.
---------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.5(1)(a): The board shall draft any rules relating to agriculture water in cooperation with the commission.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.5(2): A program or rule adopted by the board for agriculture production or irrigation water shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.5(2)(a): be consistent with the federal Clean Water Act; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-105.5(2)(b): if possible, be developed in a voluntary cooperative program with the agriculture producer associations and the commission.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-106(2)(l): Title 73, Chapter 3c, Wastewater Reuse Act; Title 73, Chapter 3c, Wastewater Reuse Act

Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-106(3)(c): encourage, participate in, or conduct studies, investigations, research, and demonstrations relating to water pollution and causes of water pollution as necessary for the discharge of duties assigned under this chapter, including the establishment of inventories of pollution sources;

Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-107 Discharge of pollutants unlawful -- Discharge permit required.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-107(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-107(1)(a): Except as provided in this chapter or rules made under it, it is unlawful for any person to discharge a pollutant into waters of the state or to cause pollution which constitutes a menace to public health and welfare, or is harmful to wildlife, fish, or aquatic life, or impairs domestic, agricultural, industrial, recreational, or other beneficial uses of water, or to place or cause to be placed any waste in a location where there is probable cause to believe it will cause pollution.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-107(1)(b): For purposes of injunctive relief, any violation of this subsection is a public nuisance.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-107(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-107(2)(a): A person may not generate, store, treat, process, use, transport, dispose, or otherwise manage sewage sludge, except in compliance with this chapter and rules made under it.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-107(2)(b): For purposes of injunctive relief, any violation of this subsection is a public nuisance.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-107(3): It is unlawful for any person, without first securing a permit from the director, to:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-107(3)(a): make any discharge or manage sewage sludge not authorized under an existing valid discharge permit; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-107(3)(b): construct, install, modify, or operate any treatment works or part of any treatment works or any extension or addition to any treatment works, or construct, install, or operate any establishment or extension or modification of or addition to any treatment works, the operation of which would probably result in a discharge.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-108 Discharge permits -- Requirements and procedure for issuance.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-108(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The board may make rules, in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-108(2): A discharge permit shall have a fixed term not exceeding five years.  Upon expiration of a discharge permit, a new permit, the permit may be renewed or may be issued by the director as authorized by the board after notice and an opportunity for public hearing and upon condition that the applicant meets or will meet the applicable requirements of this chapter, including the conditions of a permit granted by the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-108(3): The board may require notice to the director of the introduction of pollutants into publicly-owned treatment works and identification to the director of the character and volume of any pollutant of any significant source subject to pretreatment standards under  Subsection 307(b) of the federal Clean Water Act.  The director shall provide in the permit for compliance with pretreatment standards.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-108(4): The director may impose as conditions in permits for the discharge of pollutants from publicly-owned treatment works appropriate measures to establish and ensure compliance by industrial users with any system of user charges required under this chapter or the rules adopted under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-108(5): The director may apply and enforce against industrial users of publicly-owned treatment works, toxic effluent standards and pretreatment standards for the introduction into the treatment works of pollutants that interfere with, pass through, or otherwise are incompatible with the treatment works.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-108(6): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act The board shall make rules, in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-108(7): The director shall administer storm water permits to be consistent with rules established by the board.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-108.5 Storm water permits.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-108.5(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-108.5(1)(a): "Applicant" means a person who is conducting or proposing to conduct a use of land and who a permittee requires or allows to use low impact development.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-108.5(1)(b): "Independent review" is a review conducted:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-108.5(1)(b)(i): in accordance with this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-108.5(1)(b)(ii): by an engineer, or engineering firm, designated by the division as having technical expertise in the area of storm water calculations.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-108.5(1)(c): "Low impact development" means structural or natural engineered systems located close to the source of storm water that use or mimic natural processes to encourage infiltration, evapotranspiration, or reuse of the storm water.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-108.5(1)(d): "Permittee" means a municipality, metro township, or county with a storm water permit under the Utah Pollutant Discharge Elimination System.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-108.5(1)(e): "Storm water" means storm water runoff, snow melt runoff, and surface runoff and drainage.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-108.5(1)(f): "Storm water permit" means a permit issued to a permittee by the division for the permittee's municipal separate storm sewer system.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-108.5(1)(g): "Utah Pollutant Discharge Elimination System" means the state-wide program for issuing, modifying, revoking and reissuing, terminating, monitoring and enforcing permits under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-108.5(2): A permittee shall reduce any requirement for an applicant to manage or control storm water runoff rates or storm water runoff volumes for flood control purposes to account for the reduction in storm water associated with approved low impact development practices.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-108.5(3): (4) The director shall create and maintain a list of engineers, including engineering firms, capable of providing independent review of low impact development designs and storm water calculations for use by an applicant and a permittee pursuant to an appeal described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-108.5(4): (4)(a); (3); (4)(b)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-108.5(4)(a): An applicant who appeals a permittee's determination regarding post-construction retention requirements under the permittee's storm water permit may request the permittee to refer the appeal to independent review for purposes of determining the technical aspects of the appeal, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-108.5(4)(a)(i): the required size of any low impact development system;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-108.5(4)(a)(ii): the calculations of reductions in storm water runoff rates or storm water runoff volumes for flood control due to the use of low impact development; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-108.5(4)(a)(iii): the feasibility of constructing low impact development practices required by the permittee.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-108.5(4)(b): (4)(a); (3); (4)(b)(i) If an applicant makes a request under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-110 Designation by governor of areas with quality control problems -- Classification of waters -- Adoption of standards of quality.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-110(1): The governor may identify and designate by boundary, or make a determination not to designate, areas within the state which, as a result of urban-industrial concentration or other factors, have substantial water quality control problems, and designate planning agencies and waste treatment management agencies for these areas.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-110(2): The board may group the waters of the state into classes according to their present most reasonable uses, and after public hearing, upgrade and reclassify from time to time the waters of the state to the extent that it is practical and in the public interest.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-110(3): 45-1-101
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-110(3)(a): The board may establish standards of quality for each classification consistent with most reasonable present and future uses of  the waters, and the standards may be modified or changed from time to time.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-110(3)(b): Prior to classifying waters, setting quality standards or modifying or repealing them the board shall conduct public hearings for the consideration, adoption, or amendment of the classifications of waters and standards of purity and quality.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-110(3)(c): The notice shall specify the waters concerning which a classification is sought to be made for which standards are sought to be adopted and the time, date, and place of the hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-110(3)(d): 45-1-101 The notice shall be:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-110(3)(d)(i): 45-1-101 published:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-110(3)(d)(i)(A): at least twice in a newspaper of general circulation in the area affected; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-110(3)(d)(i)(B): 45-1-101 as required in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-110(3)(d)(ii): mailed at least 30 days before the public hearing to the chief executive of each political subdivision of the area affected and to other persons the board has reason to believe will be affected by the classification and the setting of standards.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-110(4): 45-1-101
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-110(4)(a): 45-1-101 The adoption of standards of quality for the waters of the state and classification of  the waters or any modification or change in classification shall be effectuated by an order of the board which shall be published:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-110(4)(a)(i): in a newspaper of general circulation in the area affected; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-110(4)(a)(ii): 45-1-101 as required in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-110(4)(b): In classifying waters and setting standards of water quality, adopting rules, or making any modification or change in classification or standards, the board shall allow and announce a reasonable time, not exceeding statutory deadlines contained in the federal Clean Water Act, for persons discharging wastes into the waters of the state to comply with the classification or standards and may, after public hearing if requested by the permittee, set and revise schedules of compliance and include these schedules within the terms and conditions of permits for the discharge of pollutants.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-110(5): Any discharge in accord with classification or standards authorized by a permit is not pollution for the purpose of this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-114 Spills or discharges of oil or other substance -- Notice to director.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any person who spills or discharges any oil or other substance which may cause the pollution of the waters of the state shall immediately notify the director of the spill or discharge, any containment procedures undertaken, and a proposed procedure for cleanup and disposal, in accordance with rules of the board.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-116 Limitation on effluent limitation standards for BOD, Total Suspended Solids, Bacteria, and pH for domestic or municipal sewage.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Unless required to meet instream water quality standards or federal requirements established under the federal Clean Water Act, the board may not establish, under SectionUtah Code Annotated § 19-5-116(1): Biochemical Oxygen Demand (BOD): The arithmetic mean of BOD values determined on effluent samples collected during any 30-day period may not exceed 25 mg/l, nor shall the arithmetic mean exceed 35 mg/l during any seven-day period.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-116(2): Total Suspended Solids (SS): The arithmetic mean of SS values determined on effluent samples collected during any 30-day period may not exceed 25 mg/l, nor shall the arithmetic mean exceed 35 mg/l during any seven-day period.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-116(3): Bacteria:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-116(3)(a): The geometric mean of total coliforms and fecal coliform bacteria in effluent samples collected during any 30-day period may not exceed either 2000/100 ml for total coliforms or 200/100 ml for fecal coliforms. The geometric mean during any seven-day period may not exceed 2500/100 ml for total coliforms or 250/100 for fecal coliforms.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-116(3)(b): The geometric mean of E. coli bacteria in effluent samples collected during any 30-day period shall not exceed 126 per 100 mL nor shall the geometric mean exceed 158 per 100 mL respectively during any 7-day period.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-116(4): pH: The pH level shall be maintained at a level not less than 6.5 or greater than 9.0.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-117 Purpose and construction of chapter.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-117(1): It is the purpose of this chapter to provide:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-117(1)(a): additional and cumulative remedies to prevent, abate, and control the pollution of the waters of the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-117(1)(b): sufficient authority to allow the state to meet federal requirements for the state's assumption of primacy under the federal Water Pollution Control Act, as amended by the Water Quality Act of 1987, 33 U.S.C. Section 1251 et seq.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-117(2): Nothing  in this chapter:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-117(2)(a): abridges or alters rights of action or remedies in equity or under common or statutory law, criminal or civil; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-117(2)(b): estops the state or any municipality or person, as riparian owners or otherwise, in the exercise of their rights in equity or under common or statutory law to suppress nuisances or to abate pollution.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-118 Chapter deemed auxiliary and supplementary to other laws.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This chapter does not  repeal any laws relating to the pollution of waters or any conservation laws, but is auxiliary and supplementary to them except to the extent that the  laws are in direct conflict with this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-119 State permits not required where federal government has primary responsibility.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If for any reason, including cessation of federal funding, the federal government has the primary responsibility for the discharge permit or underground injection permit programs in this state, discharge or underground injection permits established by this chapter are not required.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-120 Sewage permit program fee.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-120(1): 63J-1-504; 19-5-108 The department may assess a fee established under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-120(2): In establishing the fee for each  sludge disposal permit holder, the department shall take into account the proportionate size of the population served by the permit holder.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-120(3): All proceeds from the fee shall be applied to the administering of the sewage permit program required by this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-124 Phosphorus limit for household dishwashing detergent.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-5-203 Participation in survey.
-------------------------------------------------------
A wastewater service provider shall participate in the United States Environmental Protection Agency's 2022 Clean Water Needs Survey and deliver the required data to the survey data portal by no later than December 31, 2022.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-101 Short title.
-------------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Solid and Hazardous Waste Act."

As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-102(1): 19-1-106 "Board" means the Waste Management and Radiation Control Board created in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-102(9)(a): "Hazardous waste" means a solid waste or combination of solid wastes other than household waste that, because of its quantity, concentration, or physical, chemical, or infectious characteristics may cause or significantly contribute to an increase in mortality or an increase in serious irreversible or incapacitating reversible illness or may pose a substantial present or potential hazard to human health or the environment when improperly treated, stored, transported, disposed of, or otherwise managed.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-102(9)(b): "Hazardous waste" does not include those wastes listed in 40 C.F.R. Sec. 261.4(b).

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-102(10)(n): veterinary clinic; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-102(10)(o): mortuary.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-102(12): "Infectious waste" means a solid waste that contains or may reasonably be expected to contain pathogens of sufficient virulence and quantity that exposure to the waste by a susceptible host could result in an infectious disease.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-102(22): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-102(22)(a): "Transfer" means the collection of nonhazardous solid waste from a permanent, fixed, supplemental collection facility for movement to a vehicle for movement to an offsite nonhazardous solid waste storage or disposal facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-102(22)(b): "Transfer" does not mean:

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-102(24): "Treatment" means a method, technique, or process designed to change the physical, chemical, or biological character or composition of any solid or hazardous waste so as to neutralize the waste or render the waste nonhazardous, safer for transport, amenable for recovery, amenable to storage, or reduced in volume.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-102(25): "Underground storage tank" means a tank that is regulated under Subtitle I of the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, 42 U.S.C. Sec. 6991 et seq.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-105 Rules of board.
----------------------------------------------
andUtah Code Annotated § 19-6-105(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; 19-6-108; Title 19, Chapter 6, Part 4, Underground Storage Tank Act; 19-6-106 The board may make rules in accordance with

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-107 Director -- Appointment -- Powers.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-107(1): The executive director shall appoint the director.  The director shall serve under the administrative direction of the executive director.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-107(2): 19-6-109 The director shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-107(2)(a): issue an order necessary to enforce this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-107(2)(b): enforce an order by appropriate administrative and judicial proceedings;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-107(2)(c): institute judicial proceedings to secure compliance with this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-107(2)(d): 19-6-109 carry out inspections pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-107(2)(e): require submittal of specifications or other information relating to hazardous waste plans for review, and approve, disapprove, revoke, or review the plans;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-107(2)(f): develop programs for solid waste and hazardous waste management and control within the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-107(2)(g): advise, consult, and cooperate with another agency of the state, the federal government, another state, an interstate agency, an affected group, an affected political subdivision, an affected industry, or other affected person in furtherance of the purposes of this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-107(2)(h): subject to the provisions of this part, enforce rules made or revised by the board through the issuance of orders;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-107(2)(i): review plans, specifications or other data relative to solid waste and hazardous waste control systems or any part of the systems as provided in this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-107(2)(j): under the direction of the executive director, represent the state in matters pertaining to interstate solid waste and hazardous waste management and control including, under the direction of the board, entering into interstate compacts and other similar agreements; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-107(2)(k): as authorized by the board and subject to the provisions of this part, act as executive secretary of the board under the direction of the chair of the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-107(3): 19-6-104(1)(e) The director may:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-107(3)(a): 19-6-104(1)(e) subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-107(3)(b): employ full-time employees necessary to carry out this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-107(3)(c): authorize any employee or representative of the department to conduct inspections as permitted in this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-107(3)(d): encourage, participate in, or conduct studies, investigations, research, and demonstrations relating to solid waste and hazardous waste management and control necessary for the discharge of duties assigned under this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-107(3)(e): collect and disseminate information relating to solid waste and hazardous waste management control; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-107(3)(f): cooperate with any person in studies and research regarding solid waste and hazardous waste management and control.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(3)(g)(i): The director shall suspend acceptance of further applications for a commercial nonhazardous solid or hazardous waste facility upon a finding that the director cannot adequately oversee existing and additional facilities for permit compliance, monitoring, and enforcement.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(4): The director shall review a proposed nonhazardous solid or hazardous waste operation plan to determine whether that plan complies with this part and the applicable rules of the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(5)(a): If the facility is a class I or class II facility, the director shall approve or disapprove that plan within 270 days from the date the plan is submitted.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(5)(b): Within 60 days after receipt of the plans, specifications, or other information required by this section for a class I or II facility, the director shall determine whether the plan is complete and contains the information necessary to process the plan for approval.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(5)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(5)(c)(i): If the plan for a class I or II facility is determined to be complete, the director shall issue a notice of completeness.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(5)(c)(ii): If the plan is determined by the director to be incomplete, the director shall issue a notice of deficiency, listing the additional information to be provided by the owner or operator to complete the plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(5)(d): The director shall review information submitted in response to a notice of deficiency within 30 days after receipt.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(5)(e): The following time periods may not be included in the 270 day plan review period for a class I or II facility:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(5)(e)(i): time awaiting response from the owner or operator to requests for information issued by the director;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(5)(e)(ii): time required for public participation and hearings for issuance of plan approvals; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(5)(e)(iii): time for review of the permit by other federal or state government agencies.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(6)(a): If the facility is a class III or class IV facility, the director shall approve or disapprove that plan within 365 days from the date the plan is submitted.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(6)(b): The following time periods may not be included in the 365 day review period:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(6)(b)(i): time awaiting response from the owner or operator to requests for information issued by the director;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(6)(b)(ii): time required for public participation and hearings for issuance of plan approvals; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(6)(b)(iii): time for review of the permit by other federal or state government agencies.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(7): If, within 365 days after receipt of a modification request or closure plan for any facility, the director determines that the proposed plan or request, or any part of the proposed plan or request, will not comply with applicable rules, the director shall issue an order prohibiting any action under the proposed plan or request for modification or closure in whole or in part.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(8): A person who owns or operates a facility or site required to have an approved hazardous waste operation plan under this section and who has pending a permit application before the United States Environmental Protection Agency shall be treated as having an approved plan until final administrative disposition of the permit application is made under this section, unless the director determines that final administrative disposition of the application has not been made because of the failure of the owner or operator to furnish any information requested, or the facility's interim status has terminated under Section 3005 (e) of the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, 42 U.S.C. Sec. 6925 (e).
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(9): The director may not approve a proposed nonhazardous solid or hazardous waste operation plan unless the plan contains the information that the board requires, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(9)(a): estimates of the composition, quantities, and concentrations of any hazardous waste identified under this part and the proposed treatment, storage, or disposal of the hazardous waste;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(9)(b): evidence that the transfer, treatment, or disposal of nonhazardous solid waste or treatment, storage, or disposal of hazardous waste will not be done in a manner that may cause or significantly contribute to an increase in mortality, an increase in serious irreversible or incapacitating reversible illness, or pose a substantial present or potential hazard to human health or the environment;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(9)(c): consistent with the degree and duration of risks associated with the transfer, treatment, or disposal of nonhazardous solid waste or treatment, storage, or disposal of specified hazardous waste, evidence of financial responsibility in whatever form and amount that the director determines is necessary to ensure continuity of operation and that upon abandonment, cessation, or interruption of the operation of the facility or site, the reasonable measures consistent with the available knowledge will be taken to ensure that the waste subsequent to being treated, stored, or disposed of at the site or facility will not present a hazard to the public or the environment;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(9)(d): evidence that the personnel employed at the facility or site have education and training for the safe and adequate handling of nonhazardous solid or hazardous waste;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(9)(e): plans, specifications, and other information that the director considers relevant to determine whether the proposed nonhazardous solid or hazardous waste operation plan will comply with this part and the rules of the board;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(9)(f): compliance schedules, when applicable, including schedules for corrective action or other response measures for releases from a solid waste management unit at the facility, regardless of the time the waste was placed in the unit;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(9)(g): for a proposed operation plan submitted on or after July 1, 2013, for a new solid or hazardous waste facility other than a water treatment facility that treats, stores, or disposes site-generated solid or hazardous waste onsite, a traffic impact study that:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(9)(g)(i): takes into consideration the safety, operation, and condition of roadways serving the proposed facility; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(9)(g)(ii): is reviewed and approved by the Department of Transportation or a local highway authority, whichever has jurisdiction over each road serving the proposed facility, with the cost of the review paid by the person who submits the proposed operation plan; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(9)(h): for a proposed operation plan submitted on or after July 1, 2013, for a new nonhazardous solid waste facility owned or operated by a local government, financial information that discloses the costs of establishing and operating the facility, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(9)(h)(i): land acquisition and leasing;

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(10): (9) The director may not approve a commercial nonhazardous solid or hazardous waste operation plan that meets the requirements of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(10)(a): evidence that the proposed commercial facility has a proven market of nonhazardous solid or hazardous waste, including:

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108(12): Approval of a nonhazardous solid or hazardous waste operation plan may be revoked, in whole or in part, if the person to whom approval of the plan has been given fails to comply with that plan.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108.3 Director to issue written assurances, make determinations, and partition operation plans -- Board to make rules.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108.3(1): Based upon risk to human health or the environment from potential exposure to hazardous waste, the director may:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108.3(1)(a): even if corrective action is incomplete, issue an enforceable written assurance to a person acquiring an interest in real property covered by an operation plan that the person to whom the assurance is issued:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108.3(1)(a)(i): is not a permittee under the operation plan; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108.3(1)(a)(ii): will not be subject to an enforcement action under this part for contamination that exists or for violations under this part that occurred before the person acquired the interest in the real property covered by the operation plan;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108.3(1)(b): determine that corrective action to the real property covered by the operation plan is:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108.3(1)(b)(i): complete;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108.3(1)(b)(ii): incomplete;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108.3(1)(b)(iii): unnecessary with an environmental covenant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108.3(1)(b)(iv): unnecessary without an environmental covenant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108.3(1)(c): partition from an operation plan a portion of real property subject to the operation plan after determining that corrective action for that portion of real property is:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108.3(1)(c)(i): complete;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108.3(1)(c)(ii): unnecessary with an environmental covenant; or

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-108.5 Management of hazardous waste generated outside Utah.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
On and after July 1, 2017, waste entering Utah for disposal or treatment, excluding incineration, that is classified by Utah as nonhazardous solid waste shall be treated or disposed of as nonhazardous solid waste, regardless of how it is classified by the state of origin.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-109 Inspections authorized -- Fines for a self-inspected facility.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-109(1): A duly authorized officer, employee, or representative of the director may, at any reasonable time and upon presentation of appropriate credentials, enter upon and inspect any property, premise, or place on or at which solid or hazardous wastes are generated, transported, stored, treated, or disposed of, and have access to and the right to copy any records relating to the wastes, for the purpose of ascertaining compliance with this part and the rules of the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-109(2): An inspector may also inspect any waste and obtain waste samples, including samples from any vehicle in which wastes are being transported or samples of any containers or labels.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-109(3): Any person obtaining samples shall give to the owner, operator, or agent a receipt describing the sample obtained and, if requested, a portion of each sample of waste equal in volume or weight to the portion retained.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-109(4): If any analysis is made of those samples, a copy of the results of that analysis shall be furnished promptly to the owner, operator, or agent in charge.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-111 Variances -- Requirements for application -- Procedure.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-111(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-111(1)(a): If the board determines that the application of, or compliance with, any requirements of this part would cause undue or unreasonable hardship to any person, it may issue a variance from any of those requirements.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-111(1)(b): No variance may be granted except upon application for it.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-111(1)(c): Immediately upon receipt of an application for a variance, the board shall give public notice of the application and provide an opportunity for a public hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-111(1)(d): A variance granted for more than one year shall contain a timetable for coming into compliance with this part and shall be conditioned on adherence to that timetable.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-111(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-111(2)(a): Any variance granted under this section may be renewed on terms and conditions and for periods which would be appropriate for the initial granting of a variance.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-111(2)(b): No renewal may be granted except on application for it.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-111(2)(c): Immediately upon receipt of an application for renewal, the board shall give public notice of the application and provide an opportunity for a public hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-111(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-111(3)(a): The board may review any variance during the term for which it was granted.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-111(3)(b): The procedure for review is the same as that for an original application and the variance previously granted may be revoked upon a finding that the conditions and the terms upon which the variance was granted are not being met.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-111(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-111(4)(a): Any variance or renewal exists at the discretion of the board and is not  a right of the applicant or holder.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-111(4)(b): However, any person adversely affected by the granting, denying, or revoking of any variance or renewal by the board may obtain judicial review of the board's decision by filing a petition in district court within 30 days from the date of notification of the decision.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-111(4)(c): The decision of the board  may not be overturned upon review unless the court finds that the actions of the board were arbitrary or capricious.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-112 Notice of violations -- Order for correction -- Civil action to enforce.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-112(1): Whenever the director determines that any person is in violation of any applicable approved hazardous wastes operation plan or solid waste plan, the requirements of this part, or any of the board's rules, the director may cause written notice of that violation to be served upon the alleged violator.  The notice shall specify the provisions of the plan, this part or rule alleged to have been violated, and the facts alleged to constitute the violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-112(2): The director may:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-112(2)(a): issue an order requiring that necessary corrective action be taken within a reasonable time; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-112(2)(b): request the attorney general or the county attorney in the county in which the violation is taking place to bring a civil action for injunctive relief and enforcement of this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-113 Violations -- Penalties -- Reimbursement for expenses.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-113(1): As used in this section, "RCRA" means the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, 42 U.S.C. Section 6901, et seq.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-113(2): Any person who violates any order, plan, rule, or other requirement issued or adopted under this part is subject in a civil proceeding to a penalty of not more than $13,000 per day for each day of violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-113(3): On or after July 1, 1990, no person shall knowingly:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-113(3)(a): transport or cause to be transported any hazardous waste identified or listed under this part to a facility that does not have a hazardous waste operation plan or permit under this part or RCRA;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-113(3)(b): treat, store, or dispose of any hazardous waste identified or listed under this part:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-113(3)(b)(i): without having obtained a hazardous waste operation plan or permit as required by this part or RCRA;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-113(3)(b)(ii): in knowing violation of any material condition or requirement of a hazardous waste operation plan or permit; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-113(3)(b)(iii): in knowing violation of any material condition or requirement of any rules or regulations under this part or RCRA;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-113(3)(c): omit material information or make any false material statement or representation in any application, label, manifest, record, report, permit, operation plan, or other document filed, maintained, or used for purposes of compliance with this part or RCRA or any rules or regulations made under this part or RCRA; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-113(3)(d): transport or cause to be transported without a manifest any hazardous waste identified or listed under this part and required by rules or regulations made under this part or RCRA to be accompanied by a manifest.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-114 Service of notice, order, or other document.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
In accordance with procedural rules adopted by the department, service of any notice, order, or other document issued by, or under the authority of, the director may be made by forwarding a copy of that notice, order, or other document by registered mail, directed to the person's designated address.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-115 Imminent danger to health or environment -- Authority of executive director to initiate action to restrain.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Notwithstanding any other provision of this part, upon receipt of evidence that the handling, transportation, treatment, storage, or disposal of any solid or hazardous waste, or a release from an underground storage tank, is presenting an imminent and substantial danger to health or the environment, the executive director may bring suit on behalf of this state in the district court to immediately restrain any person contributing, or who has contributed, to that action to stop the handling, storage, treatment, transportation, or disposal or to take other action as appropriate.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-116 Application of part subject to state assumption of primary responsibility from federal government -- Authority of political subdivisions.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-116(1): The requirements of this part applicable to the generation, treatment, storage, or disposal of hazardous waste, and the rules adopted under this part, do not take effect until this state is qualified to assume, and does assume, primacy from the federal government for the control of hazardous wastes.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-116(2): This part does not alter the authority of political subdivisions of the state to control solid and hazardous wastes within their local jurisdictions so long as any local laws, ordinances, or rules are not inconsistent with this part or the rules of the board.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-117 Action against insurer or guarantor.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-117(1): 19-6-108 The state may assert a cause of action directly against an insurer or guarantor of an owner or operator if:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-117(1)(a): 19-6-108 a cause of action exists against an owner or operator of a treatment, storage, or disposal facility, based upon conduct for which the director requires evidence of financial responsibility under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-117(1)(b): jurisdiction over an owner or operator, who is likely to be solvent at the time of judgment, cannot be obtained in state or federal court.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-117(2): In that action, the insurer or guarantor may assert all rights and defenses available to the owner or operator, in addition to rights and defenses that would be available to the insurer or guarantor in an action brought against him by the owner or operator.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-121 Local zoning authority powers.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Nothing in this part prohibits any local zoning authority from adopting zoning criteria for commercial hazardous waste disposal facilities or sites that are more stringent than any requirements adopted by the department.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-122 Facilities to meet local zoning requirements.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Notwithstanding any provisions of this part, persons seeking to operate a commercial hazardous waste disposal facility or site shall meet all local zoning requirements before beginning operations.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-123 Kilns -- Siting.
-----------------------------------------------
A cement kiln or lightweight aggregate kiln may not accept hazardous waste for recycling or for use as fuel without meeting the siting criteria for commercial hazardous waste treatment, storage, and disposal facilities established under Section

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-124 Burial of nonhazardous solid waste by an individual.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-124(1): Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, an individual may bury nonhazardous solid waste on the individual's own property if:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-124(1)(a): the individual lives in an area where no public or duly licensed waste disposal service is available;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-124(1)(b): the individual owns the nonhazardous solid waste; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-124(1)(c): the nonhazardous solid waste is generated on the individual's private property.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-124(2): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act In accordance with
