Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-201 Short title.
-------------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Hazardous Waste Facility Siting Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-202 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-202(1): 19-1-106 "Board" means the Waste Management and Radiation Control Board created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-202(2): "Disposal" means the final disposition of hazardous wastes into or onto the lands, waters, and air of this state.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-202(3): 19-6-102 "Hazardous wastes" means hazardous waste as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-202(4): "Hazardous waste treatment, disposal, and storage facility" means a facility or site used or intended to be used for the treatment, storage, or disposal of hazardous waste materials, including physical, chemical, or thermal processing systems, incinerators, and secure landfills.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-202(5): "Site" means land used for the treatment, disposal, or storage of hazardous wastes.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-202(6): 19-6-204; 19-6-205 "Siting plan" means the state hazardous waste facilities siting plan adopted by the board pursuant to Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-202(7): "Storage" means the containment of hazardous wastes for a period of more than 90 days.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-202(8): "Treatment" means any method, technique, or process designed to change the physical, chemical, or biological character or composition of any hazardous waste to neutralize or render it nonhazardous, safer for transport, amenable to recovery or storage, convertible to another usable material, or reduced in volume and suitable for ultimate disposal.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-203 Other provisions relating to hazardous waste.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
This part may not be construed to supersede any other state or local law relating to hazardous waste, except as otherwise provided in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-204 Guidelines for facility siting -- Considerations in adopting.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-204(1): The board shall adopt and publish guidelines for the location of hazardous waste treatment, storage, and disposal facilities.  The guidelines shall ensure that facilities are sited so that the wastes located there will not constitute an unacceptable health hazard or impact the environment in an unacceptable manner.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-204(2): Proposed guidelines for siting shall take into account the following considerations:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-204(2)(a): the zoning classification of the site proposed and its proximity to present or projected land use dedicated to industrial development;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-204(2)(b): the existing land uses and the density of population in areas neighboring the proposed site;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-204(2)(c): the density of population in areas adjacent to probable hazardous waste delivery routes;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-204(2)(d): the risk and impact of accidents which might occur during the transportation of hazardous wastes to the site;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-204(2)(e): the determination of areas that are dedicated to an incompatible public use or are unsuitable for other reasons for the location of hazardous wastes;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-204(2)(f): the geology of the proposed site with special attention to the presence of fault zones and the risk of contamination to ground and surface waters through leaching and runoff;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-204(2)(g): the risk to life and property from fires or explosions that might occur if improper storage and disposal methods are used;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-204(2)(h): the economic and environmental impact of the proposed facility site location upon local governmental units adjacent to, or within which, the facility is proposed for location;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-204(2)(i): closure and postclosure monitoring and maintenance requirements; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-204(2)(j): other criteria required for the siting of hazardous wastes under state or federal law.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205 Siting plan -- Procedure for adoption -- Review -- Effect.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(1): (2); 19-6-204 After completion of the guidelines, the board shall prepare and publish a preliminary siting plan for the state.  The preliminary siting plan is not final until adopted by the board in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(2): 19-6-108; 19-6-204
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(2)(a): After completion of its guidelines, the board shall publish notice of intent to prepare a siting plan.  The notice shall invite all interested persons to nominate sites for inclusion in the siting plan.  It shall be published at least twice in not less than two newspapers with statewide circulation and shall also be sent to any person, business, or other organization that has notified the board of an interest or involvement in hazardous waste management activities.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(2)(b): Nominations for the location of hazardous waste sites shall be accepted by the board for a period of 120 days after the date of first publication of notice.  Nominations may include a description of the site or sites suggested or may simply suggest a general area.  In addition, any nomination may provide data and reasons in support of inclusion of the site nominated.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(2)(c): 19-6-108 The board, in cooperation with other state agencies and private sources, shall then prepare an inventory of:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(2)(c)(i): the hazardous wastes generated in the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(2)(c)(ii): those likely to be generated in the future;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(2)(c)(iii): those being generated in other states that are likely to be treated, disposed of, or stored in the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(2)(c)(iv): the sites within the state currently being used for hazardous waste and those suggested through the nomination process;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(2)(c)(v): 19-6-108 the treatment, storage, and disposal processes and management practices that are required to comply with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(2)(c)(vi): an estimate of the public and private costs for meeting the long-term demand for hazardous waste treatment, disposal, and storage facilities.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(2)(d): 19-6-204
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(2)(d)(i): 19-6-204 After the hazardous waste inventory and cost estimate are complete, the board, with the use of the guidelines developed in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(2)(d)(ii): The board may not exclude any area of the state from consideration in the selection of potential sites but, to the maximum extent possible, shall give preference to sites located in areas already dedicated through zoning or other land use regulations to industrial use or to areas located near industrial uses.  However, the board shall give consideration to excluding an area designated for disposal of uranium mill tailings or for disposal of nuclear wastes unless the proposed disposal site is approved by the affected county through its county executive and county legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(2)(e): The board shall also analyze and identify areas of the state where, due to the concentration of industrial waste generation processes or to favorable geology or hydrology, the construction and operation of hazardous waste treatment, disposal, and storage facilities appears to be technically, environmentally, and economically feasible.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(3): (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(3)(a): (2) The preliminary siting plan prepared pursuant to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(3)(b): Notice of the availability of the preliminary siting plan for examination shall be published at least twice in two newspapers, if available, with general circulation in the areas of the state that potentially will be affected by the plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(3)(c): The board shall also issue a statewide news release that informs persons where copies of the preliminary siting plan may be inspected or purchased at cost.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(3)(d): After release of the preliminary siting plan, the board shall hold not less than two public hearings in different areas of the state affected by the proposed siting plan to allow local officials and other interested persons to express their views and submit information relevant to the plan.  The hearings shall be conducted not less than 60 nor more than 90 days after release of the plan.  Within 30 days after completion of the hearings, the board shall prepare and make available for public inspection a summary of public comments.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(4)(a): The board, between 30 and 60 days after publication of the public comments, shall prepare a final siting plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(4)(b): The final siting plan shall be widely distributed to members of the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(4)(c): The board, at any time between 30 and 60 days after release of the final plan, on its own initiative or that of interested parties, shall hold not less than two public hearings in each area of the state affected by the final plan to allow local officials and other interested persons to express their views.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(4)(d): The board, within 30 days after the last hearing, shall vote to adopt, adopt with modification, or reject the final siting plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(5)(a): Any person adversely affected by the  board's decision may seek judicial review of the decision by filing a petition for review with the district court for Salt Lake County within 90 days after the board's decision.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(5)(b): Judicial review may be had, however, only on the grounds that the board violated the procedures set forth in this section, that it acted without or in excess of its powers, or that its actions were arbitrary or capricious and not based on substantial evidence.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(6): If the final siting plan is adopted, the  board shall cause it to be published.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(7): After publication of the final siting plan, the board shall engage in a continuous monitoring and review process to ensure that the long-range needs of hazardous waste producers likely to dispose of hazardous wastes in this state are met at a reasonable cost.  An annual review of the adequacy of the plan shall be conducted and published by the board.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(8)(a): If necessary, the board may amend the siting plan to provide additional sites or delete sites which are no longer suitable.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(8)(b): Before any plan amendment adding or deleting a site is adopted, the board, upon not less than 20 days' public notice, shall hold at least one public hearing in the area where the affected site is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(9): After adoption of the final plan, an applicant for approval of a plan to construct and operate a hazardous waste treatment, storage, and disposal facility who seeks protection under this part shall select a site contained on the final site plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-205(10): Nothing in this part, however, shall be construed to prohibit the construction and operation of an approved hazardous waste treatment, storage, and disposal facility at a site which is not included within the final site plan, but such a facility is not entitled to the protections afforded under this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-206 Exclusive remedy for devaluation of property caused by approved facility.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-206(1): Before construction of a hazardous waste management facility, but in no case later than nine months after approval of a plan for a hazardous waste treatment, storage, or disposal facility, any owner or user of property adversely affected by approval may bring an action in a district court of competent jurisdiction against the owner of the proposed facility. If the court determines that the planned construction and operation of the hazardous waste management facility will result in the devaluation of the plaintiff's property or will otherwise interfere with the plaintiff's rights in the property, it shall order the owner to compensate the plaintiff in an amount equal to the value of the plaintiff's loss.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-206(2): (1) The remedy provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-206(3): Nothing in this part prevents an owner or user of property aggrieved by the construction and operation of a facility from seeking damages that result from a subsequent modification of the design or operation of a facility but damages are limited to the incremental damage that results from the modification.  Any action for damages from a modification shall be brought within nine months after the plans for modification of the design or operation of the facility are approved.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-206(4): For the purpose of assessing damages, the value of the rights affected is fixed at the date the facility plan is approved and the actual value of the right at that date is the basis for the determination of the amount of damage suffered, and no improvements to the property subsequent to the date of approval of the plans shall be included in the assessment of damages. Similarly, for any subsequent modification of a facility, value is fixed at the date of approval of the amended facility plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-206(5): The owner or operator of a proposed facility may, at any time before an award of damages, abandon the construction or operation of the facility or any modification and cause the action to be dismissed.  As a condition of dismissal, however, the owner or operator shall compensate the plaintiff for any actual damage sustained as a result of construction or operation of the facility before abandonment together with court costs and a reasonable attorney's fee.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-206(6): Nothing in this part prevents a court from enjoining any activity at a hazardous waste facility that is outside of, or not in compliance with, the terms and conditions of an approved hazardous waste operations plan.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-207 Facility at site approved in siting plan -- Exemption from zoning and local approval requirements -- Transportation restrictions limited.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-207(1): The construction or operation of a hazardous waste treatment, storage, or disposal facility at a site included within the siting plan is not required to conform to any local zoning or other land use regulation, law, or ordinance.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-207(2): The owner of any hazardous waste treatment, storage, or disposal facility proposed to be located at a site included in the siting plan is not required to obtain approval of the site from any county or municipal planning commission or similar authority and no local unit of government may prohibit or unduly restrict the transportation of hazardous waste through the governmental unit to an approved hazardous waste treatment, storage, or disposal facility.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-208 Facilities subject to Industrial Facilities and Development Act.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The financing, acquiring, constructing, reconstructing, improving, maintaining, equipping, or finishing of a hazardous waste treatment, disposal, or storage facility is deemed, where applicable, to be a "project," subject to the Utah Industrial Facilities and Development Act.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-301 Short title.
-------------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Hazardous Substances Mitigation Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(1)(a): "Abatement action" means to take steps or contract with someone to take steps to eliminate or mitigate the direct or immediate threat to the public health or the environment caused by a hazardous materials release.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(1)(b): "Abatement action" includes control of the source of the contamination.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(2): "Bona fide prospective purchaser" has the meaning given in 42 U.S.C. Sec. 9601(40) of CERCLA, but with the substitution of "executive director" for "President" and "part" for "chapter," and including "hazardous materials" where the term "hazardous substances" appears.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(3): "CERCLA" means 42 U.S.C. 9601 et seq., the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(4): "Cleanup action" means action taken according to the procedures established in this part to prevent, eliminate, minimize, mitigate, or clean up the release of a hazardous material from a facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(5): "Contiguous property owner" means a person who qualifies for the exemption from liability in 42 U.S.C. Sec. 9607(q)(1) of CERCLA, but with the substitution of "executive director" for "President" and "part" for "chapter."
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(6): 19-6-306 "Enforcement action" means the procedures contained in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(7)(a): "Facility" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(7)(a)(i): any building, structure, installation, equipment, pipe, or pipeline, including any pipe into a sewer or publicly owned treatment works, well, pit, pond, lagoon, impoundment, ditch, landfill, storage container, motor vehicle, rolling stock, or aircraft; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(7)(a)(ii): any site or area where a hazardous material or substance has been deposited, stored, disposed of, or placed, or otherwise come to be located.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(7)(b): "Facility" does not mean any consumer product in consumer use or any vessel.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(8): 19-6-307 "Fund" means the Hazardous Substances Mitigation Fund created by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(9): "Hazardous materials" means hazardous waste as defined in the Utah Hazardous Waste Management Regulations, PCBs, dioxin, asbestos, or a substance regulated under 42 U.S.C. Section 6991(7).
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(10): "Hazardous substances" means the definition of hazardous substances contained in CERCLA.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(11): 19-6-311 "Hazardous substances priority list" means a list of facilities meeting the criteria established by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(12): "Innocent landowner" means a person who qualifies for the exemption from liability in 42 U.S.C. Sec. 9607(b)(3) of CERCLA.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(13): "National Contingency Plan" means the National Oil and Hazardous Substance Contingency plan established by CERCLA.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(14): "National Priority List" means the list established by CERCLA.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(15): "National priority list site" means a site in Utah that is listed on the National Priority List.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(16): "Proposed national priority list site" means a site in Utah that has been proposed by the Environmental Protection Agency for listing on the National Priority List.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(17): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(17)(a): "Release" means a spilling, leaking, pumping, pouring, emitting, emptying, discharging, injecting, escaping, leaching, dumping, or disposing of substances into the environment that is not authorized under state or federal law, rule, or regulation.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(17)(b): "Release" includes abandoning or discarding barrels, containers, and other closed receptacles containing any hazardous material or substance, unless the discard or abandonment is authorized under state or federal law, rule, or regulation.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(18): "Remedial action" means action taken consistent with the substantive requirements of CERCLA according to the procedures established by this part to prevent, eliminate, minimize, mitigate, or clean up the release of a hazardous substance from a facility on the hazardous substances priority list.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(19): "Remedial action plan" means a plan for remedial action consistent with the substantive requirements of CERCLA and approved by the executive director.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(20): "Remedial investigation" means a remedial investigation and feasibility study as defined in the National Contingency Plan established by CERCLA.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(21): (21)(a)(i); (ii); Title 75, Utah Uniform Probate Code; Title 75, Utah Uniform Probate Code; (21)(c)(i)(B)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(21)(a): "Responsible party" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(21)(a)(i): the owner or operator of a facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(21)(a)(ii): any person who, at the time any hazardous substance or material was disposed of at the facility, owned or operated the facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(21)(a)(iii): any person who arranged for disposal or treatment, or arranged with a transporter for transport, for disposal, or treatment of hazardous materials or substances owned or possessed by the person, at any facility owned or operated by another person and containing the hazardous materials or substances; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(21)(a)(iv): any person who accepts or accepted any hazardous materials or substances for transport to a facility selected by that person from which there is a release that causes the incurrence of response costs.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(21)(b): For hazardous materials or substances that were delivered by a motor carrier to any facility, "responsible party" does not include the motor carrier, and the motor carrier may not be considered to have caused or contributed to any release at the facility that results from circumstances or conditions beyond its control.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(21)(c): (21)(a)(i); (ii); Title 75, Utah Uniform Probate Code; Title 75, Utah Uniform Probate Code "Responsible party" under Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(21)(c)(i): Title 75, Utah Uniform Probate Code any person who does not participate in the management of a facility and who holds indicia of ownership:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(21)(c)(i)(A): primarily to protect a security interest in a facility; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(21)(c)(i)(B): Title 75, Utah Uniform Probate Code as a fiduciary or custodian under
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(21)(c)(ii): governmental ownership or control of property by involuntary transfers as provided in CERCLA Section 101(20)(D) and 40 CFR 300.1105, National Contingency Plan; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(21)(c)(iii): Title 75, Utah Uniform Probate Code any person, including a fiduciary or custodian under
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(21)(d): (21)(c)(i)(B) The exemption created by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(21)(e): The terms "security interest," "participate in management," "foreclose," and "foreclosure" under this part are defined in accordance with 42 U.S.C. Sec. 9601(20)(E), (F), and (G) of CERCLA.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302(22): "Scored site" means a facility in Utah that meets the requirements of scoring established by the National Contingency Plan for placement on the National Priority List.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302.5 Retroactive effect.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302.5(1): The Legislature finds the language in this part, prior to the passage of this act, did not clearly set forth procedures for identifying responsible parties and allocating among those parties response costs at sites where hazardous substances or materials have been released.  This lack of clarity has interfered with effective allocation of costs of cleanup as required by this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302.5(2): It is the intent of the Legislature that this act provides clarification of the Legislature's original intent to facilitate cleanups of hazardous substances or materials by providing clarification of procedures for allocating liability and response costs.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302.5(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302.5(3)(a): It is the intent of the Legislature that liability as determined under this act applies retroactively to any release of a hazardous substance or material subject to or currently in the process of investigation, abatement, or corrective action under this part as of the effective date of this act.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-302.5(3)(b): Any responsible party whose liability for cleanup costs is absolved or altered by the provisions of this act is subject only to further costs or action as required by this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-303 Rulemaking provisions.
-----------------------------------------------------
The executive director may regulate hazardous substances releases by making rules in accordance with

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-304 Inspections.
-------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-304(1): Upon presentation of appropriate credentials and at any reasonable time, any authorized officer, employee, or representative of the department may:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-304(1)(a): enter and inspect any property, premises, or place where he has reason to believe there is a hazardous materials or substances release;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-304(1)(b): copy any records relating to those hazardous materials or substances to determine compliance with this part and the rules made under authority of this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-304(1)(c): inspect and take samples of any suspected hazardous material or substance.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-304(2): If the department's representative takes samples of any suspected hazardous material or substance under authority of this section, he shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-304(2)(a): give a receipt describing the sample taken to the owner, operator, or agent who has control of the suspected hazardous material or substance;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-304(2)(b): if requested and if possible, give the owner, operator, or agent a split sample of the suspected hazardous material or substance equal in volume or weight to the portion he retains; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-304(2)(c): if an analysis of any sample is made, upon request, promptly furnish a copy of the results of the analysis to the owner, operator, or agent.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-306 Penalties -- Lawsuits.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-306(1): Any person who violates any final order or rule issued or made under this part is subject in a civil proceeding to a penalty of not more than $10,000 per day for each day of violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-306(2): Any person who violates the terms of any agreement made under authority of this part is subject in a civil proceeding to pay:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-306(2)(a): any penalties stipulated in the agreement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-306(2)(b): if no penalties are stipulated in the agreement, a penalty of not more than $10,000 per day for each day of violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-306(3): The executive director shall deposit all civil penalties collected under the authority of this section into the General Fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-306(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-306(4)(a): The executive director may enforce any orders issued under authority of this part by bringing a suit to enforce the order in the district court in Salt Lake County or in the district court in the county where the hazardous substances release occurred.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-306(4)(b): After a remedial investigation has been completed, the executive director may bring a suit in district court against all responsible parties, asking the court for injunctive relief and to apportion liability among the responsible parties for performance of remedial action.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-307(3)(b): Interest earned on fund money shall be deposited into the fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-307(4): 19-6-309; 19-6-310; 19-6-314; 19-6-316 The executive director may use fund money to:

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-308 Hazardous Substances Mitigation Fund -- Prohibited uses.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The executive director may not use fund money to pay for:Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-308(1): property damage or bodily injury resulting from a hazardous material or substance release; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-308(2): property damage or bodily injury resulting from remedial studies or abatement action taken to address a hazardous material or substance release.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-309 Emergency provisions.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-309(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-309(1)(a): If the executive director has reason to believe any hazardous materials release that occurred after March 18, 1985, is presenting a direct and immediate threat to public health or the environment, the executive director may:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-309(1)(a)(i): issue an order requiring the owner or operator of the facility to take abatement action within the time specified in the order; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-309(1)(a)(ii): bring suit on behalf of the state in the district court to require the owner or operator to take immediate abatement action.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-309(1)(b): If the executive director determines the owner or operator cannot be located or is unwilling or unable to take abatement action, the executive director may:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-309(1)(b)(i): reach an agreement with one or more potentially responsible parties to take abatement action; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-309(1)(b)(ii): use fund money to investigate the release and take abatement action.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-309(2): 19-6-307 The executive director may use money from the fund created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-309(2)(a): for abatement action even if an adjudicative proceeding or judicial review challenging an order or a decision to take abatement action is pending; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-309(2)(b): to investigate a suspected hazardous materials release if he has reason to believe the release may present a direct and immediate threat to public health.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-309(3): This section takes precedence over any conflicting provision in this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-310 Apportionment of liability -- Liability agreements -- Legal remedies.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-310(1): 19-6-309 The executive director may recover only the proportionate share of costs of any investigation and abatement performed under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-310(2): (2)(b); (c); (2)(b); (c); (2)(d); (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-310(2)(a): In apportioning responsibility for the investigation and abatement, or liability for the costs of the investigation and abatement, in any administrative proceeding or judicial action, the following standards apply:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-310(2)(a)(i): liability shall be apportioned in proportion to each responsible party's respective  contribution to the release; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-310(2)(a)(ii): the apportionment of liability shall be based on equitable factors, including the quantity, mobility, persistence, and toxicity of hazardous materials contributed by a responsible party, and the comparative behavior of a responsible party in contributing to the release, relative to other responsible parties.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-310(2)(b): Liability may not be apportioned against a current or previous owner or operator who acquired or became the operator of the facility before March 18, 1985, who may otherwise be a responsible party but who did not know that any hazardous material which is the subject of a release was on, in, or at the facility prior to acquisition or operation of the facility, and the release is not the result of an act or omission of the current or previous owner or operator.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-310(2)(c): Liability may not  be apportioned against a current or previous owner or operator who acquired or became the operator of the facility on or after March 18, 1985, who may otherwise be a responsible party but who did not know and had no reason to know, after having taken all appropriate inquiry into the previous ownership and uses of the facility, consistent with good commercial or customary practice at the time of the purchase, that any hazardous material  which is the subject of a release was on, in, or at the facility prior to acquisition or operation of the facility, and the release is not the result of an act or omission of the current or previous owner or operator.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-311 Hazardous substances priority list.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-311(1): The executive director shall develop and, as frequently as is necessary, revise a hazardous substances priority list by making a rule that:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-311(1)(a): identifies separately national priority list sites, proposed national priority list sites, and scored sites that pose a significant threat to the public health or the environment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-311(1)(b): declares those sites to be eligible to be addressed under the authority granted by this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-311(2): The executive director may not spend fund money or use the authority granted by this part to address any facilities containing hazardous substances that are not on the hazardous substances priority list.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-311(3): The executive director shall remove facilities from the hazardous substances priority list when appropriate.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-312 Preinvestigation requirements.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Before undertaking any remedial investigations on a facility on the hazardous substances priority list, the executive director shall make reasonable attempts to:Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-312(1): identify potentially responsible parties for each facility; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-312(2): send written notice to each potentially responsible party informing him of his potential responsibility.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-316 Liability for costs of remedial investigations -- Liability agreements.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-316(1): 19-6-314; 19-6-315 The executive director may recover only a proportionate share of costs of any remedial investigation performed under Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-316(2): (2)(b); (c); (2)(b); (c); (2)(d); (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-316(2)(a): In apportioning responsibility for the remedial investigation, or liability for the costs of the remedial investigation, in any administrative proceeding or judicial action, the following standards apply:

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-317 Remedial investigation report -- Remedial action plan implementation -- Legal remedies.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-317(1): Upon receipt of a remedial investigation report for a national priority list site, the executive director shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-317(1)(a): review the report;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-317(1)(b): provide a period for public comment;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-317(1)(c): issue an order defining a remedial action plan consistent with CERCLA for the facility; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-317(1)(d): follow the procedures established by the National Contingency Plan to avoid inconsistent state and federal action.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-317(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-317(2)(a): To implement the remedial action plan, the executive director shall seek to reach an agreement with all responsible parties to perform the remedial action.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-317(2)(b): The executive director may define in the agreement the remedial action required and the time limits for completion of the remedial action.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-317(2)(c): If the responsible parties fail to perform as required under an agreement entered under the authority of this section, the executive director may take action to enforce the agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-317(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-317(3)(a): If the executive director is unable to reach an agreement with one or more responsible parties to perform remedial action, he  may order all responsible parties to perform the remedial action.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-317(3)(b): The executive director may define in the order the remedial action required and the time limits for completion of the remedial action.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-319 Remedial action investigation report -- Remedial action plan implementation -- Enforcement provisions.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-319(1): Upon receipt of a remedial action investigation report for a proposed national priority list site or a scored site, the executive director shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-319(1)(a): review the report;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-319(1)(b): provide a period for public comment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-319(1)(c): issue an order defining the remedial action plan for the facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-319(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-319(2)(a): To implement the remedial action plan, the executive director shall seek to reach an agreement with all responsible parties to perform the remedial action.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-319(2)(b): In reaching an agreement for a proposed national priority list site, the executive director shall follow procedures established by the National Contingency Plan to avoid inconsistent state and federal action.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-319(2)(c): The executive director may define in the agreement the remedial action required and the time limits for completion of the remedial action.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-319(2)(d): If the responsible parties fail to perform as required under an agreement entered under the authority of this section, the executive director may take action to enforce the agreement.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-320 Remedial action completion procedures -- Legal remedies.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-320(1): 19-6-317 A party who has entered an agreement or who has been issued a final order under the authority of Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-320(2): Upon notice that remedial action at a facility is complete, the executive director shall inspect the facility to determine if the remedial action plan as implemented meets the substantive requirements of CERCLA.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-320(3): If the executive director determines that the remedial action plan as implemented meets the substantive requirements of CERCLA, except for any ongoing activities at the facility, including operation, maintenance, or monitoring, he shall issue a notice of agency action declaring that remedial action at the facility is complete and removing the facility from the hazardous substances priority list.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-320(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-320(4)(a): If the executive director determines that the remedial action plan for a national priority list site, as implemented, does not meet the substantive requirements of CERCLA, he may issue an order directing the responsible parties to take additional actions to implement the remedial action plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-320(4)(b): If the responsible parties refuse to comply with the order the executive director may take enforcement action.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-320(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-320(5)(a): If the executive director determines that the remedial action plan for a proposed national priority list site or a scored site has not been properly and completely implemented according to the agreement between the executive director and the responsible parties, or is not consistent with the substantive requirements of CERCLA, he shall request that the responsible parties take additional actions to fulfill the agreement to implement the remedial action plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-320(5)(b): If the responsible parties refuse to comply with the request, the executive director may take action to enforce the agreement.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-321 Construction with other state and federal laws -- Governmental immunity.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-321(1): (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-321(2): Title 63G, Chapter 7, Governmental Immunity Act of Utah In addition to the governmental immunity granted in
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-321(3): Nothing in this part affects, limits, or modifies in any way the authority granted to the state, any state agency, or any political subdivision under other state or federal law.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-322 Cooperative agreements with federal government -- Legislative findings.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Due to the enactment of the federal Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act of 1980, PL 96-510, and recognizing the applicability of that act to the unauthorized or accidental discharge of hazardous substances or to inactive hazardous waste sites in the state of Utah, the Legislature finds and declares it to be in the public interest to enter into agreements with the federal Environmental Protection Agency to undertake activities and perform remedial and removal actions as provided by PL 96-510, to protect the public health, safety, and welfare.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-323 Department authority to enter cooperative agreements.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department, on behalf of the state, is authorized to undertake activities and enter into contracts and cooperative agreements with the federal Environmental Protection Agency as provided by the federal Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act of 1980, PL 96-510.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-401 Short title.
-------------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Underground Storage Tank Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(1): "Abatement action" means action taken to limit, reduce, mitigate, or eliminate:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(1)(a): a release from a petroleum storage tank; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(1)(b): the damage caused by that release.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(2): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; 72-10-102 "Aboveground petroleum storage tank" means a storage tank that is, by volume, less than 10% buried in the ground, including the pipes connected to the storage tank and:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(2)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(2)(a)(i): has attached underground piping; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(2)(a)(ii): rests directly on the ground;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(2)(b): contains regulated substances;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(2)(c): has the capacity to hold 501 gallons or more; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(2)(d): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act; 72-10-102 is not:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(2)(d)(i): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act used in agricultural operations, as defined by the board by rule made in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(2)(d)(ii): used for heating oil for consumptive use on the premises where stored;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(2)(d)(iii): related to a petroleum facility under SIC Code 2911 or 5171 of the 1987 Standard Industrial Classification Manual of the federal Executive Office of the President, Office of Management and Budget;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(2)(d)(iv): directly related to oil or gas production and gathering operations; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(2)(d)(v): 72-10-102 used in the fueling of aircraft or ground service equipment at a commercial airport that serves passengers or cargo, with commercial airport defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(3): 19-1-106 "Board" means the Waste Management and Radiation Control Board created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(4): "Bodily injury" means bodily harm, sickness, disease, or death sustained by a person.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(5): "Certificate of compliance" means a certificate issued to a facility by the director:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(5)(a): demonstrating that an owner or operator of a facility containing one or more petroleum storage tanks has met the requirements of this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(5)(b): listing petroleum storage tanks at the facility, specifying:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(5)(b)(i): which tanks may receive petroleum; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(5)(b)(ii): which tanks have not met the requirements for compliance.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(6): "Certificate of registration" means a certificate issued to a facility by the director demonstrating that an owner or operator of a facility containing one or more petroleum storage tanks has:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(6)(a): registered the tanks; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(6)(b): paid the annual tank fee.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(7): 19-6-403(1)(a)(vii)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(7)(a): 19-6-403(1)(a)(vii) "Certified petroleum storage tank consultant" means a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(7)(a)(i): for a fee, or in connection with services for which a fee is charged, provides or contracts to provide information, opinions, or advice relating to underground storage tank release:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(7)(a)(i)(A): management;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(7)(a)(i)(B): abatement;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(7)(a)(i)(C): investigation;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(7)(a)(i)(D): corrective action; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(7)(a)(i)(E): evaluation;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(7)(a)(ii): has submitted an application to the director;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(7)(a)(iii): received a written statement of certification from the director; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(7)(a)(iv): 19-6-403(1)(a)(vii) meets the education and experience standards established by the board under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(7)(b): "Certified petroleum storage tank consultant" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(7)(b)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(7)(b)(i)(A): an employee of the owner or operator of the underground storage tank; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(7)(b)(i)(B): an employee of a business operation that has a business relationship with the owner or operator of the underground storage tank, and markets petroleum products or manages underground storage tanks; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(7)(b)(ii): a person licensed to practice law in this state who offers only legal advice on underground storage tank release:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(7)(b)(ii)(A): management;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(7)(b)(ii)(B): abatement;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(7)(b)(ii)(C): investigation;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(7)(b)(ii)(D): corrective action; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(7)(b)(ii)(E): evaluation.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(8): "Closed" means a petroleum storage tank that is no longer in use that has been:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(8)(a): emptied and cleaned to remove the liquids and accumulated sludges; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(8)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(8)(b)(i): removed along with all underground components; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(8)(b)(ii): filled with an inert solid material, and in the case of piping, secured and capped.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(9): "Corrective action plan" means a plan for correcting a release from a petroleum storage tank that includes provisions for any of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(9)(a): cleanup or removal of the release;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(9)(b): containment or isolation of the release;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(9)(c): treatment of the release;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(9)(d): correction of the cause of the release;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(9)(e): monitoring and maintenance of the site of the release;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(9)(f): provision of alternative water supplies to a person whose drinking water has become contaminated by the release; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(9)(g): temporary or permanent relocation, whichever is determined by the director to be more cost-effective, of a person whose dwelling has been determined by the director to be no longer habitable due to the release.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(10): "Costs" means money expended for:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(10)(a): investigation;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(10)(b): abatement action;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(10)(c): corrective action;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(10)(d): judgments, awards, and settlements for bodily injury or property damage to third parties;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(10)(e): legal and claims adjusting costs incurred by the state in connection with judgments, awards, or settlements for bodily injury or property damage to third parties; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(10)(f): costs incurred by the state risk manager in determining the actuarial soundness of the fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(11): 19-6-424 "Covered by the fund" means the requirements of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(12): "Director" means the director of the Division of Environmental Response and Remediation.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(13): 19-1-105(1)(c) "Division" means the Division of Environmental Response and Remediation, created in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(14): "Dwelling" means a building that is usually occupied by a person lodging there at night.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(15): 19-6-425 "Enforcement proceedings" means a civil action or the procedures to enforce orders established by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(16): "Facility" means the petroleum storage tanks located on a single parcel of property or on any property adjacent or contiguous to that parcel.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(17): 19-6-409 "Fund" means the Petroleum Storage Tank Fund created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(18): "Operator" means a person in control of or who is responsible on a daily basis for the maintenance of a petroleum storage tank that is in use for the storage, use, or dispensing of a regulated substance.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(19): "Owner" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(19)(a): in the case of an underground storage tank in use on or after November 8, 1984, a person who owns an underground storage tank used for the storage, use, or dispensing of a regulated substance;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(19)(b): in the case of an underground storage tank in use before November 8, 1984, but not in use on or after November 8, 1984, a person who owned the tank immediately before the discontinuance of its use for the storage, use, or dispensing of a regulated substance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(19)(c): in the case of an aboveground petroleum storage tank, a person who owns the aboveground petroleum storage tank.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(20): "Petroleum" includes crude oil or a fraction of crude oil that is liquid at:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(20)(a): 60 degrees Fahrenheit; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(20)(b): a pressure of 14.7 pounds per square inch absolute.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(21): 19-6-415 "Petroleum storage tank" means a tank that:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(21)(a): is an underground storage tank;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(21)(b): is an aboveground petroleum storage tank; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(21)(c): 19-6-415 is a tank containing regulated substances that is voluntarily submitted for participation in the Petroleum Storage Tank Fund under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(22): 19-6-405.5 "Petroleum Storage Tank Restricted Account" means the account created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(23): 19-6-410.5 "Program" means the Environmental Assurance Program under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(24): "Property damage" means physical injury to, destruction of, or loss of use of tangible property.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(25): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(25)(a): "Regulated substance" means petroleum and petroleum-based substances comprised of a complex blend of hydrocarbons derived from crude oil through processes of separation, conversion, upgrading, and finishing.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(25)(b): "Regulated substance" includes motor fuels, jet fuels, distillate fuel oils, residual fuel oils, lubricants, petroleum solvents, and used oils.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(26): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(26)(a): "Release" means spilling, leaking, emitting, discharging, escaping, leaching, or disposing a regulated substance from a petroleum storage tank into ground water, surface water, or subsurface soils.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(26)(b): A release of a regulated substance from a petroleum storage tank is considered a single release from that tank system.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(27): (27)(a)(i); (ii); (iii); Title 75, Utah Uniform Probate Code; (27)(b)(i)(B); (27)(b)(i)(B)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(27)(a): "Responsible party" means a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(27)(a)(i): is the owner or operator of a facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(27)(a)(ii): owns or has legal or equitable title in a facility or a petroleum storage tank;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(27)(a)(iii): owned or had legal or equitable title in a facility at the time petroleum was received or contained at the facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(27)(a)(iv): operated or otherwise controlled activities at a facility at the time petroleum was received or contained at the facility; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(27)(a)(v): is an underground storage tank installation company.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(27)(b): (27)(a)(i); (ii); (iii); Title 75, Utah Uniform Probate Code "Responsible party" is as defined in Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(27)(b)(i): Title 75, Utah Uniform Probate Code a person who is not an operator and, without participating in the management of a facility and otherwise not engaged in petroleum production, refining, and marketing, holds indicia of ownership:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(27)(b)(i)(A): primarily to protect the person's security interest in the facility; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(27)(b)(i)(B): Title 75, Utah Uniform Probate Code as a fiduciary or custodian under
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(27)(b)(ii): governmental ownership or control of property by involuntary transfers as provided in CERCLA Section 101(20)(D), 42 U.S.C. Sec. 9601(20)(D).

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(27)(d): The terms and activities "indicia of ownership," "primarily to protect a security interest," "participation in management," and "security interest" under this part are in accordance with 40 C.F.R.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(27)(e): (27)(b)(i)(B) The terms "participate in management" and "indicia of ownership" as defined in 40 C.F.R.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(28): "Rests directly on the ground" means that at least some portion of a petroleum storage tank situated aboveground is in direct contact with soil.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(29): "Soil test" means a test, established or approved by board rule, to detect the presence of petroleum in soil.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(30): "State cleanup appropriation" means money appropriated by the Legislature to the department to fund the investigation, abatement, and corrective action regarding releases not covered by the fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(31): "Underground piping" means piping that is buried in the ground that is in direct contact with soil and connected to an aboveground petroleum storage tank.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(32): "Underground storage tank" means a tank regulated under Subtitle I, Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, 42 U.S.C. Sec. 6991c, et seq., including:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(32)(a): underground pipes and lines connected to a storage tank;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(32)(b): underground ancillary equipment;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(32)(c): a containment system; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(32)(d): each compartment of a multi-compartment storage tank.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(33): "Underground storage tank installation company" means a person, firm, partnership, corporation, governmental entity, association, or other organization that installs underground storage tanks.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(34): "Underground storage tank installation company permit" means a permit issued to an underground storage tank installation company by the director.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402(35): (7)(a) "Underground storage tank technician" means a person employed by and acting under the direct supervision of a certified petroleum storage tank consultant to assist in carrying out the functions described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402.5 Retroactive effect.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402.5(1): The Legislature finds the definitions in this part prior to the passage of this act did not clearly set forth procedures for identifying responsible parties and interfered with effective allocation of costs of cleanup as required by this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402.5(2): It is the intent of the Legislature that this act provides clarification regarding procedures for allocating responsibility for the costs of investigation, abatement, and corrective action as required under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-402.5(3): It is the intent of the Legislature that this part imposes liability as determined under this part retroactively to any release of petroleum or any other regulated substance subject to investigation, abatement, or corrective action under this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-415.5 State owned or leased tanks to participate in program.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-417 Use of fund revenues to investigate certain releases from petroleum storage tank.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If the director is notified of or otherwise becomes aware of a release or suspected release of petroleum, he may expend revenues from the fund to investigate the release or suspected release if he has reasonable cause to believe the release is from a tank that is covered by the fund.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-419(5)(a): $1,990,000 if the release was from a tank:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-419(5)(a)(i): located at a facility engaged in petroleum production, refining, or marketing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-419(5)(a)(ii): with an average monthly facility throughput of more than 10,000 gallons; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-419(5)(b): $990,000 if the release was from a tank:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-419(5)(b)(i): not located at a facility engaged in petroleum production, refining, or marketing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-419(5)(b)(ii): with an average monthly facility throughput of 10,000 gallons or less.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-419(6): The director may pay fund money to a responsible party up to the following amounts in a fiscal year:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-419(6)(a): $1,990,000 to a responsible party owning or operating less than 100 petroleum storage tanks; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-419(6)(b): $3,990,000 to a responsible party owning or operating 100 or more petroleum storage tanks.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-419(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-419(7)(a): In authorizing payments for costs from the fund, the director shall apportion money:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-419(7)(a)(i): first, to the following type of expenses incurred by the state:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-419(7)(a)(i)(A): legal;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-419(7)(a)(i)(B): adjusting; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-419(7)(a)(i)(C): actuarial;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-419(7)(a)(ii): second, to costs incurred for:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-419(7)(a)(ii)(A): investigation;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-419(7)(a)(ii)(B): abatement action; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-419(7)(a)(ii)(C): corrective action; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-419(7)(a)(iii): third, to payment of:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-419(7)(a)(iii)(A): judgments;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-419(7)(a)(iii)(B): awards; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-419(7)(a)(iii)(C): settlements to third parties for bodily injury or property damage.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-419(7)(b): The board shall make rules governing the apportionment of costs among third party claimants.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-420 Releases -- Abatement actions -- Corrective actions.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-420(1): If the director determines that a release from a petroleum storage tank has occurred, the director shall:

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-420(1)(b): determine which responsible parties, if any, are covered by the fund regarding the release in question.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-420(2)(b): (2)(a); 19-6-405.7; 19-6-424.5; 19-6-424.5; 19-6-414 if the owner or operator fails to comply with the action ordered by the director under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-420(2)(b)(i): 19-6-405.7 subject to the conditions in this part, use money from the fund, if the tank involved is covered by the fund, state cleanup appropriation, or the Petroleum Storage Tank Cleanup Fund created under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-420(2)(b)(ii): commence an enforcement proceeding;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-420(2)(b)(iii): 19-6-424.5 enter into agreements or issue orders as allowed by Section

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-420(2)(b)(v): 19-6-414 where the owner or operator is the responsible party, revoke the responsible party's certificate of compliance, as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-420(3): 19-6-419; 19-6-419

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-420(3)(b): 19-6-419 If a release presents the possibility of imminent and substantial danger to the public health or the environment, the owner or operator may take immediate abatement action and petition the director for reimbursement from the fund for the costs of the abatement action.  If the owner or operator can demonstrate to the satisfaction of the director that the abatement action was reasonable and timely in light of circumstances, the director shall reimburse the petitioner for costs associated with immediate abatement action, subject to the limitations established in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-420(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-420(4)(a): If the director determines corrective action is necessary, the director shall order the owner or operator to submit a corrective action plan to address the release.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-420(4)(b): If the owner or operator submits a corrective action plan, the director shall review the corrective action plan and approve or disapprove the plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-420(4)(c): In reviewing the corrective action plan, the director shall consider the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-420(4)(c)(i): the threat to public health;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-420(4)(c)(ii): the threat to the environment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-420(4)(c)(iii): the cost-effectiveness of alternative corrective actions.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-420(5): 19-6-419 If the director approves the corrective action plan or develops the director's own corrective action plan, the director shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-420(5)(a): approve the estimated cost of implementing the corrective action plan;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-420(5)(b): order the owner or operator to implement the corrective action plan;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-420(5)(c): 19-6-419
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-420(5)(c)(i): if the release is covered by the fund, determine the amount of fund money to be allocated to an owner or operator to implement a corrective action plan; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-420(5)(c)(ii): 19-6-419 subject to the limitations established in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-420(6): 19-6-419
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-420(6)(a): The director may not distribute any money from the fund for corrective action until the owner or operator obtains the director's approval of the corrective action plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-420(6)(b): 19-6-419 An owner or operator who begins corrective action without first obtaining approval from the director and who is covered by the fund may be reimbursed for the costs of the corrective action, subject to the limitations established in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-422 Participation by state risk manager in suit, claim, or settlement.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-422(1): If a suit is filed or a claim is made against  a responsible party who is eligible for payments from the fund for bodily injury or property damage connected with a release of petroleum from a petroleum storage tank, the state risk manager and his legal counsel may participate with the responsible party and his legal counsel in:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-422(1)(a): the defense of any suit;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-422(1)(b): determination of legal strategy and any other decisions affecting the defense of any suit; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-422(1)(c): any settlement negotiations.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-422(2): The state risk manager shall approve any settlement between the responsible party and a third party before payment of fund money is made.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424 Claims not covered by fund.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424(1): The director may not authorize payments from the fund unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424(1)(a): the claim was based on a release occurring during a period for which that tank was covered by the fund;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424(1)(b): the claim was made:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424(1)(b)(i): during a period for which that tank was covered by the fund; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424(1)(b)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424(1)(b)(ii)(A): within one year after that fund-covered tank is closed; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424(1)(b)(ii)(B): within six months after the end of the period during which the tank was covered by the fund; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424(1)(c): there are sufficient revenues in the fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424(2): The director may not authorize payments from the fund for an underground storage tank installation company unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424(2)(a): the claim was based on a release occurring during the period prior to the issuance of a certificate of compliance;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424(2)(b): the claim was made within 12 months after the date the tank is issued a certificate of compliance for that tank; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424(2)(c): there are sufficient revenues in the fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424(3): The director may require the claimant to provide additional information as necessary to demonstrate coverage by the fund at the time of submittal of the claim.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424(4): (1); (2) If the Legislature repeals or refuses to reauthorize the program for petroleum storage tanks established in this part, the director may authorize payments from the fund as provided in this part for claims made until the end of the time period established in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5 Apportionment of liability -- Liability agreements -- Legal remedies -- Amounts recovered.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(1): 19-6-420 After providing notice and opportunity for comment to responsible parties identified and named under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(1)(a): issue written orders determining responsible parties;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(1)(b): issue written orders apportioning liability among responsible parties; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(1)(c): take action, including legal action or issuing written orders, to recover costs from responsible parties, including costs of any investigation, abatement, and corrective action performed under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(2): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(2)(a): In any apportionment of liability, whether made by the director or made in any administrative proceeding or judicial action, the following standards apply:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(2)(a)(i): liability shall be apportioned among responsible parties in proportion to their respective contributions to the release; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(2)(a)(ii): the apportionment of liability shall be based on equitable factors, including the quantity, mobility, persistence, and toxicity of regulated substances contributed by a responsible party, and the comparative behavior of a responsible party in contributing to the release, relative to other responsible parties.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(2)(b): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(2)(b)(i): The burden of proving proportionate contribution shall be borne by each responsible party.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(2)(b)(ii): (2)(a) If a responsible party does not prove the responsible party's proportionate contribution, the court or the director shall apportion liability to the party based on available evidence and the standards of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(2)(c): The court, the board, or the director may not impose joint and several liability.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(2)(d): Each responsible party is strictly liable for his share of costs.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(3): The failure of the director to name all responsible parties is not a defense to an action under this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(4): The director may enter into an agreement with any responsible party regarding that party's proportionate share of liability or any action to be taken by that party.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(5): 19-6-420(1)(a) The director and a responsible party may not enter into an agreement under this part unless all responsible parties named and identified under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(5)(a): have been notified in writing by either the director or the responsible party of the proposed agreement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(5)(b): have been given an opportunity to comment on the proposed agreement prior to the parties' entering into the agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(6): (6)(a); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(6)(a): Any party who incurs costs under this part in excess of his liability may seek contribution from any other party who is or may be liable under this part for the excess costs in the district court.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(6)(b): (6)(a); (2) In resolving claims made under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(7)(a): A party who has resolved his liability under this part is not liable for claims for contribution regarding matters addressed in the agreement or order.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(7)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(7)(b)(i): An agreement or order determining liability under this part does not discharge any of the liability of responsible parties who are not parties to the agreement or order, unless the terms of the agreement or order expressly provide otherwise.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(7)(b)(ii): An agreement or order determining liability made under this subsection reduces the potential liability of other responsible parties by the amount of the agreement or order.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(8): (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(8)(a): If the director obtains less than complete relief from a party who has resolved his liability under this section, the director may bring an action against any party who has not resolved his liability as determined in an order.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(8)(b): (2) In apportioning liability, the standards of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(8)(c): A party who resolved his liability for some or all of the costs under this part may seek contribution from any person who is not a party to the agreement or order.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(9): 19-6-420; 19-6-405.7

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-424.5(9)(b): 19-6-420 If the director makes payments from the fund or state cleanup appropriation, he may recover the amount paid using the authority of Section

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-425 Violation of part -- Civil penalty -- Suit in district court.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-426 Limitation of liability of state -- Liability of responsible parties -- Indemnification agreement involving responsible parties.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-426(1): This part is not intended to create an insurance program.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-426(2): The fund established in this part shall only provide funds to finance costs for responsible parties who meet the requirements of this part when releases from petroleum storage tanks occur.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-426(3): The assets of the fund, if any, are the sole source of money to pay claims against the fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-426(4): The state is not liable for:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-426(4)(a): any amounts payable from the fund for which the fund does not have sufficient assets;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-426(4)(b): any expenses or debts of the fund; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-426(4)(c): any claim arising from the creation, management, rate-setting, or any other activity pertaining to the fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-426(5): The responsible parties are liable for any costs associated with any release from the underground storage tank system.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-426(6): This part does not preclude a responsible party from enforcing or recovering under any agreement or contract for indemnification associated with a release from the tank or from pursuing any other legal remedies that may be available against any party.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-426(7): 19-6-419 If any payment is made under this part, the fund shall be subrogated to all the responsible parties' rights of recovery against any person or organization and the responsible parties shall execute and deliver instruments and papers and do whatever else is necessary to secure the rights.  The responsible parties shall do nothing after a release is discovered to prejudice the rights.  In the event of recovery by the fund, any amount recovered shall first be used to reimburse the responsible parties for costs they are required to pay pursuant to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-426(8): Parties who elect to participate in the fund do so subject to the conditions and limitations in this section and in this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-427 Liability of any person under other laws -- Additional state and governmental immunity -- Exceptions.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-427(1): (2) Except as provided in Subsection
