Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-501 Short title.
-------------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Solid Waste Management Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(1)(a): "Advanced recycling" means a manufacturing process that converts post-use polymers or recovered feedstock into basic raw materials, chemicals, or advanced recycling products using technology including:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(1)(a)(i): pyrolysis;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(1)(a)(ii): gasification;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(1)(a)(iii): depolymerization;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(1)(a)(iv): catalytic cracking;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(1)(a)(v): reforming;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(1)(a)(vi): hydrogenation;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(1)(a)(vii): solvolysis; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(1)(a)(viii): chemolysis.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(1)(b): "Advanced recycling" does not include incineration of plastics, energy recovery processes, or a product sold as fuel.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(2): 19-1-105(1)(d) "Advanced recycling facility" means a manufacturing facility:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(2)(a): 19-1-105(1)(d) that is registered with the Division of Waste Management and Radiation Control, created in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(2)(b): that receives, stores, and converts post-use polymers or recovered feedstock using advanced recycling;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(2)(c): that is subject to applicable Department of Environmental Quality manufacturing regulations for air, water, waste, and land use; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(2)(d): for which the feedstock received by the manufacturing facility is source-separated, diverted, or recovered from municipal or other waste streams prior to acceptance at the facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(3): "Advanced recycling product" means a recycled product produced at an advanced recycling facility, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(3)(a): a monomer;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(3)(b): an oligomer;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(3)(c): a plastic;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(3)(d): a chemical feedstock;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(3)(e): a basic and unfinished chemical;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(3)(f): a wax;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(3)(g): a lubricant;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(3)(h): a coating; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(3)(i): an adhesive.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(4): "Depolymerization" means a manufacturing process that breaks post-use polymers into smaller molecules to produce raw materials or products.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(5): (5)(a) "Gasification" means a manufacturing process that:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(5)(a): heats post-use polymers or recovered feedstock in an oxygen-controlled atmosphere; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(5)(b): (5)(a) following the process described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(6): "Governing body" means the governing board, commission, or council of a public entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(7): "Jurisdiction" means the area within the incorporated limits of:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(7)(a): a municipality;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(7)(b): a special service district;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(7)(c): a municipal-type service district;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(7)(d): a service area; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(7)(e): the territorial area of a county not lying within a municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(8): "Long-term agreement" means an agreement or contract having a term of more than five years but less than 50 years.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(9): "Mass balance attribution" means a chain of custody accounting methodology with rules defined by a third-party certification system that enables the attribution of the mass of advanced recycling feedstock to at least one advanced recycling product.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(10): "Municipal residential waste" means solid waste that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(10)(a): discarded or rejected at a residence within the public entity's jurisdiction; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(10)(b): collected at or near the residence by:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(10)(b)(i): a public entity; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(10)(b)(ii): a person with whom the public entity has as an agreement to provide solid waste management.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(11): "Post-use polymer" means a plastic that:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(11)(a): is derived from an industrial, commercial, agricultural, or domestic activity;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(11)(b): includes pre-consumer materials and post-consumer materials;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(11)(c): has been sorted from solid waste and other regulated waste but may contain residual amounts of waste including organic material and incidental contaminants or impurities;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(11)(d): is not mixed with solid waste or hazardous waste during processing at the advanced recycling facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(11)(e): is used as a feedstock for the manufacturing of raw materials, intermediate products, or final products using advanced recycling; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(11)(f): is held for processing or processed at the advanced recycling facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(12): "Product sold as fuel" does not mean a recycled product.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(13): Title 17D, Chapter 1, Special Service District Act; Title 17B, Chapter 2a, Part 9, Service Area Act; Title 17, Chapter 34, Municipal-Type Services to Unincorporated Areas "Public entity" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(13)(a): a county;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(13)(b): a municipality;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(13)(c): Title 17D, Chapter 1, Special Service District Act a special service district under
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(13)(d): Title 17B, Chapter 2a, Part 9, Service Area Act a service area under
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(13)(e): Title 17, Chapter 34, Municipal-Type Services to Unincorporated Areas a municipal-type service district created under
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(14): (14)(a) "Pyrolysis" means a manufacturing process that:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(14)(a): heats post-use polymers or recovered feedstock, without oxygen, until melted and thermally decomposed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(14)(b): (14)(a) following the process described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(15): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(15)(a): "Recovered feedstock" means a material:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(15)(a)(i): that includes post-use polymers;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(15)(a)(ii): for which the United States Environmental Protection Agency made a non-waste determination or has otherwise determined is feedstock and solid waste; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(15)(a)(iii): that is converted using an advanced recycling process after storage of less than 270 days.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(15)(b): "Recovered feedstock" does not include unprocessed municipal solid waste or recovered feedstock that is not mixed with solid waste or hazardous waste onsite, or during processing, at an advanced recycling facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(16): 4-10-102 "Recycled plastic" means a product produced from:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(16)(a): mechanical recycling of pre-consumer feedstock or plastic, or post-consumer plastic;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(16)(b): the advanced recycling of pre-consumer feedstock or plastic, or post-consumer plastic, using mass balance attribution under a third-party certification system; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(16)(c): 4-10-102 a recycled material, as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(17): "Requirement" means an ordinance, policy, rule, mandate, or other directive that imposes a legal duty on a person.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(18): "Residence" means an improvement to real property used or occupied as a primary or secondary detached single-family dwelling.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(19): "Resource recovery" means the separation, extraction, recycling, or recovery of usable material, energy, fuel, or heat from solid waste and the disposition of it.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(20): "Short-term agreement" means a contract or agreement having a term of five years or less.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(21): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(21)(a): "Solid waste" means a putrescible or nonputrescible material or substance discarded or rejected as being spent, useless, worthless, or in excess of the owner's needs at the time of discard or rejection, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(21)(a)(i): garbage;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(21)(a)(ii): refuse;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(21)(a)(iii): industrial and commercial waste;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(21)(a)(iv): sludge from an air or water control facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(21)(a)(v): rubbish;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(21)(a)(vi): ash;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(21)(a)(vii): contained gaseous material;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(21)(a)(viii): incinerator residue;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(21)(a)(ix): demolition and construction debris;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(21)(a)(x): a discarded automobile; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(21)(a)(xi): offal.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(21)(b): "Solid waste" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(21)(b)(i): sewage or another highly diluted water carried material or substance and those in gaseous form; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(21)(b)(ii): post-use polymers or recovered feedstock that are converted or held at an advanced recycling facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(22): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(22)(a): "Solid waste management" means the purposeful and systematic collection, transportation, storage, processing, recovery, or disposal of solid waste.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(22)(b): "Solid waste management" does not include advanced recycling.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-502(23): (23)(a)(v)(F); (23)(a)(v)(F)(II); Title 11, Chapter 13, Interlocal Cooperation Act; 19-6-102(19)(b)

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-505 Long-term agreements for joint action -- Construction, acquisition, or sale of interest in management facilities -- Issuance of bonds.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-505(1): Title 11, Chapter 13, Interlocal Cooperation Act
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-505(1)(a): Title 11, Chapter 13, Interlocal Cooperation Act Two or more public entities, which for the purposes of this section shall only include any political subdivision of the state, the state and its agencies, and the United States and its agencies, may enter into long-term agreements with one another pursuant to
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-505(1)(b): Any payments made by a public entity for services received under the agreement are not an indebtedness of the public entity within the meaning of any constitutional or statutory restriction, and no election is necessary for the authorization of the agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-505(1)(c): Any public entity or any public entity in combination with a private entity agreeing to make solid waste management facilities available may, in the agreement, agree to make available to other public entities a specified portion of the capacity of the solid waste management facilities, without regard to its future need of the specified capacity for its own use and may in the agreement agree to increase the capacity of its solid waste management facilities from time to time, as necessary, in order to take care of its own needs and to perform its obligations to the other parties to the agreement.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-506 Schedule of fees -- Classification of property -- Collection of delinquent fees.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-506(1): 19-6-505
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-506(1)(a): The governing body of any public entity may by ordinance or resolution establish a schedule of fees to be imposed and assessed on property within its jurisdiction the revenue from which shall be used for solid waste purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-506(1)(b): In establishing a schedule of fees, the governing body shall classify the property within its jurisdiction based upon the character and volume of waste occurring from the various property uses subject to this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-506(1)(c): 19-6-505 If the governing body makes solid waste facilities available to a public entity as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-506(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-506(2)(a): The governing body may impose, assess, and collect a reasonable fee for each classification of property established and divide the property within its jurisdiction according to the classifications.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-506(2)(b): It may also establish classifications of property for which services may be provided for no fee or a reduced fee and determine the eligibility requirements for inclusion in the classifications upon application by property owners on a case-by-case basis.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-506(2)(c): The governing body shall impose and assess the appropriate fee established for each classification and division of property by ordinance or resolution, and provide therein for the billing and collection of the fees on an annual or more frequent basis as it shall determine to be necessary or appropriate.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-506(2)(d): The ordinance or resolution may provide that the fees imposed and assessed may be billed and collected by the county treasurer as a part of the regular, ad valorem property tax notice, billing, and collection system of the county, if it is feasible to do so, unless the public entity imposing and assessing the fees has an existing service or utility billing and collection system which can be used for this purpose.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-506(3): County treasurers may include the fees certified to them pursuant to this part on the general, ad valorem tax notice and collect and remit the fees in the manner and as a part of the tax collection system including the collection of delinquent fees in the manner provided by law for tax delinquencies.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-506(4): Any governing body which uses the general property tax billing and collection system of a county to bill and collect the fees imposed and assessed under this part shall reimburse the county for the actual costs thereof annually, which costs include the materials, equipment, and supplies used and the labor involved plus a factor added for overhead and general and administrative expenses.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-509(2)(a): a landfill; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-509(2)(b): a recycling facility.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-602 Lead acid batteries -- Disposal limitations.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-602(1): 19-6-603 A person may not place, discard, or otherwise dispose of a lead acid battery in any solid waste treatment, storage, or disposal facility operated by a municipality, county, other political subdivision, or other entity. All lead acid batteries shall be disposed of by delivery to:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-602(1)(a): 19-6-603 a lead acid battery retailer as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-602(1)(b): a lead acid battery wholesaler;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-602(1)(c): a collection or recycling facility; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-602(1)(d): a secondary lead smelter that meets state and federal permit requirements.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-602(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-602(2)(a): Lead acid batteries shall be removed from vehicles prior to crushing or shredding.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-602(2)(b): The removed lead acid batteries shall be disposed of in accordance with this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-603 Collection for recycling.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-603(1): A person selling lead acid batteries at retail shall at the point of sale accept a customer's used lead acid battery and a maximum of one additional used lead acid battery when the customer purchases a new lead acid battery.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-603(2): A person selling lead acid batteries at wholesale shall at the point of sale accept a customer's used lead acid batteries.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-603(3): 19-6-602(1)(b); (c); (d)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-603(3)(a): 19-6-602(1)(b); (c); (d) A person selling lead acid batteries at retail shall post on the premises a clearly legible notice that is at least 8 1/2 inches by 11 inches in size and visible to customers that states: "It is illegal under state law to discard a motor vehicle battery or other lead acid battery. You must recycle your used battery. State law requires us to accept up to two of your used lead acid batteries for recycling when you purchase a new lead acid battery.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-603(3)(b): A person selling lead acid batteries wholesale shall post on the premises a clearly legible notice that is at least 8 1/2 inches by 11 inches in size and visible to customers that states:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-603(4): 19-6-602(1)(b); (c); (d) Lead acid batteries that a lead acid battery retailer is not required to accept under this section shall be disposed of only at facilities listed under Subsections

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-701 Short title.
-------------------------------------------
This act is known as the "Used Oil Management Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-702 Legislative findings.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-702(1): The Legislature finds millions of gallons of used oil are generated each year in Utah, and this oil is:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-702(1)(a): a valuable petroleum resource that can be recycled; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-702(1)(b): in spite of the potential for recycling, significant quantities of used oil are wastefully disposed of or improperly used by means that pollute the water, land, and air, and endanger the public health, safety, and welfare.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-702(2): The Legislature finds used oil should be collected, treated, and reused in a manner that conserves energy and does not present a hazard to public health or the environment.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-702(3): The Legislature finds in light of the harmful consequences that can result from the improper disposal and use of used oil, and its value as a resource, the collection, recycling, and reuse of used oil is in the public interest.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(1): 19-1-106 "Board" means the Waste Management and Radiation Control Board created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(2): "Commission" means the State Tax Commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(3): Title 19, Chapter 1, General Provisions "Department" means the Department of Environmental Quality created in
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(4): "Director" means the director of the Division of Waste Management and Radiation Control.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(5): 19-1-105 "Division" means the Division of Waste Management and Radiation Control, created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(6): "DIY" means do it yourself.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(7): "DIYer" means a person who generates used oil through household activities, including maintenance of personal vehicles.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(8): "DIYer used oil" means used oil a person generates through household activities, including maintenance of personal vehicles.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(9): "DIYer used oil collection center" means any site or facility that accepts or aggregates and stores used oil collected only from DIYers.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(10): Title 19, Chapter 6, Hazardous Substances "Hazardous waste" means any substance defined as hazardous waste under
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(11): "Lubricating oil" means the fraction of crude oil or synthetic oil used to reduce friction in an industrial or mechanical device.  Lubricating oil includes rerefined oil.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(12): "Lubricating oil vendor" means the person making the first sale of a lubricating oil in Utah.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(13): "Manifest" means the form used for identifying the quantity and composition and the origin, routing, and destination of used oil during its transportation from the point of collection to the point of storage, processing, use, or disposal.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(14): "Off-specification used oil" means used oil that exceeds levels of constituents and properties as specified by board rule and consistent with 40 CFR 279, Standards for the Management of Used Oil.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(15): "On-specification used oil" means used oil that does not exceed levels of constituents and properties as specified by board rule and consistent with 40 CFR 279, Standards for the Management of Used Oil.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(16): (16)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(16)(a): (16)(b) "Processing" means chemical or physical operations under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(16)(a)(i): gasoline, diesel, and other petroleum derived fuels;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(16)(a)(ii): lubricants; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(16)(a)(iii): other products derived from used oil.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(16)(b): "Processing" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(16)(b)(i): blending used oil with virgin petroleum products;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(16)(b)(ii): blending used oils to meet fuel specifications;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(16)(b)(iii): filtration;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(16)(b)(iv): simple distillation;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(16)(b)(v): chemical or physical separation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(16)(b)(vi): rerefining.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(17): "Recycled oil" means oil reused for any purpose following its original use, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(17)(a): the purpose for which the oil was originally used; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(17)(b): used oil processed or burned for energy recovery.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(18): "Rerefining distillation bottoms" means the heavy fraction produced by vacuum distillation of filtered and dehydrated used oil.  The composition varies with column operation and feedstock.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(19): "Used oil" means any oil, refined from crude oil or a synthetic oil, that has been used and as a result of that use is contaminated by physical or chemical impurities.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(20): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(20)(a): "Used oil aggregation point" means any site or facility that accepts, aggregates, or stores used oil collected only from other used oil generation sites owned or operated by the owner or operator of the aggregation point, from which used oil is transported to the aggregation point in shipments of no more than 55 gallons.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(20)(b): A used oil aggregation point may also accept oil from DIYers.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(21): "Used oil burner" means a person who burns used oil for energy recovery.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(22): "Used oil collection center" means any site or facility registered with the state to manage used oil and that accepts or aggregates and stores used oil collected from used oil generators, other than DIYers, who are regulated under this part and bring used oil to the collection center in shipments of no more than 55 gallons and under the provisions of this part.  Used oil collection centers may accept DIYer used oil also.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(23): "Used oil fuel marketer" means any person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(23)(a): directs a shipment of off-specification used oil from its facility to a used oil burner; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(23)(b): first claims the used oil to be burned for energy recovery meets the used oil fuel specifications of 40 CFR 279, Standards for the Management of Used Oil, except when the oil is to be burned in accordance with rules for on-site burning in space heaters in accordance with 40 CFR 279.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(24): "Used oil generator" means any person, by site, whose act or process produces used oil or whose act first causes used oil to become subject to regulation.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(25): "Used oil handler" means a person generating used oil, collecting used oil, transporting used oil, operating a transfer facility or aggregation point, processing or rerefining used oil, or marketing used oil.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(26): "Used oil processor or rerefiner" means a facility that processes used oil.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(27): "Used oil transfer facility" means any transportation-related facility, including loading docks, parking areas, storage areas, and other areas where shipments of used oil are held for more than 24 hours during the normal course of transportation and not longer than 35 days.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(28): (28)(b); (28)(b)(i); (ii); (iii)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(28)(a): (28)(b); (28)(b)(i); (ii); (iii) "Used oil transporter" means the following persons unless they are exempted under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(28)(a)(i): any person who transports used oil;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(28)(a)(ii): any person who collects used oil from more than one generator and transports the collected oil;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(28)(a)(iii): (28)(b)(i); (ii); (iii) except as exempted under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(28)(a)(iv): owners and operators of used oil transfer facilities.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(28)(b): "Used oil transporter" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(28)(b)(i): persons who transport oil on site;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(28)(b)(ii): generators who transport shipments of used oil totalling 55 gallons or less from the generator to a used oil collection center as allowed under 40 CFR 279.24, Off-site Shipments;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(28)(b)(iii): generators who transport shipments of used oil totalling 55 gallons or less from the generator to a used oil aggregation point owned or operated by the same generator as allowed under 40 CFR 279.24, Off-site Shipments;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(28)(b)(iv): persons who transport used oil generated by DIYers from the initial generator to a used oil generator, used oil collection center, used oil aggregation point, used oil processor or rerefiner, or used oil burner subject to permitting or registration under this part; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-703(28)(b)(v): railroads that transport used oil and are regulated under 49 U.S.C. Subtitle V, Rail Programs, and 49 U.S.C. 5101 et seq., federal Hazardous Materials Transportation Uniform Safety Act.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-705 Powers and duties of the director
----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-705(1): The director shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-705(1)(a): administer and enforce the rules and orders of the board;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-705(1)(b): issue and revoke registration numbers for DIYer used oil collection centers and used oil collection centers;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-705(1)(c): after public notice and opportunity for a public hearing:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-705(1)(c)(i): issue or modify a permit under this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-705(1)(c)(ii): deny a permit when the director finds the application is not complete; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-705(1)(c)(iii): revoke a permit issued under this section upon a finding the permit holder has failed to ensure compliance with this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-705(1)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-705(1)(d)(i): coordinate with federal, state, and local government, and other agencies, including entering into memoranda of understanding, to ensure effective regulation of used oil under this part, minimize duplication of regulation, and encourage responsible recycling of used oil; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-705(1)(d)(ii): as the department finds appropriate to the implementation of this part, enter into contracts with local health departments to carry out specified functions under this part and be reimbursed by the department in accordance with the contract;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-705(1)(e): require forms, analyses, documents, maps, and other records as the director finds necessary to permit and inspect an operation regulated under this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-705(1)(f): establish a toll-free telephone line to provide information to the public regarding management of used oil and locations of used oil collection centers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-705(1)(g): accept, receive, and administer grants or other funds or gifts from public and private agencies, including the federal government, for the purpose of carrying out any of the functions of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-705(2): The director may:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-705(2)(a): authorize any employee of the division to enter any facility regulated under this part at reasonable times and upon presentation of credentials for the purpose of inspection, audit, or sampling of the used oil site or facility, records, operations, or product;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-705(2)(b): direct a person whose activities are regulated under this part to take samples for a stated purpose and cause them to be analyzed at that person's expense; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-705(2)(c): enforce board rules by issuing orders.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-706(1): (1)(a)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-706(1)(a): Except as authorized by the director, or by rule of the board, or as exempted in this section, a person may not place, discard, or otherwise dispose of used oil:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-706(1)(a)(i): in any solid waste treatment, storage, or disposal facility operated by a political subdivision or a private entity, except as authorized for the disposal of used oil that is hazardous waste under state law;

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-706(1)(a)(iii): on the ground.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-706(2)(a)(i): to the extent reasonably possible all oil has been removed from the item or substance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-706(2)(a)(ii): no free flowing oil remains in the item or substance.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-706(2)(b): (2)(b)(i); (2); (2)

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-706(2)(b)(i)(B): gravity hot-draining and crushing;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-706(2)(b)(i)(C): dismantling and gravity hot-draining; or

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-707 Rebuttable presumption regarding used oil mixtures.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-707(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-707(1)(a): Used oil containing more than 1000 ppm total halogens is presumed to be a hazardous waste because it has been mixed with halogenated hazardous waste listed in 40 CFR 261, Subpart D.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-707(1)(b): This presumption may be rebutted by demonstrating the used oil does not contain hazardous waste, such as by using the analytical method from SW-846, Edition III, to show the used oil does not contain significant concentrations of halogenated hazardous constituents as listed by board rule.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-707(2): (1); (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-707(2)(a): (1) The rebuttable presumption under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-707(2)(b): (1) The rebuttable presumption under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-707(3): (1)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-707(3)(a): (1) The rebuttable presumption under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-707(3)(b): The rebuttable presumption does apply to used oils contaminated with CFCs that have been mixed with used oil from sources other than refrigeration units.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-708 Registration and permit exemptions.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-708(1): 19-6-706 The following persons are subject to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-708(1)(a): generators of DIYer used oil; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-708(1)(b): farmers who generate in a calendar year an average of 25 gallons per month or less of used oil from vehicles or machinery used on the farm.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-708(2): (3) The following are subject to rules made by the board as necessary to obtain and maintain primacy of the state used oil program under 40 C.F.R.  279, Standards for the Management of Used Oil, but are not subject to any other provision of this part:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-708(2)(a): mixtures of used oil and diesel fuel mixed on-site by the generator of the used oil for use in the generator's own vehicles are not subject to this part once the used oil and diesel fuel have been mixed, but prior to mixing, the used oil is subject to this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-708(2)(b): used oil transporters and used oil burners conducting incidental processing operations that occur during the normal course of used oil management prior to transportation or burning;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-708(2)(c): on-specification or off-specification used oil, after it is delivered, as documented by manifest, to a burner authorized to operate by the board or this part and rules made under this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-708(2)(d): used oil burners authorized by the board to burn on-specification or off-specification used oil;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-708(2)(e): used oil placed directly into a crude oil or natural gas pipeline, after the used oil is introduced into the pipeline;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-708(2)(f): used oil generated on vessels due to normal shipboard operations is not subject to this part until it is transported ashore;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-708(2)(g): rerefining distillation bottoms used as feedstock to manufacture asphalt products;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-708(2)(h): materials reclaimed from used oil, used beneficially, and not burned for energy recovery or used in a manner constituting disposal;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-708(2)(i): materials derived from used oil that are disposed of or used in a manner constituting disposal, but are subject to regulation under this chapter if the materials are identified as hazardous waste;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-708(2)(j): (3) wastewater containing a de minimis amount of used oil, as defined in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-708(2)(k): used oil contaminated with polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), if it is subject to regulation under 40 CFR 761, Toxic Substances Control Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-708(2)(l): used oils that are a hazardous waste under this chapter and may not be recycled; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-708(2)(m): used oils that are not hazardous waste under this chapter and cannot be recycled under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-708(3): (2)(j)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-708(3)(a): (2)(j) As used in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-708(3)(a)(i): small spills, leaks, or drippings from pumps, machinery, pipes, and other similar equipment during normal operations; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-708(3)(a)(ii): small amounts of oil lost to the wastewater treatment system or unit during washing or draining operations.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-708(3)(b): "De minimis quantities of used oil" does not include used oil discarded as a result of abnormal operations resulting in substantial leaks, spills, or other releases, or to used oil recovered from wastewaters.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-709 Reclamation of site or facility.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-709(1): The owner or operator of any of the following operations shall reclaim the site of the operation to a post-operations land use, as approved by the board in coordination with the department, when the operation ceases or the permit is revoked:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-709(1)(a): DIYer used oil collection center;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-709(1)(b): used oil collection center;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-709(1)(c): used oil aggregation point;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-709(1)(d): used oil transfer facility; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-709(1)(e): used oil processing or rerefining facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-709(2): DIYer used oil collection centers, used oil collection centers, and used oil aggregation points are not required to post a reclamation surety under this part, but are subject to the reclamation requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-709(3): Facilities and sites required to be permitted under this part shall post a reclamation surety in a form and amount required by board rule prior to issuance of a permit.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-710(5)(c): The owner or operator of the facility shall notify the director in writing of any changes in the information submitted to apply for a permit within 20 days of the change.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-711(1)(b): a permit from the director.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-711(2): The applicant for a permit under this section shall demonstrate:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-711(2)(a): the used oil is not mixed with any hazardous waste;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-711(2)(b): the used oil does not exhibit any hazardous characteristic other than ignitability; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-711(2)(c): how the applicant will minimize the impact on the environment of the use of used oil as a dust or weed suppressant or for other similar applications to the land.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-714 Recycling fee on sale of oil.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-714(1): On and after October 1, 1993, a recycling fee of $.04 per quart or $.16 per gallon is imposed upon the first sale in Utah by a lubricating oil vendor of lubricating oil.  The lubricating oil vendor shall collect the fee at the time the lubricating oil is sold.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-714(2): A fee under this section may not be collected on sales of lubricating oil:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-714(2)(a): shipped outside the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-714(2)(b): purchased in five-gallon or smaller containers and used solely in underground mining operations; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-714(2)(c): in bulk containers of 55 gallons or more.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-714(3): This fee is in addition to all other state, county, or municipal fees and taxes imposed on the sale of lubricating oil.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-714(4): 59-12-104 The exemptions from sales and use tax provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-714(5): The commission may make rules to implement and enforce the provisions of this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-719 Used oil collection account.
-----------------------------------------------------------
There is created in the General Fund a restricted account known as the Used Oil Collection Administration Account. All money received by the state from the recycling fee placed on lubricating oil under this part, all permit fees, all penalties imposed under this part, and all money received as a grant or donation to be used for the administration of this part shall be placed in this account to be appropriated to the division for the management of DIYer used oil under this part subject to the priorities in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-721.1 Notice of violations -- Order for correction -- Civil action to enforce.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-721.1(1): Whenever the director determines that a person is in violation of an applicable approved used oil operation permit, the requirements of this part, or any of the board's rules, the director may cause written notice of that violation to be served upon the alleged violator. The notice shall specify the provisions of the permit, this part, or rule alleged to have been violated, and the facts alleged to constitute the violation.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-721.1(2): The director may:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-721.1(2)(a): issue an order requiring that necessary corrective action be taken within a reasonable time; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-721.1(2)(b): request the attorney general or the county attorney in the county in which the violation is taking place to bring a civil action for injunctive relief and enforcement of this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-723 Local ordinances regarding used oil.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Any political subdivision of the state may enact and enforce ordinances regarding the management of used oil that are consistent with this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-801 Title.
-------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Waste Tire Recycling Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-802 Legislative findings.
----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-802(1): The Legislature finds that the disposal of waste tires is a matter of statewide concern and that recycling of waste tires should be promoted in light of the health and environmental benefits.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-802(2): The Legislature further finds that the recycling of waste tires will decrease the number of tires which are disposed of in landfills and will reduce the health and safety hazards posed by existing stockpiles of waste tires.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-802(3): It is the intent of the Legislature in adopting this part to encourage the development of the recycling industry and the development of markets for recycled products.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(1): "Abandoned waste tire pile" means a waste tire pile regarding which the local department of health has not been able to:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(1)(a): locate the persons responsible for the tire pile; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(1)(b): cause the persons responsible for the tire pile to remove the tire pile.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(2)(a): "Beneficial use" means the use of chipped tires in a manner that is not recycling, storage, or disposal, but that serves as a replacement for another product or material for specific purposes.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(2)(b): "Beneficial use" includes the use of chipped tires:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(2)(b)(i): as daily landfill cover;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(2)(b)(ii): for civil engineering purposes;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(2)(b)(iii): as low-density, light-weight aggregate fill; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(2)(b)(iv): for septic or drain field construction.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(2)(c): "Beneficial use" does not include the use of waste tires or material derived from waste tires:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(2)(c)(i): in the construction of fences; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(2)(c)(ii): as fill, other than low-density, light-weight aggregate fill.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(3): 19-1-106 "Board" means the Waste Management and Radiation Control Board created under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(4): "Chip" or "chipped tire" means a two inch square or smaller piece of a waste tire.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(5): "Commission" means the Utah State Tax Commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(6)(a): "Consumer" means a person who purchases a new tire to satisfy a direct need, rather than for resale.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(6)(b): "Consumer" includes a person who purchases a new tire for a motor vehicle to be rented or leased.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(7): "Crumb rubber" means waste tires that have been ground, shredded, or otherwise reduced in size such that the particles are less than or equal to 3/4 inch in diameter and are 98% wire free by weight.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(8): "Director" means the director of the Division of Waste Management and Radiation Control.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(9): "Disposal" means the deposit, dumping, or permanent placement of waste tire in or on land or in water in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(10): "Dispose of" means to deposit, dump, or permanently place waste tire in or on land or in water in the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(11): 19-1-105 "Division" means the Division of Waste Management and Radiation Control created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(12): 19-6-807 "Fund" means the Waste Tire Recycling Fund created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(13): "Landfill waste tire pile" means a waste tire pile:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(13)(a): located within the permitted boundary of a landfill or transfer station operated by a governmental entity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(13)(b): consisting solely of waste tires brought to a landfill or transfer station for disposal and diverted from the landfill or transfer station waste stream to the waste tire pile.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(14): 26A-1-102 "Local health department" means the local health department, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(15): "Materials derived from waste tires" means tire sections, tire chips, tire shreddings, rubber, steel, fabric, or other similar materials derived from waste tires.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(16): "Mobile facility" means a mobile facility capable of cutting waste tires on site so the waste tires may be effectively disposed of by burial, such as in a landfill.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(17): "New motor vehicle" means a motor vehicle that has never been titled or registered.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(18): "Passenger tire equivalent" means a measure of mixed sizes of tires where each 25 pounds of whole tires or material derived from waste tires is equal to one waste tire.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(19): "Proceeds of the fee" means the money collected by the commission from payment of the recycling fee including interest and penalties on delinquent payments.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(20): 19-6-806 "Recycler" means a person who:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(20)(a): annually uses, or can reasonably be expected within the next year to use, a minimum of 100,000 waste tires generated in the state or 1,000 tons of waste tires generated in the state to recover energy or produce energy, crumb rubber, chipped tires, or an ultimate product; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(20)(b): 19-6-806 is registered as a recycler in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(21): 19-6-805 "Recycling fee" means the fee provided for in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(22): "Shredded waste tires" means waste tires or material derived from waste tires that has been reduced to a six inch square or smaller.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(23): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(23)(a): "Storage" means the placement of waste tires in a manner that does not constitute disposal of the waste tires.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(23)(b): "Storage" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(23)(b)(i): the use of waste tires as ballast to maintain covers on agricultural materials or to maintain covers at a construction site;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(23)(b)(ii): the storage for five or fewer days of waste tires or material derived from waste tires that are to be recycled or applied to a beneficial use; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(23)(b)(iii): the storage of a waste tire before the tire is:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(23)(b)(iii)(A): resold wholesale or retail; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(23)(b)(iii)(B): recapped.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(24): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(24)(a): "Store" means to place waste tires in a manner that does not constitute disposal of the waste tires.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(24)(b): "Store" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(24)(b)(i): to use  waste tires as ballast to maintain covers on agricultural materials or to maintain covers at a construction site; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(24)(b)(ii): to store for five or fewer days waste tires or material derived from waste tires that are to be recycled or applied to a beneficial use.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(25): "Tire" means a pneumatic rubber covering designed to encircle the wheel of a vehicle in which a person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(26): "Tire retailer" means a person engaged in the business of selling new tires either as replacement tires or as part of a new vehicle sale.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(27): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act "Transfer station" is defined by rule made by the board in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(28): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(28)(a): "Ultimate product" means a product that has as a component materials derived from waste tires and that the director finds has a demonstrated market.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(28)(b): "Ultimate product" includes pyrolized materials derived from:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(28)(b)(i): waste tires; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(28)(b)(ii): chipped tires.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(28)(c): "Ultimate product" does not include a product regarding which a waste tire remains after the product is disposed of or disassembled.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(29): "Waste tire" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(29)(a): a tire that is no longer suitable for the tire's original intended purpose because of wear, damage, or defect; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(29)(b): a tire that a tire retailer removes from a vehicle for replacement with a new or used tire.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(30): "Waste tire pile" means a pile of 200 or more waste tires at one location.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(31): (31); 63M-5-103
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(31)(a): "Waste tire transporter" means a person engaged in picking up or transporting at one time more than 10 whole waste tires, or the equivalent amount of material derived from waste tires, generated in Utah for the purpose of storage, processing, or disposal.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(31)(b): (31) "Waste tire transporter" includes a person engaged in the business of collecting, hauling, or transporting waste tires or who performs these functions for another person, except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(31)(c): 63M-5-103 "Waste tire transporter" does not include:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(31)(c)(i): a person transporting waste tires generated solely by:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(31)(c)(i)(A): that person's personal vehicles;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(31)(c)(i)(B): a commercial vehicle fleet owned or operated by that person or that person's employer;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(31)(c)(i)(C): vehicles sold, leased, or purchased by a motor vehicle dealership owned or operated by that person or that person's employer; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(31)(c)(i)(D): a retail tire business owned or operated by that person or that person's employer;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(31)(c)(ii): 63M-5-103 a solid waste collector operating under a license issued by a unit of local government as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(31)(c)(iii): a recycler of waste tires;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(31)(c)(iv): a person transporting tires by rail as a common carrier subject to federal regulation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-803(31)(c)(v): a person transporting processed or chipped tires.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-804(5)(a): (5) An individual, including a waste tire transporter, violating this section is subject to enforcement proceedings and a civil penalty of not more than $100 per waste tire or per passenger tire equivalent disposed of in violation of this section. A warning notice may be issued before taking further enforcement action under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-804(5)(b): A civil proceeding to enforce this section and collect penalties under this section may be brought in the district court where the violation occurred by the director, the local health department, or the county attorney having jurisdiction over the location where the tires were disposed in violation of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-804(5)(c): Penalties collected under this section shall be deposited in the fund.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-805 Recycling fee.
---------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-805(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-805(1)(a): A recycling fee is imposed upon each purchase from a tire retailer of a new tire by a consumer. The fee shall be paid by the consumer to the tire retailer at the time the new tire is purchased.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-805(1)(b): The recycling fee does not apply to recapped or resold used tires.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-805(2): The fee for each tire with a rim diameter up to and including 24.5 inches, single or dual bead capacity is $1.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-812 Landfilling shredded tires -- Reimbursement.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-812(1): Title 19, Chapter 6, Part 1, Solid and Hazardous Waste Act A waste tire may be disposed of in a landfill if:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-812(1)(a): Title 19, Chapter 6, Part 1, Solid and Hazardous Waste Act the land fill is operated in compliance with the requirements of
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-812(1)(b): the waste tire is shredded; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-812(1)(c): the waste tire is stored in a segregated cell or other landfill facility that ensures that the disposed shredded waste tire is in a clean and accessible condition so that the waste tire may be reasonably retrieved and recycled at a future time.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-812(2): (1) The owner or operator of a landfill may apply to the local health department having jurisdiction over the applicant's business address for reimbursement of $20 per ton of waste tires placed in the landfill if:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-812(2)(a): (1) the waste tires are disposed in compliance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-812(2)(b): the waste tires are generated from within the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-812(2)(c): the application includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-812(2)(c)(i): the site from which the waste tires are removed;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-812(2)(c)(ii): the landfill where the waste tires are disposed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-812(2)(c)(iii): the amount of shredded tires disposed.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-812(3): 19-6-813 An application for reimbursement under this section is substantially the same as the application process required of recyclers applying for partial reimbursement under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-812(4): A waste tire, for which reimbursement is paid under this section, is not eligible for additional reimbursement under this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-813(2)(a): is ineligible to receive any further reimbursement under this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-813(2)(b): shall return to the Division of Finance any reimbursement previously received for deposit in the fund.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-814 Local health department responsibility.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-814(1): A local health department that has received an application for partial reimbursement from a recycler shall within 15 calendar days after receiving the application:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-814(1)(a): review the application for completeness;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-814(1)(b): conduct an on-site investigation of the recycler's waste tire use if the application is the initial application of the recycler; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-814(1)(c): submit the recycler's application for partial reimbursement together with a brief written report of the results of the investigation and the dollar amount approved for payment to the Division of Finance.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-814(2): If the local health department approves a dollar amount for partial reimbursement which is less than the amount requested by the recycler, the local health department shall submit its written report of the investigation and recommendation to the recycler at least five days prior to submitting the report and recommendation to the Division of Finance.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-815 Payment by Division of Finance.
--------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-815(1): 19-6-809 The Division of Finance is authorized to pay the recycler partial reimbursements described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-815(2): The Division of Finance shall pay the dollar amount of partial reimbursement approved by the local health department to the recycler within the next payment period established by rule of the Division of Finance, after receipt of the local health department's report and recommendation.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-816 Limitations on reimbursement.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-816(1): The costs reimbursed under this part may not exceed the money in the fund.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-816(2): 19-6-809; 19-6-811; 19-6-812 If applications for reimbursement under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-816(3): The amount remaining unpaid on a claim for reimbursement shall be treated as a new application for reimbursement in the next succeeding month until the unpaid amount is $500 or less, at which time the balance of the claim shall be paid in full.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-816.5(2): 19-6-809(2) At the end of a fiscal year, the Division of Finance shall use surplus funds to make payments to qualified recyclers equal to $10 for each ton of waste tires, material derived from waste tires, or chipped tires, for which the recycler received a partial reimbursement under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-816.5(3): (2) If the surplus funds are insufficient to make the payments described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-821 Violations -- Civil proceedings and penalties -- Orders.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-821(1): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act; 19-6-804(1); (3); (4); 19-6-804(5); 19-6-808(1); (2); (3); 19-6-808(4) A person who violates any provision of this part or any order, permit, plan approval, or rule issued or adopted under this part is subject to a civil penalty of not more than $10,000 per day for each day of violation as determined in a civil hearing under
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-821(1)(a): 19-6-804(1); (3); (4); 19-6-804(5) any violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-821(1)(b): 19-6-808(1); (2); (3); 19-6-808(4) any violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-821(2): The director may bring an action in the name of the state to restrain a person from continuing a violation of this part and to require the person to perform necessary remediation regarding a violation of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-821(3): Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act When the director finds a situation exists in violation of this part that presents an immediate threat to the public health or welfare, the director may issue an emergency order under
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-821(4): The director may revoke the registration of a waste tire recycler or transporter who violates any provision of this part or any order, plan approval, permit, or rule issued or adopted under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-821(5): The director may revoke the tire storage permit for a storage facility that is in violation of any provision of this part or any order, plan approval, permit, or rule issued or adopted under this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-821(6): If a person has been convicted of violating a provision of this part prior to a finding by the director of a violation of the same provision in an administrative hearing, the director may not assess a civil monetary penalty under this section for the same offense for which the conviction was obtained.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-821(7): All penalties collected under this section shall be deposited in the fund.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-901 Title.
-------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Illegal Drug Operations Site Reporting and Decontamination Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-902 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-902(1): 19-1-106 "Board" means the Waste Management and Radiation Control Board, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-902(2): 19-6-906(2) "Certified decontamination specialist" means an individual who has met the standards for certification as a decontamination specialist and has been certified by the board under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-902(3): 26B-7-409 "Contaminated" or "contamination" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-902(3)(a): polluted by hazardous materials that cause property to be unfit for human habitation or use due to immediate or long-term health hazards; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-902(3)(b): 26B-7-409 that a property is polluted by hazardous materials as a result of the use, production, or presence of methamphetamine in excess of decontamination standards adopted by the Department of Health and Human Services under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-902(4): 19-6-903 "Contamination list" means a list maintained by the local health department of properties:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-902(4)(a): 19-6-903 reported to the local health department under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-902(4)(b): determined by the local health department to be contaminated.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-902(5): 26B-7-409
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-902(5)(a): "Decontaminated" means property that at one time was contaminated, but the contaminants have been removed.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-902(5)(b): 26B-7-409 "Decontaminated" for a property that was contaminated by the use, production, or presence of methamphetamine means that the property satisfies decontamination standards adopted by the Department of Health and Human Services under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-902(6): 58-37d-3 "Hazardous materials":
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-902(6)(a): 58-37d-3 has the same meaning as "hazardous or dangerous material" as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-902(6)(b): includes any illegally manufactured controlled substances.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-902(7): Title 26A, Local Health Authorities "Health department" means a local health department under
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-902(8): "Owner of record":
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-902(8)(a): means the owner of real property as shown on the records of the county recorder in the county where the property is located; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-902(8)(b): may include an individual, financial institution, company, corporation, or other entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-902(9): "Property":
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-902(9)(a): means any real property, site, structure, part of a structure, or the grounds surrounding a structure; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-902(9)(b): includes single-family residences, outbuildings, garages, units of multiplexes, condominiums, apartment buildings, warehouses, hotels, motels, boats, motor vehicles, trailers, manufactured housing, shops, or booths.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-902(10): 19-6-903 "Reported property" means property that is the subject of a law enforcement report under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-903 Law enforcement reporting and records -- Removal from list.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-903(1): (1)(a); (1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-903(1)(a): When any state or local law enforcement agency in the course of its official duties observes any paraphernalia of a clandestine drug laboratory operation, including chemicals or equipment used in the manufacture of unlawful drugs, the agency shall report the location where the items were observed to the local health department.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-903(1)(b): (1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-903(1)(b)(i): (1)(a) The law enforcement officer shall make the report under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-903(1)(b)(ii): If the report cannot be made at the location, the report shall be made as soon afterward as is practical.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-903(1)(c): (1)(a) The report under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-903(1)(c)(i): the date of the observation;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-903(1)(c)(ii): the name of the reporting agency and the case number of the case that involves the location of the observation;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-903(1)(c)(iii): the contact information of the officer involved, including name and telephone number;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-903(1)(c)(iv): the address of the location and descriptions of the property that may be contaminated; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-903(1)(c)(v): a brief description of the evidence at the location that led to the belief the property at the location may be contaminated.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-903(2): (1) The law enforcement agency shall forward to the local health department copies of the reports made under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-903(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-903(3)(a): Upon receipt of a complaint or a report from law enforcement regarding possibly contaminated property, the local health officer or his designee shall determine if reasonable evidence exists that the property is contaminated.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-903(3)(b): The local health department shall place property considered to be contaminated on a contamination list.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-903(4): The local health departments shall maintain searchable records of the properties on their contamination lists and shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-903(4)(a): make the records reasonably available to the public;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-903(4)(b): provide written notification to persons requesting access to the records that the records are only advisory in determining if specific property has been contaminated by clandestine drug lab activity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-903(4)(c): remove the contaminated property from the list when the following conditions have been met:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-903(4)(c)(i): the local health department has monitored the decontamination process and, after documenting that the test results meet decontamination standards, has authorized the removal of or purging of the contamination information from the department's records; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-903(4)(c)(ii): a certified decontamination specialist submits a report to the local health department stating that the property is decontaminated.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-904 Decontamination specialist reporting to local health departments.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-904(1): A certified decontamination specialist is required to report to the local health department the location of any property that is the subject of decontamination work by that decontamination specialist.  The report shall be submitted prior to commencement of the decontamination work.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-904(2): (1) The report under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-904(2)(a): sufficient information to allow the local health department to investigate and verify the location of the property, including the address and description of the property; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-904(2)(b): a proposed work plan for decontaminating the property.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-904(3): Upon completion of the decontamination process, a report certifying that the property is decontaminated shall be submitted to the local health department within 30 days.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-905 Notification of property owner -- Notification of municipality or county.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-905(1): 19-6-903(4)(c)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-905(1)(a): If the local health department determines a property is contaminated, it shall notify the owner of record that the property has been placed on the contamination list and shall provide to the owner information regarding remediation options and the requirements necessary to clean up the property, obtain certification that the property is decontaminated, and remove the property from the contamination list.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-905(1)(b): The notification shall include a deadline for the owner to provide to the local health department information on how the owner plans to address the contamination.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-905(1)(c): 19-6-903(4)(c) This part does not require that decontamination be conducted by a certified decontamination specialist.  However, upon completion of the decontamination, the property must be determined to be decontaminated in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-905(2): If the local health department does not receive a response from the owner of record within the time period specified in the notice, or the owner of record advises the local health department that the owner does not intend to take action or that the reported property will be abandoned, the local health department shall notify the municipality in which the reported property is located, or the county, if the location is in an unincorporated area, of the owner of record's response or lack of response.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1001 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Mercury Switch Removal Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1002 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1002(1): 19-1-106 "Board" means the Waste Management and Radiation Control Board created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1002(2): "Director" means the director of the Division of Waste Management and Radiation Control.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1002(3): 19-1-105 "Division" means the Division of Waste Management and Radiation Control created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1002(4): "Manufacturer" means the last person in the production or assembly process of a vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1002(5): "Mercury switch" means a mercury-containing capsule that is part of a convenience light switch assembly installed in a vehicle's hood or trunk.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1002(6): "Person" means an individual, a firm, an association, a partnership, a corporation, the state, or a local government.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1002(7): "Plan" means a plan for removing and collecting mercury switches from vehicles.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1002(8): "Vehicle" means any passenger automobile or car, station wagon, truck, van, or sport utility vehicle that may contain one or more mercury switches.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1003 Board and director powers.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1003(1): Title 63G, Chapter 3, Utah Administrative Rulemaking Act By following the procedures and requirements of
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1003(1)(a): governing administrative proceedings under this part;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1003(1)(b): specifying the terms and conditions under which the director shall approve, disapprove, revoke, or review a plan submitted by a manufacturer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1003(1)(c): governing reports and educational materials required by this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1003(2): These rules shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1003(2)(a): time requirements for plan submission, review, approval, and implementation;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1003(2)(b): a public notice and comment period for a proposed plan; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1003(2)(c): safety standards for the collection, packaging, transportation, storage, recycling, and disposal of mercury switches.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1003(3): 19-6-1006 The director may:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1003(3)(a): review and approve or disapprove plans, specifications, or other data related to mercury switch removal;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1003(3)(b): enforce a rule by issuing a notice, an order, or both;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1003(3)(c): initiate an administrative action to compel compliance with this part and any rules adopted under this part; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1003(3)(d): 19-6-1006 request the attorney general to bring an action for injunctive relief and enforcement of this part, including imposition of the penalty described in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1004 Mercury switch collection plan -- Reimbursement for mercury switch removal.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1004(1): (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1004(1)(a): Each manufacturer of any vehicle sold within this state, individually or in cooperation with other manufacturers, shall submit a plan, accompanied by a fee, to the director.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1004(1)(b): If the director disapproves a plan, the manufacturer shall submit an amended plan within 90 days.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1004(1)(c): (2) A manufacturer shall submit an updated plan within 90 days of any change in the information required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1004(1)(d): The director may require the manufacturer to modify the plan at any time upon finding that an approved plan as implemented has failed to meet the requirements of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1004(1)(e): If the manufacturer does not know or is uncertain about whether or not a switch contains mercury, the plan shall presume that the switch contains mercury.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1004(2): The plan shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1004(2)(a): the make, model, and year of any vehicle, including current and anticipated future production models, sold by the manufacturer that may contain one or more mercury switches;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1004(2)(b): the description and location of each mercury switch for each make, model, and year of vehicle;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1004(2)(c): education materials that include:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1004(2)(c)(i): safe and environmentally sound methods for mercury switch removal; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1004(2)(c)(ii): information about hazards related to mercury and the proper handling of mercury;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1004(2)(d): a method for storage and disposal of the mercury switches, including packaging and shipping of mercury switches to an authorized recycling, storage, or disposal facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1004(2)(e): a procedure for the transfer of information among persons involved with the plan to comply with reporting requirements; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1004(2)(f): a method to implement and finance the plan, which shall include the prompt reimbursement by the manufacturer of costs incurred by a person removing and collecting mercury switches.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1004(3): In order to ensure that the costs of removal and collection of mercury switches are not borne by any other person, the manufacturers of vehicles sold in the state shall pay:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1004(3)(a): a minimum of $5 for each mercury switch removed by a person as partial compensation for the labor and other costs incurred in removing the mercury switch;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1004(3)(b): the cost of packaging necessary to store or transport mercury switches to recycling, storage, or disposal facilities;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1004(3)(c): the cost of shipping mercury switches to recycling, storage, or disposal facilities;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1004(3)(d): the cost of recycling, storage, or disposal of mercury switches;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1004(3)(e): the cost of the preparation and distribution of educational materials; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1004(3)(f): the cost of maintaining all appropriate record-keeping systems.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1004(4): Manufacturers of vehicles sold within this state shall reimburse a person for each mercury switch removed and collected without regard to the date on which the mercury switch is removed and collected.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1004(5): The manufacturer shall ensure that plan implementation occurs by July 1, 2007.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1005 Reporting requirements.
-------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1005(1): Each manufacturer that is required to implement a plan shall submit, either individually or in cooperation with other manufacturers, an annual report on the plan's implementation to the director within 90 days after the anniversary of the date on which the manufacturer is required to begin plan implementation.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1005(2): The report shall include:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1005(2)(a): the number of mercury switches collected;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1005(2)(b): the number of mercury switches for which the manufacturer has provided reimbursement;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1005(2)(c): a description of the successes and failures of the plan; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1005(2)(d): a statement that details the costs required to implement the plan.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-6-1006 Penalties.
------------------------------------------
A manufacturer who fails to submit, modify, or implement a plan according to this part and rules enacted under this part is subject to a civil penalty of not more than $1,000 per day per violation as determined in an administrative proceeding conducted according to the board's rules.
