Utah Code Annotated - Title 19 - Chapter 7 - Environmental Self-Evaluation Act
******************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-101 Title.
-------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Environmental Self-Evaluation Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-102 Purposes.
----------------------------------------
The purpose of this chapter is to:Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-102(1): enhance the environment through voluntary compliance with environmental laws; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-102(2): provide incentives to voluntarily identify and remedy environmental compliance problems.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-103 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-103(1): 19-1-305; Title 63G, Chapter 4, Administrative Procedures Act "Administrative proceeding" means an adjudicatory proceeding conducted by the  department or other government entity with authority to enforce any environmental law, including any notice of violation proceeding, any department proceeding listed in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-103(2): "Environmental audit report" means any document, information, report, finding, communication, note, drawing, graph, chart, photograph, survey, suggestion, or opinion, whether in preliminary, draft, or final form, prepared as the result of or in response to an environmental self-evaluation.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-103(3): "Environmental law" means any requirement contained in this title, or in rules made under this title, or in any rules, orders, permits, licenses, or closure plans issued or approved by the department, or in any other provision or ordinance addressing protection of the environment.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-103(4): "Environmental self-evaluation" means a self-initiated assessment, audit, or review, not otherwise expressly required by an environmental law, that is performed to determine whether a person is in compliance with environmental laws.  A person may perform an environmental self-evaluation through the use of employees or the use of outside consultants.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-104 Unlawful disclosure -- Environmental audit report.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-104(1): Information that is divulged, disseminated, or otherwise disclosed in violation of Utah Rules of Evidence, Rule 508, may not be admitted as evidence in an administrative or judicial proceeding.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-104(2): If any person, including a department employee or a presiding hearing officer, divulges or disseminates any part of the information contained in an environmental audit report and that report is privileged under Utah Rules of Evidence, Rule 508, the privilege is not waived except as provided under Utah Rules of Evidence, Rule 508(d)(1).
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-104(3): Title 63G, Chapter 2, Government Records Access and Management Act; Title 63G, Chapter 2, Government Records Access and Management Act An environmental audit report obtained pursuant to an in camera review is a protected record for purposes of


Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-105 Privilege in administrative proceeding.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
An environmental audit report is privileged in accordance with and to the extent provided by Utah Rules of Evidence, Rule 508, Environmental Self-Evaluation Privilege, in any administrative proceeding.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-106 In camera review -- Burden of proof.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-106(1): The person seeking disclosure of an environmental audit report shall request an in camera review of the audit report by a court of record.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-106(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-106(2)(a): If a court of record determines through in camera review that all or part of an environmental audit report is not privileged, the court shall order the disclosure of the nonprivileged portions of the environmental audit report.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-106(2)(b): The privileged portions of the environmental audit report may not be disclosed.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-106(3): The person asserting the environmental self-evaluation privilege has the burden of establishing a prima facie case of privilege.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-106(4): The person seeking disclosure of an environmental audit report has the burden of proving that the environmental audit report is not privileged or excepted pursuant to the Utah Rules of Evidence, Rule 508.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-107 Privileged communications.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-107(1): 19-7-103; 19-7-103 A person or an officer or employee of that person who performs an environmental self-evaluation, as defined by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-107(2): (1) Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-108 Scope of chapter.
------------------------------------------------
This chapter shall apply to all administrative and judicial proceedings commenced on or after March 21, 1995.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-109 Incentives for voluntary disclosure and compliance -- Waiver of civil penalties.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-109(1): Title 19, Environmental Quality Code As used in this section, "regulated entity" means any person, business, or other entity subject to regulation under
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-109(2): The department shall waive civil penalties for an instance of noncompliance with an environmental law or requirement:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-109(2)(a): that a regulated entity discovered through an environmental self-evaluation;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-109(2)(b): that a regulated entity voluntarily disclosed to the department in writing within 21 days after the entity's  discovery of the violation;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-109(2)(c): that a regulated entity remedied or corrected within 60 days after discovery of the violation, or within a reasonable amount of time if the violation cannot be remedied within 60 days; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-109(2)(d): regarding which the regulated entity submitted to the department a written outline of reasonable steps the regulated entity will take to prevent a recurrence.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-109(3): (2) The department may not waive penalties under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-109(3)(a): the instance of noncompliance resulted from a lack of due diligence in complying with environmental laws, taking into account the size and nature of the regulated entity;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-109(3)(b): the instance of noncompliance is a recurrence of a similarly caused specific violation or a violation of the specific terms of a judicial or administrative consent order or agreement;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-109(3)(c): the instance of noncompliance resulted from reckless or willful disregard of environmental laws;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-109(3)(d): the regulated entity conducted the environmental self-evaluation for a fraudulent purpose;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-109(3)(e): the department had already initiated a compliance investigation at the time of the disclosure and the regulated entity had been advised of or was aware of the investigation;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-109(3)(f): the instance of noncompliance was discovered pursuant to a legally mandated monitoring, testing, or sampling requirement prescribed by law, rule, permit, order, or consent agreement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-109(3)(g): the instance of noncompliance resulted in serious actual harm or imminent and substantial endangerment to human health or the environment.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-109(4): (4); (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-109(4)(a): To the extent the instance of noncompliance resulted in an economic benefit or competitive advantage over other similar regulated entities that did achieve compliance, the department may seek a civil penalty to recover the monetary amount of the economic benefit or competitive advantage resulting from the incidence of noncompliance.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-109(4)(b): (4); (2) Action under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-7-109(5): This section does not limit the department's discretion in reducing penalties for noncompliance with an environmental law which may not fully qualify for waiver under this section, but which the department determines should be appropriately reduced.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-103 Creation of restricted account -- Purposes.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-103(1): There is created within the General Fund the Environmental Voluntary Cleanup restricted account.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-103(2): The account shall be used to fund department administration and oversight of voluntary cleanups initiated under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-103(3): The account may earn interest, which shall be deposited in the account, to be used for the purposes under this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-104 Program.
---------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-104(1): There is created under this chapter and within the Department of Environmental Quality the Voluntary Environmental Cleanup Program.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-104(2): The program shall be administered by the executive director.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-104(3): The program shall be funded by application fees and imposed oversight costs as provided in this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-105 Eligibility and exceptions -- Grounds for application rejection by executive director.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Subject to SectionUtah Code Annotated § 19-8-105(1): a treatment, storage, or disposal facility regulated under 42 U.S.C. 6901 et seq.;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-105(2): that portion of a site that is on the national priorities list; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-105(3): that portion of a site for which a state or federal enforcement action is existing or pending against the applicant for remediation of the contaminants described in the application.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-106 Rejection of application -- Notice to applicant -- Resubmission procedure.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-106(1): 19-8-105 The executive director may in his sole discretion reject an application prior to accepting the application fee, and return the application fee to the applicant if:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-106(1)(a): the executive director has reason to believe that a working relationship with the applicant cannot be achieved; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-106(1)(b): 19-8-105 the application site is not eligible under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-106(2): (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-106(2)(a): The executive director may reject an application after processing the application if:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-106(2)(a)(i): the application is not complete or is not accurate; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-106(2)(a)(ii): the applicant has not demonstrated financial capability to perform the voluntary cleanup.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-106(2)(b): (2) The applicant is not entitled to refund of an application fee for an application rejected under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-106(3): (1); (2) An application rejected under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-106(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-106(4)(a): If the executive director rejects an application because it is incomplete or inaccurate, the executive director shall, not later than 60 days after receipt of the application, provide to the applicant a list in writing of all information needed to make the application complete or accurate, as appropriate.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-106(4)(b): The applicant may submit for a second time an application rejected due to inaccuracy or incompleteness without submitting an additional application fee.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-108 Voluntary agreement -- Procedure and establishment.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-108(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-108(1)(a): Before the executive director may evaluate any detailed plan or report regarding the remediation goals and proposed methods of remediation, the applicant and the executive director shall have entered into a voluntary cleanup agreement under this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-108(1)(b): The agreement shall establish the terms and conditions for the evaluation of investigation, remediation, and status reports.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-108(2): Before the applicant may initiate any response action covered by an agreement, a voluntary cleanup agreement shall have been signed by the applicant and the executive director, except that the applicant may take emergency measures as necessary, but shall coordinate these measures with the appropriate emergency response authorities.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-108(3): 19-8-107 A voluntary cleanup agreement shall provide for:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-108(3)(a): 19-8-107 recovery by the department of all reasonable costs:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-108(3)(a)(i): incurred in the voluntary cleanup in the review and oversight of the applicant's work plan and reports and as a result of the department's field activities regarding the cleanup;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-108(3)(a)(ii): attributable to the voluntary cleanup agreement; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-108(3)(a)(iii): 19-8-107 in excess of the amount of fees submitted by the applicant under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-108(3)(b): a schedule of payments by the applicant to the department, to be made by the applicant for recovery of all department costs attributable to the voluntary cleanup program, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-108(3)(b)(i): direct and indirect costs of overhead, salaries, equipment, and utilities;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-108(3)(b)(ii): legal, management, and support costs; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-108(3)(b)(iii): appropriate tasks, deliverables, and schedules.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-108(4): (4)(b) A voluntary cleanup agreement shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-108(4)(a): identify all statutes and rules with which the applicant shall comply;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-108(4)(b): describe any work plan or report the applicant shall submit to the executive director for review, including a final report that provides all information necessary for the executive director to confirm that all work contemplated by the voluntary cleanup agreement has been completed;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-108(4)(c): (4)(b) include a schedule for submitting the information required by Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-108(4)(d): state the technical standards to be applied in evaluating the work plans and reports.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-108(5): If an agreement under this section is not established between the applicant and the executive director within 30 days after good faith negotiations between the parties have been initiated:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-108(5)(a): the applicant or the executive director may, upon providing written notice to the other party, withdraw from the negotiations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-108(5)(b): the applicant's application fee is not refundable.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-108(6): The department may not initiate an enforcement action against an applicant regarding a contamination or release, or any activity that resulted in the contamination or release if the applicant:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-108(6)(a): is in compliance with this chapter regarding the contamination or release; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-108(6)(b): has entered into a voluntary cleanup agreement that is in effect under this chapter regarding the contamination or release.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-109 Termination of agreement -- Cost recovery.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-109(1): An agreement established under this chapter may be terminated by the executive director or the applicant by giving 15 days prior notice, in writing, to the other party.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-109(2): (2)
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-109(2)(a): Only those costs incurred or obligated by the executive director prior to the date of termination of the agreement are recoverable under an agreement terminated under this section.  Any unused amounts already paid by the applicant to the department as of the date of termination, other than the application fee, are refundable to the applicant.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-109(2)(b): (2) The executive director shall provide to the applicant written and itemized notification of all costs for which the applicant is liable under this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-109(3): (2)(b) If the applicant does not pay to the executive director the department's costs incurred in the voluntary cleanup within 90 days after the date the applicant receives written notice under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-109(4): Termination of an agreement under this section does not affect any right of the:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-109(4)(a): executive director to recover costs under any other law; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-109(4)(b): department to take enforcement and other action as allowed by law.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-110 Voluntary cleanup work plans and reports.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-110(1): After the applicant and the executive director have signed the voluntary cleanup agreement, the applicant shall prepare and submit the appropriate work plans and reports to the executive director as provided in the agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-110(2): The executive director shall review and evaluate the work plans and reports for accuracy, quality, and completeness.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-110(3): The executive director may approve a voluntary cleanup work plan or report, or if he does not approve the work plan or a report, he shall notify the applicant in writing concerning additional information or commitments necessary to obtain approval.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-110(4): At any time during the evaluation of a work plan or report, the executive director may request the applicant to submit additional or corrected information.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-110(5): After considering the proposed future use of the property that is the subject of the agreement, the executive director may approve work plans and reports submitted under this section that do not require removal or remedy of all discharges, releases, and threatened releases on the property if the applicant's response actions under the agreement:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-110(5)(a): will be completed in a manner that protects human health and the environment;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-110(5)(b): will not cause, contribute to, or exacerbate discharges, releases, or threatened releases on the property that are not required to be removed or remedied under the work plan; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-110(5)(c): will not interfere with or substantially increase the costs of response actions to address any remaining discharges, releases, or threatened releases resulting from releases initially generated on the property.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-111(2)(d): 19-8-108; 19-8-110 state the applicant has complied with the voluntary cleanup agreement and has met the requirements of Sections
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-111(3): The executive director shall upon issuance of the certificate of completion record a copy in the real property records of the county in which the site is located.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-114 Additional permits not required.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-114(1): Response action conducted as part of a voluntary cleanup agreement under this chapter does not require a state or local environmental permit, except as required by a program delegated to the state by the federal government under this title.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-114(2): The department shall by rule require that the applicant conducting the voluntary cleanup under this chapter comply with any federal or state standard, requirement, criterion, or limitation to which the response action would otherwise be subject if a permit were required.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-115 Rules -- Public notice -- Participation.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
The department shall make rules as necessary to administer this chapter.  The rules shall include provisions for public participation by, and notice to, affected property owners regarding voluntary cleanup decisions.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-120(7)(e): (9) comply with administrative rules made under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-120(8): (9) Grants made under this section shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-120(8)(a): be for no greater amount than allowed by the federal grant; and

Utah Code Annotated § 19-8-120(9)(a): form, content, and procedure for loan and grant applications;

Utah Code Annotated - Title 19 - Chapter 10 - Environmental Institutional Control Act
*************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-101 Title -- Scope.
-----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-101(1): This chapter is known as the "Environmental Institutional Control Act."
Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-101(2): Title 57, Chapter 25, Uniform Environmental Covenants Act
Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-101(2)(a): This chapter applies to an environmental institutional control created before May 1, 2006.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-101(2)(b): Title 57, Chapter 25, Uniform Environmental Covenants Act


Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-102(1): "Environmental institutional control" or "institutional control" means, with respect to real property, any deed restriction, restrictive covenant, easement, reservation, environmental notice, engineering control, or other restriction or obligation that is designed to protect human health or the environment and:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-102(1)(a): is established in connection with a cleanup or risk assessment that is reviewed, overseen, conducted, or administered by the department; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-102(1)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-102(1)(b)(i): limits the use of the real property, groundwater, or surface water;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-102(1)(b)(ii): limits activities that may be performed on or at the property; or
Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-102(1)(b)(iii): requires maintenance of any engineering or other control.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-102(2): "Executive director" means the executive director of the state Department of Environment Quality or the executive director's designated representative.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-103 Establishment of environmental institutional controls.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
An owner of real property may, with the approval of the executive director, restrict the use of the real property by imposing on the real property appropriate environmental institutional controls to mitigate the risk posed to the public health, safety, or welfare, or the environment.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-104 Requirements for creation of institutional control.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
An environmental institutional control shall:Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-104(1): be in writing and shall be recorded by the owner of the real property in the county recorder's office in the county where the real property is located;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-104(2): contain a legal description of the area of the real property that is subject to the institutional control;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-104(3): include a statement documenting any requirements for maintenance of the institutional control, including a description of the institutional control and the reason it must remain in place to protect the public health, safety, or welfare, or the environment;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-104(4): 19-10-105 include a statement that the institutional control runs with the land and is binding on all successors in interest unless or until the institutional control is removed as provided in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-104(5): include a statement acknowledging the department's right of access to the property at all reasonable times to verify that the institutional controls are being maintained;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-104(6): include a statement explaining how the institutional control can be modified or terminated and stating that if any person desires to cancel or modify the institutional control in the future, the person shall obtain prior written approval from the executive director pursuant to this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-104(7): include a notarized signature of the executive director indicating approval of the environmental institutional control; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-104(8): include the notarized signature of the property owner indicating approval of the environmental institutional control.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-105 Termination of institutional control.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-105(1): An owner may request in writing that the executive director approve termination or modification of the environmental institutional control.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-105(2): An environmental institutional control may be terminated or modified, in whole or in part, if the executive director determines an unacceptable risk is not posed to public health, safety, or welfare, or the environment.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-105(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-105(3)(a): The executive director shall review the request and provide to the owner a written decision approving or denying the request within 120 days from the executive director's receipt of the request.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-105(3)(b): If the executive director denies the request, the executive director shall send the owner a written explanation for the denial.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-105(3)(c): If the executive director approves an owner's request to terminate or modify all or a portion of the environmental institutional controls, the owner shall file the approval with the county recorder in the county in which the real property is located.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-106 Enforcement and inspection regarding institutional controls.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-106(1): An environmental institutional control may be enforced or protected by a temporary restraining order or an injunction obtained in a court of competent jurisdiction by the department or other affected parties.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-106(2): In addition to injunctive relief, the department is entitled to recover costs for actions which, in its discretion, it may take in enforcing and protecting the institutional controls.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-106(3): The department may enter the property at reasonable times to ensure compliance with the environmental institutional controls.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-107 Records regarding institutional controls.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
The department shall maintain a record of the properties subject to environmental institutional controls established under this chapter.  The department may archive the records.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-10-108 Appeals of institutional control decisions.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Any determination by the executive director under this chapter may be appealed as provided in

Utah Code Annotated - Title 19 - Chapter 11 - Western Interstate Nuclear Compact
********************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 19-11-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This chapter is known as the "Western Interstate Nuclear Compact."

Utah Code Annotated § 19-11-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 19-11-102(1): The words "the compact" or "this compact" mean the Western Interstate Nuclear Compact.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-11-102(2): The words "the board" mean the Western Interstate Nuclear Board.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-11-201 Text of compact.
------------------------------------------------
The Western Interstate Nuclear Compact is hereby enacted into law in the state of Utah and entered into with all other states legally joining therein, in the form substantially as follows:

Utah Code Annotated § 19-11-301 Utah member of board -- Designation.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
The member of the board representing the state of Utah shall be designated by the governor of the state of Utah.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-11-302 Alternate member.
-------------------------------------------------
The alternate required pursuant to Article II(a) of the compact shall be designated by the board member representing this state and shall serve at the board member's pleasure.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-11-401 Bylaws of board to be filed.
------------------------------------------------------------
Pursuant to Article II(j) of the compact, the board shall file copies of its bylaws and any amendments thereto with the Division of Archives.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 19 - Chapter 13 - Recycling Market Development Zone Act
***********************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-101 Title.
--------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Recycling Market Development Zone Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-102 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-102(1): "Composting" means the controlled decay of landscape waste or sewage sludge and organic industrial waste, or a mixture of these, by the action of bacteria, fungi, molds, and other organisms.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-102(2): "Postconsumer waste material" means any product generated by a business or consumer that has served its intended end use, and that has been separated from solid waste for the purposes of collection, recycling, and disposition and that does not include secondary waste material.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-102(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-102(3)(a): "Recovered materials" means waste materials and by-products that have been recovered or diverted from solid waste.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-102(3)(b): "Recovered materials" does not include those materials and by-products generated from, and commonly reused within, an original manufacturing process.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-102(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-102(4)(a): "Recycling" means the diversion of materials from the solid waste stream and the beneficial use of the materials and includes a series of activities by which materials that would become or otherwise remain waste are diverted from the waste stream for collection, separation, and processing, and are used as raw materials or feedstocks in lieu of or in addition to virgin materials in the manufacture of goods sold or distributed in commerce or the reuse of the materials as substitutes for goods made from virgin materials.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-102(4)(b): "Recycling" does not include burning municipal solid waste for energy recovery.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-102(5): "Recycling market development zone" or "zone" means an area designated by the office as meeting the requirements of this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-102(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-102(6)(a): "Secondary waste material" means industrial by-products that go to disposal facilities and waste generated after completion of a manufacturing process.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-102(6)(b): "Secondary waste material" does not include internally generated scrap commonly returned to industrial or manufacturing processes, such as home scrap and mill broke.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-102(7): 59-7-610; 59-10-1007 "Tax incentive" means a nonrefundable tax credit available under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-103 Duties of the department.
---------------------------------------------------------
The department shall:Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-103(1): facilitate recycling development zones through state support of county incentives that encourage development of manufacturing enterprises that use recycling materials currently collected;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-103(2): evaluate an application from a county or municipality executive authority to be designated as a recycling market development zone and determine if the county or municipality qualifies for that designation;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-103(3): provide technical assistance to municipalities and counties in developing applications for designation as a recycling market development zone;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-103(4): assist counties and municipalities designated as recycling market development zones in obtaining assistance from the federal government and agencies of the state;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-103(5): assist a qualified business in obtaining the benefits of an incentive or inducement program authorized by this part; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-103(6): monitor the implementation and operation of this part and conduct a continuing evaluation of the progress made in the recycling market development zone.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-104 Criteria for recycling market development zone -- Application process and fees.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-104(1): 19-13-105 An area may be designated as a recycling market development zone only if:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-104(1)(a): 19-13-105 the county or municipality agrees to make a qualifying local contribution under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-104(1)(b): the county or municipality provides for postconsumer waste collection for recycling within the county or municipality.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-104(3)(b)(iii): the county's or municipality's economic development plan and demonstration of coordination between the zone and the county or municipality in overall development goals;

Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-104(3)(f): any additional information the county or municipality considers relevant to its designation as a recycling market development zone.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-105 Qualifying local contributions.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Qualifying local contributions to the recycling market development zone may vary depending on available resources, and may include:Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-105(1): simplified procedures for obtaining permits;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-105(2): dedication of available government grants;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-105(3): waiver of business license or permit fees;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-105(4): infrastructure improvements;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-105(5): private contributions;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-105(6): utility rate concessions;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-105(7): suspension or relaxation of locally originated zoning laws or general plans; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-105(8): other proposed local contributions as the department finds promote the purposes of this part.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-106 Eligibility review.
---------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-106(1): 19-13-104 The department shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-106(1)(a): 19-13-104 review and evaluate an application submitted under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-106(1)(b): determine whether the municipality or county is eligible for designation as a recycling market development zone.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-106(2): In designating recycling market development zones, the department shall consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-106(2)(a): whether the current waste management practices and conditions of the county or municipality are favorable to the development of postconsumer waste material markets;
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-106(2)(b): whether the creation of the zone is necessary to assist in attracting private sector recycling investments to the area; and
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-106(2)(c): the amount of available landfill capacity to serve the zone.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-107 Quarterly consideration.
--------------------------------------------------------
The department shall take action quarterly on any application requesting designation as a recycling market development zone.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-108 Duration of designation.
--------------------------------------------------------
A recycling market development zone designation ends five years from the date the department designates the area as a recycling market development zone, at the end of which the county or municipality may reapply for the designation.

Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-109 Revocation of designations.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-109(1): The department may revoke the designation of a recycling market development zone if no businesses utilize the tax incentives during any calendar year.
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-109(2): Before revocation of the zone, the department shall conduct a public hearing within a reasonable distance of the zone to determine reasons for inactivity and explore possible alternative actions.


Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-110 Recycling market development zone credit.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
For a taxpayer within a recycling market development zone, there are allowed the nonrefundable credits against tax as provided by Sections

Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-111 Annual report.
----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 19-13-111(1): A county or municipality designated as a recycling market development zone shall report by no later than July 31 of each year to the department regarding the economic activity that has occurred in the zone following the designation.
